cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 001. Personal Jurisdiction Overview
cards.backPlain: 1. Personal jurisdiction involves the court's ability to exercise authority over parties or their property. 1.1. The core concept is fairness—i.e., is it fair for this court to exercise jurisdiction over this defendant? 1.2. The court must balance the state's interest in protecting its citizens with due process rights protecting against unfair exercise of jurisdiction. 1.3. Perform this analysis for each defendant separately. 1.4. Statutory and constitutional constraints can limit the court's jurisdiction. 2. Personal-jurisdiction analysis: jurisdiction must be both statutorily authorized and constitutional. 2.1. Statutory: an applicable state law must authorize jurisdiction. Usually a long-arm statute will apply. 2.2. Constitutional: jurisdiction must satisfy due process. 2.2.1. Minimum contacts: parties must have minimum contacts with the forum state. 2.2.2. Adequate notice: parties must receive adequate notice of the action and an opportunity to be heard.
cards.frontPrompt: What is personal jurisdiction, and what are the basic statutory and constitutional requirements for a court to exercise it?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Personal jurisdiction}} involves the court's ability to exercise authority over parties or their property. 1.1. The core concept is {{c2::fairness}}—i.e., is it fair for this court to exercise jurisdiction over this defendant? 1.2. The court must balance the {{c3::state's interest in protecting its citizens}} with {{c4::due process rights protecting against unfair exercise of jurisdiction}}. 1.3. Perform this analysis for {{c5::each defendant separately}}. 1.4. {{c6::Statutory and constitutional constraints}} can limit the court's jurisdiction. 2. Personal-jurisdiction analysis: jurisdiction must be both {{c7::statutorily authorized}} and {{c8::constitutional}}. 2.1. Statutory: an applicable state law must authorize jurisdiction. Usually a {{c9::long-arm statute}} will apply. 2.2. Constitutional: jurisdiction must satisfy {{c10::due process}}. 2.2.1. {{c11::Minimum contacts}}: parties must have minimum contacts with the forum state. 2.2.2. {{c12::Adequate notice}}: parties must receive adequate notice of the action and an {{c13::opportunity to be heard}}.
cards.easyContent: Personal jurisdiction is the court’s power over parties or their property. It must be authorized by statute (usually a long-arm statute) and satisfy due process through minimum contacts and adequate notice.
cards.mediumContent: Personal jurisdiction is the court's authority over parties or their property, grounded in fairness. The court balances the forum state's interests against the defendant's due process rights and must conduct the analysis for each defendant separately. Jurisdiction must be statutorily authorized (typically under a state long-arm statute) and constitutionally valid by satisfying due process: there must be minimum contacts with the forum and adequate notice plus an opportunity to be heard.
cards.hardContent: Personal jurisdiction is the court's ability to exercise authority over parties or their property, with fairness as the core concept—i.e., whether it is fair for this particular court to exercise jurisdiction over this defendant. The court balances the forum state's interest in protecting its citizens against the defendant's due process rights, and it must conduct this analysis for each defendant separately. Personal jurisdiction must be both statutorily authorized—usually via a state long-arm statute—and constitutional, meaning it satisfies due process by requiring minimum contacts with the forum state and adequate notice of the action plus an opportunity to be heard.
cards.mnemonic: PJ = Statute + MC + Notice (due process satisfied).
cards.clozeLite: Personal jurisdiction is a court's power over {{c1::parties or their property}}, requiring {{c2::statutory authorization}} and {{c3::constitutional due process}} via {{c4::minimum contacts}} and {{c5::adequate notice}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 002. Types of Personal Jurisdiction
cards.backPlain: 1. In personam jurisdiction: jurisdiction over persons. 1.1. The court may render a judgment (money or injunction) against an individual based on that person's contacts with the forum state. 2. In rem jurisdiction: jurisdiction over property or status, including ownership disputes. 2.1. The court adjudicates the rights of parties with respect to property located in the forum state. 2.2. The judgment is binding as to the disposition of property rights or status, not as to the parties personally. 2.3. In rem jurisdiction often involves estate issues, business proceedings, or property disputes (e.g., an action to quiet title). 3. Quasi in rem jurisdiction: permits a court without personal jurisdiction over a defendant to determine certain types of disputes between a plaintiff and defendant when property is located in the forum state. 3.1. Property is attached for some reason not necessarily involving the property itself (e.g., an action against a defendant and his assets due to fears he will flee the state). 3.2. The court may render a judgment as to the parties with respect to the property (rather than a judgment over the person generally or over the property itself).
cards.frontPrompt: What are the three main types of personal jurisdiction—in personam, in rem, and quasi in rem—and how do they differ?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::In personam jurisdiction}}: jurisdiction over persons. 1.1. The court may {{c2::render a judgment (money or injunction) against an individual}} based on that person's {{c3::contacts with the forum state}}. 2. {{c4::In rem jurisdiction}}: jurisdiction over {{c5::property or status}}, including ownership disputes. 2.1. The court adjudicates the rights of parties with respect to {{c6::property located in the forum state}}. 2.2. The judgment is binding as to the {{c7::disposition of property rights or status}}, not as to the parties personally. 2.3. In rem jurisdiction often involves {{c8::estate issues, business proceedings, or property disputes}} (e.g., an action to quiet title). 3. {{c9::Quasi in rem jurisdiction}}: permits a court without personal jurisdiction over a defendant to determine certain types of disputes between a plaintiff and defendant when {{c10::property is located in the forum state}}. 3.1. Property is {{c11::attached}} for some reason not necessarily involving the property itself (e.g., an action against a defendant and his assets due to fears he will flee the state). 3.2. The court may render a judgment as to the parties {{c12::with respect to the property}} (rather than a judgment over the person generally or over the property itself).
cards.easyContent: There are three types of jurisdiction: in personam (power over the person), in rem (power over property or status), and quasi in rem (using property in the forum to resolve a dispute when the court lacks full personal jurisdiction).
cards.mediumContent: In personam jurisdiction is power over the person and allows the court to enter money or injunctive judgments based on the defendant's contacts with the forum. In rem jurisdiction is power over property or status; the court adjudicates rights in property located in the forum, and the judgment binds only property rights or status. Quasi in rem jurisdiction lets a court without full personal jurisdiction resolve disputes using property in the forum that is attached, with the judgment limited to the parties' interests in that property.
cards.hardContent: In personam jurisdiction is jurisdiction over persons and allows a court to render judgments, such as money damages or injunctions, against an individual based on that person's contacts with the forum state. In rem jurisdiction is jurisdiction over property or status; the court adjudicates rights in property located in the forum, and the resulting judgment is binding as to the disposition of property rights or status, but not as to the parties personally. In rem actions often involve estates, business proceedings, or property disputes such as actions to quiet title. Quasi in rem jurisdiction permits a court that lacks personal jurisdiction over a defendant to determine certain disputes when the defendant's property is located in the forum: the property is attached, sometimes for reasons not directly involving the property itself (for example, to secure assets if the defendant may flee), and the court's judgment is limited to the parties' rights with respect to that property.
cards.mnemonic: PJ is P-R-Q: Person, Res, quasi reach through property.
cards.clozeLite: Three types of PJ: {{c1::in personam}} (power over person), {{c2::in rem}} (power over property or status), and {{c3::quasi in rem}} (using property when no full PJ).

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 003. Statutory Limitations on Personal Jurisdiction
cards.backPlain: State laws often determine when courts may exercise jurisdiction. A federal court must analyze jurisdiction as would the state court in which it sits and must follow applicable state statutes. Note: the court's exercise of jurisdiction must also satisfy constitutional requirements. Most state statutes grant courts in personam jurisdiction if: 1. Service of process: the defendant is personally served in the forum state. The duration of the defendant's presence is irrelevant. 2. Domicile: the defendant is domiciled in the forum state. Domicile means the defendant maintains a permanent home in the forum state. A court can exercise jurisdiction over domiciled persons even if they are not physically present when served. 3. Consent: the defendant consents to jurisdiction (expressly or impliedly). 4. Long-arm statute: the defendant's acts fall within the state's long-arm statute. 4.1. General/unlimited long-arm statute: confers the state's courts with jurisdiction to the full extent allowed by the Constitution. 4.2. Limited/enumerated long-arm statute: specifies when state courts can exercise jurisdiction based on particular acts or contacts.
cards.frontPrompt: What statutory bases commonly authorize a court to exercise in personam jurisdiction over a defendant?
cards.cloze: State laws often determine when courts may exercise jurisdiction. A federal court must analyze jurisdiction as would the state court in which it sits and must follow applicable {{c1::state statutes}}. Note: the court's exercise of jurisdiction must also satisfy {{c2::constitutional requirements}}. Most state statutes grant courts in personam jurisdiction if: 1. {{c3::Service of process}}: the defendant is personally served in the forum state. The duration of the defendant's presence is irrelevant. 2. {{c4::Domicile}}: the defendant is domiciled in the forum state. Domicile means the defendant maintains a {{c5::permanent home}} in the forum state. A court can exercise jurisdiction over domiciled persons even if they are not physically present when served. 3. {{c6::Consent}}: the defendant consents to jurisdiction (expressly or impliedly). 4. {{c7::Long-arm statute}}: the defendant's acts fall within the state's long-arm statute. 4.1. {{c8::General/unlimited long-arm statute}}: confers the state's courts with jurisdiction to the full extent allowed by the Constitution. 4.2. {{c9::Limited/enumerated long-arm statute}}: specifies when state courts can exercise jurisdiction based on particular acts or contacts.
cards.easyContent: State statutes, applied by both state and federal courts, limit when courts can exercise personal jurisdiction. Common statutory bases are personal service in the forum, domicile, consent, and long-arm statutes.
cards.mediumContent: Statutory limits on personal jurisdiction come from state laws that federal courts must apply as state courts would. In personam jurisdiction is usually proper when the defendant is personally served in the forum, is domiciled in the forum, consents to jurisdiction, or when the defendant's acts fall within the state's long-arm statute. Long-arm statutes may be general, extending to the full constitutional limit, or limited, enumerating specific acts that permit jurisdiction. All statutory grants must still satisfy constitutional due process.
cards.hardContent: State statutes define when courts may exercise personal jurisdiction, and a federal court sitting in diversity must analyze jurisdiction as a state court in the forum would, following applicable state statutes. Even when a statute authorizes jurisdiction, the exercise must also satisfy constitutional due process. Most states confer in personam jurisdiction where: (1) the defendant is personally served in the forum state, regardless of how long she is present; (2) the defendant is domiciled in the forum, meaning she maintains a permanent home there, allowing jurisdiction even if she is not physically present when served; (3) the defendant expressly or impliedly consents to jurisdiction; or (4) the defendant’s acts fall within a state long-arm statute. Long-arm statutes may be general/unlimited, authorizing jurisdiction to the full extent permitted by the Constitution, or limited/enumerated, specifying particular acts or contacts that will support jurisdiction.
cards.mnemonic: S-D-C-L: Service, Domicile, Consent, Long-arm.
cards.clozeLite: In personam jurisdiction is usually proper when a defendant is {{c1::personally served in the forum}}, {{c2::domiciled in the forum}}, {{c3::consents to jurisdiction}}, or {{c4::falls within the state's long-arm statute}}; {{c5::all statutory grants must still satisfy constitutional due process}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 004. Constitutional Limitations on Personal Jurisdiction
cards.backPlain: To be subject to personal jurisdiction, the defendant must have such minimum contacts with the forum state that exercising jurisdiction does not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice. 1. Analysis: minimum contacts, relatedness, and fairness. 2. Minimum contacts: the defendant must have sufficient minimum contacts with the forum state; the inquiry focuses on: 2.1. Purposeful availment: did the defendant avail herself of the forum state's laws? 2.2. Foreseeability: did the defendant know of or anticipate being held accountable for her in-forum activities? 3. Fair play and substantial justice (see related cards for more detail): given the defendant's contacts, the exercise of jurisdiction must not offend these notions; the inquiry focuses on factors such as: 3.1. Convenience: would litigating in the forum severely disadvantage the defendant? 3.2. The state's interest: does the forum state have an interest in providing redress for residents or an interest in the outcome?
cards.frontPrompt: What does due process require for constitutional personal jurisdiction, and what are the key components of the minimum-contacts analysis?
cards.cloze: To be subject to personal jurisdiction, the defendant must have such {{c1::minimum contacts}} with the forum state that exercising jurisdiction does not offend {{c2::traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice}}. 1. Analysis: {{c3::minimum contacts, relatedness, and fairness}}. 2. Minimum contacts: the defendant must have sufficient minimum contacts with the forum state; the inquiry focuses on: 2.1. {{c4::Purposeful availment}}: did the defendant avail herself of the forum state's laws? 2.2. {{c5::Foreseeability}}: did the defendant know of or anticipate being held accountable for her in-forum activities? 3. {{c6::Fair play and substantial justice}} (see related cards for more detail): given the defendant's contacts, the exercise of jurisdiction must not offend these notions; the inquiry focuses on factors such as: 3.1. {{c7::Convenience}}: would litigating in the forum severely disadvantage the defendant? 3.2. The {{c8::state's interest}}: does the forum state have an interest in providing redress for residents or an interest in the outcome?
cards.easyContent: Due process requires that a defendant have minimum contacts with the forum such that exercising jurisdiction does not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice. The core ideas are purposeful availment, foreseeability, and fairness.
cards.mediumContent: Constitutional limits on personal jurisdiction require minimum contacts with the forum and that jurisdiction not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice. Minimum contacts focus on whether the defendant purposefully availed herself of the forum's laws and could foresee being haled into that forum. Fairness considers factors like the convenience to the defendant and the forum state's interest in hearing the case.
cards.hardContent: Under due process, a defendant is subject to personal jurisdiction only if she has such minimum contacts with the forum state that exercising jurisdiction does not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice. The analysis looks at minimum contacts, relatedness, and fairness. For minimum contacts, courts ask whether the defendant purposefully availed herself of the benefits and protections of the forum state's laws and whether it was foreseeable that she would be haled into court there based on her in-forum activities. The fairness, or fair play and substantial justice, inquiry considers whether litigating in the forum would severely disadvantage the defendant and whether the forum state has a legitimate interest in adjudicating the dispute, such as providing redress to its residents or having an interest in the outcome.
cards.mnemonic: MC + FP&SJ: Minimum Contacts, Fair Play & Substantial Justice.
cards.clozeLite: Due process requires {{c1::minimum contacts}} so that jurisdiction does not offend {{c2::traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice}}, focusing on {{c3::purposeful availment}} and {{c4::foreseeability}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 005. Minimum Contacts
cards.backPlain: 1. Purposeful availment: The defendant must purposefully avail herself of the forum state's laws, i.e., reach out in a non-accidental manner. Examples include using the state’s roads, doing business in the state, or otherwise deliberately engaging with the forum. 2. Foreseeability: The defendant must know or reasonably anticipate that she could be held accountable for her activities in the forum state.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the two core requirements for establishing minimum contacts for personal jurisdiction?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Purposeful availment}}: The defendant must {{c2::purposefully avail herself of the forum state's laws}}, i.e., reach out in a {{c3::non-accidental manner}}. Examples include {{c4::using the state’s roads, doing business in the state, or otherwise deliberately engaging with the forum}}. 2. {{c5::Foreseeability}}: The defendant must {{c6::know or reasonably anticipate that she could be held accountable for her activities in the forum state}}.
cards.easyContent: Minimum contacts require that the defendant purposefully avails herself of the forum state and can reasonably foresee being held accountable there.
cards.mediumContent: To establish minimum contacts, (1) the defendant must purposefully avail herself of the forum state’s laws by deliberately engaging with the state (e.g., using roads or doing business there), and (2) it must be foreseeable that she could be held accountable in that forum for those activities.
cards.hardContent: Minimum contacts require: 1. Purposeful availment: The defendant must purposefully avail herself of the forum state's laws by reaching out in a non-accidental manner, such as using the state’s roads, doing business in the state, or otherwise deliberately engaging with the forum. 2. Foreseeability: The defendant must know or reasonably anticipate that she could be held accountable in the forum state for her activities there.
cards.mnemonic: Minimum Contacts = PF: Purposeful availment + Foreseeability.
cards.clozeLite: Minimum contacts require {{c1::purposeful availment}} of the forum and {{c2::foreseeability}} of being held accountable there.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Circumstances that may give rise to minimum contacts
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 006. Circumstances that may give rise to minimum contacts
cards.front: Circumstances that may give rise to minimum contacts
cards.backPlain: 1. Website: Interactive sites are more likely to have the requisite minimum contacts; passive sites are less likely. 1.1. Interactive: Two-way communication between user and operator (e.g., information exchanged for the purpose of soliciting business; purchases allowed). 1.2. Passive: Site makes information available to interested viewers, but no business is transacted. 2. Putting goods into the stream of commerce: Manufacturers may be held liable if they could reasonably expect consumers to purchase their products in the forum state. Mere awareness that component parts may reach the forum as part of another product is insufficient. 3. Targeting the forum state: The Supreme Court has increasingly equated minimum contacts with targeting of the forum state. This requires some deliberate activity within, and cultivation of, the state.
cards.frontPrompt: What types of circumstances commonly give rise to minimum contacts, including website activity, stream of commerce, and targeting the forum state?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Website}}: {{c2::Interactive sites}} are more likely to have the requisite {{c3::minimum contacts}}; {{c4::passive sites}} are less likely. 1.1. {{c5::Interactive}}: {{c6::Two-way communication between user and operator}} (e.g., information exchanged for the purpose of {{c7::soliciting business}}; {{c8::purchases allowed}}). 1.2. {{c9::Passive}}: Site makes information available to interested viewers, but {{c10::no business is transacted}}. 2. {{c11::Putting goods into the stream of commerce}}: Manufacturers may be held liable if they could {{c12::reasonably expect consumers to purchase their products in the forum state}}. {{c13::Mere awareness that component parts may reach the forum as part of another product is insufficient}}. 3. {{c14::Targeting the forum state}}: The Supreme Court has increasingly equated {{c15::minimum contacts}} with {{c16::targeting of the forum state}}. This requires some {{c17::deliberate activity within, and cultivation of, the state}}.
cards.easyContent: Minimum contacts can arise from interactive website activity, putting goods into the forum’s stream of commerce with expectation of sales there, and deliberately targeting or cultivating the forum state.
cards.mediumContent: Circumstances supporting minimum contacts include: (1) interactive websites that engage in two-way communication and solicit or transact business, as opposed to merely passive informational sites; (2) placing goods into the stream of commerce with a reasonable expectation that consumers in the forum state will purchase them (more than mere awareness that components might end up there); and (3) deliberately targeting and cultivating the forum state so that activity is directed at that specific forum.
cards.hardContent: Circumstances that may give rise to minimum contacts include: 1. Website activity: Interactive sites, which allow two-way communication and may exchange information to solicit business or allow purchases, are more likely to create minimum contacts, whereas passive sites that merely provide information and transact no business are less likely. 2. Stream of commerce: Manufacturers who put goods into the stream of commerce may be subject to jurisdiction if they could reasonably expect consumers in the forum state to purchase their products; mere awareness that component parts may reach the forum as part of another product is insufficient. 3. Targeting the forum state: Minimum contacts are increasingly tied to whether the defendant deliberately targets the forum state, engaging in deliberate activity within and cultivation of the forum.
cards.mnemonic: WST: Websites, Stream, Targeting create minimum contacts.
cards.clozeLite: Minimum contacts often arise from {{c1::interactive websites}}, {{c2::stream of commerce}} with expected forum sales, and {{c3::deliberately targeting the forum state}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 007. PJ Fairness Factors
cards.backPlain: Even if minimum contacts are satisfied, due process also requires that the exercise of personal jurisdiction be fair and not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice. Courts assess fairness under three main factors: 1. Relatedness of contacts and claim: Whether the plaintiff’s claim arises from or is related to the defendant’s contacts with the forum, which frames the inquiry into specific vs. general jurisdiction. 2. Convenience: Whether litigating in the forum would severely disadvantage the defendant, such that proceeding there would be fundamentally unfair. 3. State’s interest: Whether the forum state has a legitimate interest in providing a forum and expending its resources on the dispute. All three factors are weighed together to determine whether asserting personal jurisdiction comports with due process.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the overall fairness requirement for personal jurisdiction and what are the three main fairness factors courts consider?
cards.cloze: Even if {{c1::minimum contacts}} are satisfied, due process also requires that the exercise of {{c2::personal jurisdiction}} be {{c3::fair}} and not offend {{c4::traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice}}. Courts assess fairness under three main factors: {{c5::(1) relatedness of contacts and claim, (2) convenience, and (3) the forum state's interest}}.
cards.easyContent: Even if minimum contacts exist, due process also requires that exercising personal jurisdiction be fair, judged by three factors: relatedness of contacts and claim, the defendant’s convenience, and the forum state’s interest.
cards.mediumContent: Fairness in personal jurisdiction requires that asserting jurisdiction not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice. Courts balance three factors: (1) how the claim’s relatedness to the defendant’s forum contacts frames specific vs. general jurisdiction; (2) whether litigating in the forum would severely disadvantage the defendant; and (3) the forum state’s interest in providing a forum for the dispute.
cards.hardContent: Due process independently requires that, beyond minimum contacts, the exercise of personal jurisdiction be fair and not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice. Courts conduct a fairness analysis based on three principal factors: (1) relatedness of contacts and claim, which determines whether specific or general jurisdiction is appropriate; (2) the convenience of the forum, focusing on whether litigating there would so severely disadvantage the defendant that it would be fundamentally unfair; and (3) the forum state’s interest in adjudicating the dispute and allocating its limited judicial resources. These factors are weighed together to decide whether exercising personal jurisdiction comports with due process.
cards.mnemonic: PJ fairness = RCS: Relatedness, Convenience, State’s interest.
cards.atomizationNotes: Atomized into: (1) overall PJ fairness standard, (2) relatedness and specific vs. general jurisdiction, (3) convenience factor, and (4) state’s interest factor.
cards.clozeLite: PJ fairness requires not offending {{c1::traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice}} and weighing {{c2::relatedness}}, {{c3::defendant’s convenience}}, and {{c4::forum state’s interest}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 008. PJ Notice Requirements
cards.backPlain: Due process requires that the defendant must be sufficiently notified of a pending lawsuit. Requirement: Notice must be reasonably calculated, under the circumstances, to apprise interested parties of the pendency of the action and afford them an opportunity to be heard. Methods: 1. Traditional methods of notice satisfy due process, such as personal delivery, registered mail, or delivery to an appointed agent. 2. The plaintiff need not deliver notice personally; it can be given by a court-appointed agent or an agent hired by the plaintiff. 3. If the plaintiff knows that notice was not received by the defendant (e.g., mail returned undelivered), the plaintiff cannot proceed if practical alternatives to giving notice exist.
cards.frontPrompt: What does due process require for notice in personal jurisdiction, and what methods and follow-up obligations apply?
cards.cloze: Due process requires that the {{c1::defendant}} must be sufficiently {{c2::notified of a pending lawsuit}}. Requirement: Notice must be {{c3::reasonably calculated, under the circumstances, to apprise interested parties of the pendency of the action and afford them an opportunity to be heard}}. Methods: 1. {{c4::Traditional methods of notice}} satisfy due process, such as {{c5::personal delivery, registered mail, or delivery to an appointed agent}}. 2. The {{c6::plaintiff need not deliver notice personally}}; it can be given by a {{c7::court-appointed agent}} or an {{c8::agent hired by the plaintiff}}. 3. If the plaintiff {{c9::knows that notice was not received by the defendant}} (e.g., mail returned undelivered), the plaintiff {{c10::cannot proceed if practical alternatives to giving notice exist}}.
cards.easyContent: Due process requires notice that is reasonably calculated to inform the defendant of the lawsuit and give an opportunity to be heard, usually satisfied by traditional service methods.
cards.mediumContent: Notice satisfies due process when it is reasonably calculated, under the circumstances, to inform interested parties of the action and allow them to be heard. Traditional methods—personal delivery, registered mail, or service on an appointed agent—generally suffice, and the plaintiff can use agents to serve. However, if the plaintiff learns that notice failed, she must use practical alternative methods before proceeding.
cards.hardContent: Under due process, the defendant must receive notice of a pending lawsuit that is reasonably calculated, in light of the circumstances, to apprise interested parties of the action and provide an opportunity to be heard. Traditional methods of service—such as personal delivery, registered mail, or delivery to an appointed agent—generally meet this standard, and service may be carried out by a court-appointed agent or an agent hired by the plaintiff. If the plaintiff becomes aware that the defendant did not receive notice, the plaintiff may not proceed if there are practical alternative means to give notice.
cards.mnemonic: RCO: Reasonably Calculated, inform of Case, Opportunity to be heard.
cards.clozeLite: Due process requires {{c1::notice reasonably calculated under the circumstances}} to {{c2::inform parties}} and {{c3::allow an opportunity to be heard}}; {{c4::traditional service methods}} usually suffice.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 009. PJ Personal Service
cards.backPlain: If the defendant is personally served in the forum state, they are likely subject to personal jurisdiction within that forum. Three recognized exceptions: 1. Fraud: A defendant who is served after being lured into the forum under false pretenses. 2. Force: A defendant who is served after being brought involuntarily into the forum by force. 3. Witness: A defendant who is served while responding to a court subpoena. Note: Personal jurisdiction can be established through personal service even if the defendant's presence is transient and unrelated to the suit, so long as no exception applies.
cards.frontPrompt: How does in-forum personal service establish personal jurisdiction, and what are the main exceptions to this rule?
cards.cloze: If the defendant is {{c1::personally served in the forum state}}, they are likely subject to {{c2::personal jurisdiction}} within that forum. Three recognized exceptions: 1. {{c3::Fraud}}: A defendant who is served after being {{c4::lured into the forum under false pretenses}}. 2. {{c5::Force}}: A defendant who is served after being {{c6::brought involuntarily into the forum by force}}. 3. {{c7::Witness}}: A defendant who is served while {{c8::responding to a court subpoena}}. Note: Personal jurisdiction can be established through {{c9::personal service}} even if the defendant's presence is {{c10::transient and unrelated to the suit}}, so long as {{c11::no exception applies}}.
cards.easyContent: Personal jurisdiction is generally proper when the defendant is personally served in the forum state, unless service was obtained by fraud, force, or while the defendant was in the state solely as a witness.
cards.mediumContent: In-state personal service usually suffices to establish personal jurisdiction, even if the defendant’s presence is brief and unrelated to the claim. However, jurisdiction based on such service is improper if service was secured by fraud (luring the defendant into the forum), by force (bringing the defendant involuntarily), or while the defendant was present only to comply with a court subpoena.
cards.hardContent: A court may typically exercise personal jurisdiction when the defendant is personally served with process while physically present in the forum state, even if that presence is transient and unrelated to the underlying dispute. There are three main exceptions: (1) Fraud—service is invalid if the defendant was lured into the forum under false pretenses; (2) Force—service is invalid if the defendant was brought into the forum involuntarily by force; and (3) Witness—service is improper when the defendant is served while present in the forum solely to respond to a court subpoena. If any of these exceptions applies, personal jurisdiction may not be asserted based solely on in-forum personal service.
cards.mnemonic: FFW: Fraud, Force, Witness-only defeat transient PJ.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::In-state personal service}} usually establishes {{c2::personal jurisdiction}} even if presence is brief, except when service is {{c3::fraudulent}}, {{c4::by force}}, or on a {{c5::subpoenaed witness only}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 010. PJ Express or Implied Consent
cards.backPlain: 1. A defendant can establish personal jurisdiction by express or implied consent. 1.1. The most common form of consent is a forum-selection clause. 1.2. Courts will enforce forum-selection clauses unless the selected forum is remote and alien to the parties or the transaction. 1.3. Ensure that the defendant is a party to the contract containing the clause and that the dispute falls within the scope of the clause. 2. A defendant can also consent to personal jurisdiction by waiving the objection. 2.1. The defendant must raise the personal-jurisdiction objection in its first appearance (answer or Rule 12 motion). 2.2. The defendant must litigate the objection promptly or it may be deemed waived.
cards.frontPrompt: How can a defendant expressly or impliedly consent to personal jurisdiction, and what are the enforcement limits on forum-selection clauses?
cards.cloze: 1. A {{c1::defendant}} can establish {{c2::personal jurisdiction}} by {{c3::express or implied consent}}. 1.1. The most common form of consent is a {{c4::forum-selection clause}}. 1.2. Courts will enforce forum-selection clauses unless the selected forum is {{c5::remote and alien to the parties or the transaction}}. 1.3. Ensure that the defendant is a {{c6::party to the contract}} containing the clause and that the dispute {{c7::falls within the scope of the clause}}. 2. A defendant can also consent to personal jurisdiction by {{c8::waiving the objection}}. 2.1. The defendant must raise the personal-jurisdiction objection in its {{c9::first appearance (answer or Rule 12 motion)}}. 2.2. The defendant must {{c10::litigate the objection promptly}} or it may be deemed {{c11::waived}}.
cards.easyContent: Personal jurisdiction can be based on a defendant’s express or implied consent, most commonly through an enforceable forum-selection clause or by waiving a personal-jurisdiction objection. Waiver occurs if the defendant fails to timely raise and litigate the objection in its first appearance.
cards.mediumContent: Personal jurisdiction can rest on a defendant’s consent. Express consent commonly appears in a forum-selection clause, which courts enforce unless the chosen forum is remote and alien to the parties or transaction, and only if the defendant is a party to the contract and the dispute falls within the clause’s scope. A defendant also impliedly consents by waiving any personal-jurisdiction objection by not raising it in the first appearance or not litigating it promptly.
cards.hardContent: Personal jurisdiction may be established by a defendant’s express or implied consent. The most common form is a forum-selection clause. Courts generally enforce forum-selection clauses unless the designated forum is remote and alien to the parties or the transaction. The defendant must be a party to the contract and the dispute must fall within the scope of the clause. Separately, a defendant can consent by waiver: the defendant must raise any personal-jurisdiction objection in its first appearance (answer or Rule 12 motion) and litigate it promptly; otherwise, the objection is deemed waived and personal jurisdiction is treated as consented to.
cards.mnemonic: Contract or Conduct: contract clause or conduct waives PJ.
cards.clozeLite: PJ can be based on {{c1::express consent in a forum-selection clause}} or {{c2::implied consent by waiver}} if {{c3::not raised in the first appearance}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 011. Subject Matter Jurisdiction
cards.backPlain: 1. Federal courts must have authority over the claim in question, which is subject-matter jurisdiction (SMJ), as opposed to personal jurisdiction, which concerns authority over the parties or property. 1.1. SMJ refers to the court’s ability to exercise that authority over the type of case. 2. The Constitution provides limits on the types of cases that federal courts can hear. 3. SMJ cannot be waived. 4. Types of federal subject-matter jurisdiction: 4.1. Diversity jurisdiction. 4.2. Federal-question jurisdiction. 4.3. Supplemental jurisdiction. 4.4. Removal jurisdiction. 5. By contrast, state courts are presumed to have subject-matter jurisdiction over all types of cases, except where federal courts have exclusive SMJ. 5.1. In a narrow set of cases, federal courts have exclusive SMJ (e.g., patent infringement).
cards.frontPrompt: What is subject-matter jurisdiction in federal courts, what are its main types, and can it be waived?

SMJ {{c7::cannot be waived}}. 4. By contrast, {{c12::state courts}} are presumed to have subject-matter jurisdiction over all types of cases, except where federal courts have {{c13::exclusive}} SMJ. 5.1. In a narrow set of cases, federal courts have exclusive SMJ (e.g., {{c14::patent infringement}}).
cards.easyContent: Subject-matter jurisdiction is a court’s power over the type of case or claim, as opposed to power over the parties. Federal SMJ is limited by the Constitution, cannot be waived, and includes diversity, federal-question, supplemental, and removal jurisdiction, while state courts are presumed to have general SMJ except where federal jurisdiction is exclusive.
cards.mediumContent: Subject-matter jurisdiction (SMJ) is the federal court’s authority over the claim or type of case, distinct from personal jurisdiction over parties or property. The Constitution limits the categories of cases federal courts can hear, and SMJ cannot be waived. Federal SMJ arises through diversity, federal-question, supplemental, and removal jurisdiction. State courts are presumed to have broad SMJ, subject to specific areas of exclusive federal jurisdiction, such as patent infringement.
cards.hardContent: Subject-matter jurisdiction (SMJ) is the authority of a federal court over the claim in question—its power over the type or category of case—distinct from personal jurisdiction, which involves power over the parties or property. The Constitution sets outer limits on the types of cases federal courts may hear. SMJ cannot be waived and may be raised at any time. The principal types of federal SMJ are diversity jurisdiction, federal-question jurisdiction, supplemental jurisdiction, and removal jurisdiction. In contrast, state courts are presumed to have general SMJ over all types of cases, except where Congress has given federal courts exclusive SMJ, such as in patent infringement and other specially designated matters.
cards.mnemonic: DFSR: Diversity, Federal question, Supplemental, Removal.
cards.clozeLite: Federal {{c1::subject-matter jurisdiction}} is power over the {{c2::type of case}}, is {{c3::limited by the Constitution}}, and {{c4::cannot be waived}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 012. Diversity Jurisdiction
cards.backPlain: 1. Federal courts have subject-matter jurisdiction over controversies between citizens of different states, even where claims do not involve federal law. 2. Diversity jurisdiction is conferred by the Constitution and by statute (28 U.S.C. § 1332). 3. Requirements for diversity jurisdiction: 3.1. Complete diversity of citizenship. 3.1.1. Every plaintiff must be of diverse citizenship from every defendant (i.e., there is no diversity if any plaintiff is a citizen of the same state as any defendant). 3.1.2. Complete diversity does not require that all parties be citizens of different states; it only requires that no plaintiff and no defendant share the same state citizenship (e.g., two plaintiffs can be from Utah, as long as no defendant is from Utah). 3.1.3. Diversity is examined at the time of filing; diversity need not exist when the claim arose. 3.1.4. Diversity can exist between a citizen of a U.S. state and a foreign country (often referred to as alienage jurisdiction). 3.2. Amount in controversy must exceed $75,000. 3.2.1. The plaintiff must make a good-faith allegation that her claim exceeds $75,000. 4. Exceptions to diversity jurisdiction: 4.1. Federal courts will not hear actions involving divorce, alimony, child custody, or probate, even if diversity requirements are otherwise satisfied.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for federal diversity jurisdiction, and what major categories of cases are excluded even if those requirements are met?
cards.cloze: 1. Federal courts have {{c1::subject-matter jurisdiction}} over controversies between {{c2::citizens of different states}}, even where claims do not involve {{c3::federal law}}. 2. Diversity jurisdiction is conferred by the {{c4::Constitution}} and by statute ({{c5::28 U.S.C. § 1332}}). 3. Requirements for diversity jurisdiction: 3.1. {{c6::Complete diversity of citizenship}}. 3.1.1. Every plaintiff must be of diverse citizenship from every defendant (i.e., there is no diversity if any {{c7::plaintiff}} is a citizen of the same state as any {{c8::defendant}}). 3.1.2. Complete diversity does not require that all parties be citizens of different states; it only requires that no P and no D share the same state citizenship (e.g., two Ps can be from Utah, as long as no D is from Utah). 3.1.3. Diversity is examined at the {{c9::time of filing}}; diversity need not exist when the claim arose. 3.1.4. Diversity can exist between a citizen of a U.S. state and a {{c10::foreign country}} (often referred to as {{c11::alienage jurisdiction}}). 3.2. {{c12::Amount in controversy}} must {{c13::exceed $75,000}}. 3.2.1. The plaintiff must make a {{c14::good-faith allegation}} that her claim exceeds $75,000. 4. Exceptions to diversity jurisdiction: 4.1. Federal courts will not hear actions involving {{c15::divorce}}, {{c16::alimony}}, {{c17::child custody}}, or {{c18::probate}}, even if diversity requirements are otherwise satisfied.
cards.easyContent: Diversity jurisdiction allows federal courts to hear civil cases between citizens of different states (or between a state citizen and a foreign citizen) when complete diversity exists and the amount in controversy exceeds $75,000, but it does not extend to core domestic relations or probate matters.
cards.mediumContent: Federal diversity jurisdiction covers controversies between citizens of different states, and between a U.S. citizen and a foreign citizen, even if no federal law is involved. It is authorized by the Constitution and 28 U.S.C. § 1332. It requires (1) complete diversity—no plaintiff shares state citizenship with any defendant, determined at the time of filing; and (2) an amount in controversy exceeding $75,000, based on the plaintiff’s good-faith allegation. Federal courts still lack diversity jurisdiction over divorce, alimony, child custody, and probate actions.
cards.hardContent: Diversity jurisdiction is a form of federal subject-matter jurisdiction over civil controversies between citizens of different states, and between a state citizen and a foreign citizen, even where no federal question is presented. It is authorized by the Constitution and implemented by 28 U.S.C. § 1332. To qualify, the case must satisfy: (1) complete diversity—every plaintiff is of diverse citizenship from every defendant, meaning no P shares a state of citizenship with any D, with citizenship measured at the time of filing; and (2) an amount in controversy exceeding $75,000, based on the plaintiff’s good-faith allegation. This jurisdictional grant is subject to important exceptions: federal courts do not exercise diversity jurisdiction over core domestic relations matters (divorce, alimony, child custody) or probate proceedings, even if complete diversity and the amount-in-controversy requirement are met.
cards.mnemonic: D+A>75, no DAPC-P: no Divorce, Alimony, child custody, Probate.
cards.clozeLite: Diversity jurisdiction requires {{c1::complete diversity}} and {{c2::amount in controversy > $75,000}}, but excludes {{c3::divorce, alimony, child custody}} and {{c4::probate}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 013. Citizenship for Diversity
cards.backPlain: 1. For diversity jurisdiction, every plaintiff must be of diverse citizenship from every defendant. 2. Determining citizenship for diversity purposes differs for individuals and businesses. 3. Natural persons: 3.1. A natural person is a citizen of the state where they are domiciled at the time the suit is filed. 3.2. Domicile is the state where the person was last both: 3.2.1. Present; and 3.2.2. Intending to remain indefinitely. 3.3. A person always has one—and never more than one—domicile. You keep your domicile until you acquire a new one. 3.4. Factors for determining a person’s domicile include simultaneous: 3.4.1. Physical factor: actual presence in the state; and 3.4.2. Mental factor: intent to make the state a permanent home (e.g., where the person votes, works, is licensed, etc.). 4. Businesses. 4.1. Corporations: 4.1.1. A corporation is a citizen of every state in which it is incorporated and of the state where it maintains its principal place of business (PPB). 4.1.2. A corporation can have multiple states of citizenship. 4.1.3. To determine the PPB, look to where the corporation’s high-level decisions are made—the “nerve center,” usually the corporate headquarters. 4.2. Unincorporated businesses (e.g., LLCs, LLPs): 4.2.1. An unincorporated association is a citizen of all states in which any partner or member is a citizen.
cards.frontPrompt: How is citizenship determined for natural persons, corporations, and unincorporated business entities for purposes of diversity jurisdiction?

Determining citizenship for diversity purposes differs for {{c3::individuals}} and {{c4::businesses}}. 3. Natural persons: 3.1. A person always has {{c8::one—and never more than one—domicile}}. You keep your domicile until you acquire a new one. 3.4. Factors for determining a person’s domicile include simultaneous: 3.4.1. {{c9::Physical}} factor: actual presence in the state; and 3.4.2. {{c10::Mental}} factor: intent to make the state a permanent home (e.g., where the person votes, works, is licensed, etc.). 4. Businesses. 4.1. Corporations: 4.1.1. A corporation is a citizen of every state in which it is {{c11::incorporated}} and of the state where it maintains its {{c12::principal place of business (PPB)}}. 4.1.2. A corporation can have {{c13::multiple states of citizenship}}. 4.1.3. To determine the PPB, look to where the corporation’s high-level decisions are made—the {{c14::“nerve center”}}, usually the corporate headquarters. 4.2. Unincorporated businesses (e.g., LLCs, LLPs): 4.2.1. An unincorporated association is a citizen of {{c15::all states in which any partner or member is a citizen}}.
cards.easyContent: For diversity jurisdiction, each plaintiff must be a citizen of a different state than each defendant. Individuals are citizens of their state of domicile, corporations are citizens of every state of incorporation plus their principal place of business, and unincorporated entities are citizens of every state where any member or partner is a citizen.
cards.mediumContent: Diversity jurisdiction requires that every plaintiff be of diverse citizenship from every defendant. A natural person’s citizenship is the state of domicile at the time of filing, defined by physical presence plus intent to remain indefinitely, and a person has only one domicile until they acquire a new one. A corporation is a citizen of every state in which it is incorporated and of the state of its principal place of business, determined by the “nerve center” where high-level decisions are made. Unincorporated entities such as LLCs and LLPs are citizens of every state in which any partner or member is a citizen.
cards.hardContent: For diversity jurisdiction, complete diversity requires that each plaintiff be a citizen of a different state than each defendant. Citizenship is determined differently for individuals and business entities. A natural person is a citizen of the state of domicile at the time of filing, with domicile defined by both physical presence and intent to remain indefinitely; a person can have only one domicile, which continues until a new one is established, as shown by factors such as where the person lives, votes, works, and is licensed. A corporation is a citizen of every state where it is incorporated and of its principal place of business, identified by the “nerve center” where corporate officers direct, control, and coordinate the company, usually the headquarters; thus, a corporation can have multiple state citizenships. Unincorporated entities (LLCs, LLPs, partnerships) take on the citizenship of all their members or partners and therefore may have many states of citizenship.
cards.mnemonic: People: Domicile; Corps: I+N; LLCs: ALL members.
cards.clozeLite: For diversity, {{c1::individuals}} are citizens of their {{c2::domicile}}; {{c3::corporations}} of each {{c4::state of incorporation}} plus {{c5::principal place of business}}; {{c6::LLCs/LLPs}} of all members’ states.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 014. Amount in Controversy
cards.backPlain: 1. The plaintiff’s complaint must make a good-faith allegation that the amount of damages or injury in controversy exceeds $75,000, excluding interest and costs. 2. Lenient standard for dismissal: 2.1. To dismiss for insufficient amount in controversy, there must be no legal possibility that recovery will exceed $75,000. 2.2. The amount actually awarded is irrelevant. 3. Equitable relief claims: 3.1. The court looks at the value of the harm caused. 3.2. The court may view the amount either from the plaintiff’s or the defendant’s perspective: 3.2.1. Does the act requiring injunctive relief harm the plaintiff by more than $75,000? 3.2.2. Or would it cost the defendant more than $75,000 to comply with the injunction sought? 4. Aggregating claims to meet $75,000: 4.1. One plaintiff can aggregate all of her claims against a single defendant. 5. Multiple plaintiffs or multiple defendants: 5.1. Aggregation is allowed only if either: 5.1.1. One plaintiff has joint liability claims against multiple defendants—use the total value of the jointly liable claim; and/or 5.1.2. Multiple plaintiffs seek to enforce a single title or right in which they have a common, undivided interest (rare), such as several plaintiffs jointly owning real estate and suing the defendant to quiet title.
cards.frontPrompt: What is required to satisfy the federal amount-in-controversy requirement, including how courts treat equitable relief and aggregation of claims?
cards.cloze: 1. The plaintiff’s complaint must make a {{c1::good-faith allegation}} that the amount of damages or injury in controversy {{c2::exceeds $75,000}}, excluding {{c3::interest and costs}}. 2. Lenient standard for dismissal: 2.1. To dismiss for insufficient amount in controversy, there must be {{c4::no legal possibility}} that recovery will exceed $75,000. 2.2. The amount actually awarded is {{c5::irrelevant}}. 3. Equitable relief claims: 3.1. The court looks at the {{c6::value of the harm}} caused. 3.2. The court may view the amount either from the {{c7::plaintiff’s perspective}} or the {{c8::defendant’s perspective}}: 3.2.1. Does the act requiring injunctive relief harm the plaintiff by more than $75,000? 3.2.2. Or would it cost the defendant more than $75,000 to comply with the injunction sought? 4. Aggregating claims to meet $75,000: 4.1. One plaintiff can {{c9::aggregate all of her claims}} against a single defendant. 5. Multiple plaintiffs or multiple defendants: 5.1. Aggregation is allowed only if either: 5.1.1. One plaintiff has {{c10::joint liability claims}} against multiple defendants—use the total value of the jointly liable claim; and/or 5.1.2. Multiple plaintiffs seek to enforce a {{c11::single title or right}} in which they have a {{c12::common, undivided interest}} (rare), such as several plaintiffs jointly owning real estate and suing the defendant to quiet title.
cards.easyContent: The amount in controversy for diversity jurisdiction is met if the plaintiff in good faith alleges more than $75,000, excluding interest and costs, and dismissal is proper only if it is legally impossible to recover that amount. Courts measure equitable relief by the value of the harm or the cost of compliance and allow limited aggregation of claims to reach $75,000.
cards.mediumContent: To meet the amount-in-controversy requirement for diversity jurisdiction, the plaintiff must allege in good faith that the amount in controversy exceeds $75,000, excluding interest and costs. This is a lenient standard: dismissal is proper only if there is no legal possibility that the recovery could exceed $75,000, and the actual recovery amount does not matter. For equitable relief, courts look to the value of the harm or the cost of compliance from either the plaintiff’s or defendant’s perspective. A single plaintiff may aggregate all claims against one defendant. With multiple parties, aggregation is allowed only for joint liability claims against multiple defendants or when multiple plaintiffs share a single, common, undivided interest, such as joint ownership of property.
cards.hardContent: The amount-in-controversy requirement for diversity jurisdiction is satisfied when the plaintiff’s complaint, on its face, includes a good-faith allegation that the damages or injury in controversy exceed $75,000, excluding interest and costs. The standard is generous: a federal court may dismiss only if it appears to a legal certainty that the claim is really for less than the jurisdictional amount; the amount ultimately awarded is irrelevant. For equitable claims, the court assesses the value of the object of the litigation by looking either to the magnitude of the harm to the plaintiff or to the cost to the defendant of complying with the requested injunction. A single plaintiff may aggregate all of her separate claims against a single defendant to reach the jurisdictional minimum. Aggregation among multiple plaintiffs or defendants is more limited: it is permitted where one plaintiff asserts joint liability claims against multiple defendants (using the total value of the joint claim) or where multiple plaintiffs seek to enforce a single title or right in which they have a common, undivided interest, such as co-owners of real property suing to quiet title.
cards.mnemonic: G>75: Good faith, >$75k, Group your own claims, Gauge injunction’s value.
cards.clozeLite: Amount in controversy needs a {{c1::good-faith allegation}} of {{c2::> $75,000 excluding interest and costs}}; courts may {{c3::value injunctions by harm or compliance cost}} and {{c4::let one plaintiff aggregate all claims vs one defendant}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 015. Federal Question Jurisdiction
cards.backPlain: Federal courts have subject-matter jurisdiction over properly pleaded claims arising under federal law (28 U.S.C. § 1331). No diversity or amount-in-controversy requirements apply. 1. Requirements 1.1. The claim must show a right or interest founded substantially on federal law. 1.2. The federal question must appear on the face of the well-pleaded complaint. 1.3. Federal question jurisdiction cannot be based on extraneous allegations or potential defenses. 2. Analysis 2.1. Ask whether the plaintiff is enforcing a right that arises under federal law (e.g., federal statute, regulation, or the Constitution). If not, no federal question jurisdiction exists. 2.2. Beware of fact patterns where the complaint mentions a federal law or issue, but the plaintiff is not actually enforcing a federal right. 3. Exclusive federal jurisdiction 3.1. Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over certain types of claims, which must be heard in federal court. 3.2. Otherwise, federal claims can generally be heard in state court, which are courts of general jurisdiction. 4. Common areas of exclusive federal jurisdiction 4.1. Bankruptcy. 4.2. Patent, copyright, and trademark. 4.3. Federal antitrust claims. 4.4. Postal matters.
cards.frontPrompt: When does a federal court have federal question jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1331, and what are common areas of exclusive federal jurisdiction?

cards.easyContent: Federal question jurisdiction exists when a properly pleaded claim arises under federal law under 28 U.S.C. § 1331, without needing diversity or an amount in controversy. The federal question must appear on the face of the well-pleaded complaint.
cards.mediumContent: Under 28 U.S.C. § 1331, a federal court has federal question jurisdiction when the plaintiff’s well-pleaded complaint shows a right or interest founded substantially on federal law and the federal question appears on the face of the complaint, not in extraneous allegations or defenses. Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over certain matters such as bankruptcy, patents/copyrights/trademarks, federal antitrust, and postal matters; otherwise, federal claims can usually be heard in state court.
cards.hardContent: Federal question jurisdiction (28 U.S.C. § 1331) gives federal courts subject-matter jurisdiction over properly pleaded claims arising under federal law, without any diversity or amount-in-controversy requirements. The claim must show a right or interest founded substantially on federal law, and the federal question must appear on the face of the well-pleaded complaint; jurisdiction cannot be based on extraneous allegations or potential defenses. In analyzing jurisdiction, ask whether the plaintiff is enforcing a federal right (e.g., under a federal statute, regulation, or the Constitution); if not, no federal question jurisdiction exists, even if the complaint references federal issues. Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over certain areas—most commonly bankruptcy, patent/copyright/trademark, federal antitrust claims, and postal matters—while most other federal claims may be heard in either federal or state courts of general jurisdiction.
cards.mnemonic: FACE Fed: Federal claim on FACE of complaint.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::28 U.S.C. § 1331}}, a federal court has {{c2::federal question jurisdiction}} when the {{c3::well-pleaded complaint}} shows a right founded on {{c4::federal law}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 016. Supplemental Jurisdiction
cards.backPlain: Supplemental jurisdiction allows a federal court to hear additional claims (e.g., counterclaims and cross-claims) that do not, on their own, meet diversity or federal question jurisdiction requirements (28 U.S.C. § 1367). It cannot be used to get a case into federal court in the first place. 1. Requirements 1.1. Common nucleus of operative fact (CNOF). 1.2. Each additional claim must share a CNOF with an existing claim that independently invokes federal question or diversity jurisdiction. 1.3. Same transaction or occurrence: supplemental claims share a CNOF if they arise from the same transaction or occurrence as the underlying claim. 2. Discretionary refusal The court may refuse to hear a supplemental claim if: 2.1. The original jurisdiction claims are dismissed early in the proceeding. 2.2. The supplemental claim raises a novel or complex state law issue. 2.3. The supplemental claim substantially predominates over the original jurisdiction claims. 3. Limitation in diversity cases 3.1. In diversity cases, the plaintiff cannot use supplemental jurisdiction to overcome a lack of complete diversity (this limitation does not apply to defendants). 3.2. However, the plaintiff may use supplemental jurisdiction to overcome an insufficient amount in controversy.
cards.frontPrompt: What is supplemental jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1367, what is the common nucleus of operative fact requirement, and what special limitation applies in diversity cases?
cards.cloze: Supplemental jurisdiction allows a federal court to hear {{c1::additional claims}} (e.g., counterclaims and cross-claims) that do not, on their own, meet {{c2::diversity}} or {{c3::federal question jurisdiction}} requirements ({{c4::28 U.S.C. § 1367}}). It {{c5::cannot be used to get a case into federal court}} in the first place. 1. Requirements 1.1. {{c6::Common nucleus of operative fact (CNOF)}}. 1.2. Each additional claim must share a CNOF with an {{c7::existing claim that independently invokes federal question or diversity jurisdiction}}. 1.3. Same transaction or occurrence: supplemental claims share a CNOF if they arise from the {{c8::same transaction or occurrence}} as the underlying claim. 2. Discretionary refusal The court may refuse to hear a supplemental claim if: 2.1. The original jurisdiction claims are {{c9::dismissed early}} in the proceeding. 2.2. The supplemental claim raises a {{c10::novel or complex state law}} issue. 2.3. The supplemental claim {{c11::substantially predominates}} over the original jurisdiction claims. 3. Limitation in diversity cases 3.1. In diversity cases, the {{c12::plaintiff}} cannot use supplemental jurisdiction to overcome a {{c13::lack of complete diversity}} (this limitation does not apply to defendants). 3.2. However, the plaintiff may use supplemental jurisdiction to overcome an {{c14::insufficient amount in controversy}}.
cards.easyContent: Supplemental jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1367 lets a federal court hear additional claims that share a common nucleus of operative fact with a claim that has original federal question or diversity jurisdiction. It cannot be used to create original jurisdiction.
cards.mediumContent: Under 28 U.S.C. § 1367, supplemental jurisdiction permits a federal court to hear additional claims (e.g., counterclaims, cross-claims) that independently lack diversity or federal question jurisdiction, so long as they share a common nucleus of operative fact—typically the same transaction or occurrence—with a claim that independently supports federal jurisdiction. The court may decline supplemental jurisdiction if the original jurisdiction claims are dismissed early, the supplemental claim raises novel or complex state law, or the supplemental issues substantially predominate.
cards.hardContent: Supplemental jurisdiction (28 U.S.C. § 1367) allows a federal court to hear additional claims that, by themselves, do not meet diversity or federal question jurisdiction requirements, but share a common nucleus of operative fact (CNOF) with a claim that independently invokes federal question or diversity jurisdiction—i.e., they arise from the same transaction or occurrence as the underlying claim. Supplemental jurisdiction cannot be used to get a case into federal court initially. The court has discretion to decline supplemental jurisdiction when the original jurisdiction claims are dismissed early, when the supplemental claim raises a novel or complex state law issue, or when the supplemental claim substantially predominates over the original jurisdiction claims. In diversity cases, a plaintiff cannot use supplemental jurisdiction to cure a lack of complete diversity (though this restriction does not apply to defendants), but a plaintiff may use supplemental jurisdiction to cure a failure to meet the amount-in-controversy requirement.
cards.mnemonic: CNOF: Claims Nest On Facts—same factual core needed.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::28 U.S.C. § 1367}}, supplemental jurisdiction covers claims lacking {{c2::independent federal question or diversity}} if they share a {{c3::common nucleus of operative fact}}. In diversity, {{c4::plaintiffs can’t use it to cure lack of complete diversity}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 017. Removal Jurisdiction
cards.backPlain: A defendant can remove a case originally filed in state court to federal court if the federal court would have had subject-matter jurisdiction (i.e., diversity or federal question). 1. Removal rules 1.1. The case must be one that could have been filed in federal court. 1.2. Only defendants can remove, and all defendants must agree to removal. 1.3. A case can be removed only to the federal district court embracing the state court in which the case was originally filed. 1.4. A defendant who files a permissive counterclaim in state court waives the right to remove. 2. Timing 2.1. The defendant must remove within 30 days of service of the first removable document (usually service of process). 3. Procedure 3.1. The defendant must file a notice of removal in both state and federal courts. 3.2. The notice must state the grounds for removal and include copies of all documents served in state court, and it must be signed. 3.3. All adverse parties must receive notice of removal. 4. Diversity jurisdiction limitations (forum-defendant rule) 4.1. A defendant cannot remove a diversity case if the plaintiff filed suit in any defendant's home state. 4.2. In other words, no removal if any defendant is a citizen of the forum state. 5. Remand 5.1. If removal is improper, the federal court can remand the case to state court. 5.2. For improper procedure, the plaintiff must move to remand within 30 days. 5.3. For lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, the plaintiff can move to remand at any time.
cards.frontPrompt: When and how may a defendant remove a case from state to federal court, what is the forum-defendant rule, and what are the deadlines for remand?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::defendant}} can remove a case originally filed in state court to federal court if the federal court would have had {{c2::subject-matter jurisdiction}} (i.e., {{c3::diversity}} or {{c4::federal question}}). 1. Removal rules 1.1. The case must be one that {{c5::could have been filed in federal court}}. 1.2. Only {{c6::defendants}} can remove, and {{c7::all defendants must agree}} to removal. 1.3. A case can be removed only to the {{c8::federal district court embracing the state court}} in which the case was originally filed. 1.4. A defendant who files a {{c9::permissive counterclaim}} in state court {{c10::waives the right to remove}}. 2. Timing 2.1. The defendant must remove within {{c11::30 days}} of service of the first removable document (usually service of process). 3. Procedure 3.1. The defendant must file a {{c12::notice of removal}} in both state and federal courts. 3.2. The notice must {{c13::state the grounds for removal}} and include {{c14::copies of all documents served in state court}}, and it must be {{c15::signed}}. 3.3. All {{c16::adverse parties}} must receive notice of removal. 4. Diversity jurisdiction limitations ({{c17::forum-defendant rule}}) 4.1. A defendant cannot remove a diversity case if the plaintiff filed suit in any {{c18::defendant's home state}}. 4.2. In other words, no removal if any defendant is a {{c19::citizen of the forum state}}. 5. Remand 5.1. If removal is improper, the federal court can {{c20::remand}} the case to state court. 5.2. For {{c21::improper procedure}}, the plaintiff must move to remand within {{c22::30 days}}. 5.3. For {{c23::lack of subject-matter jurisdiction}}, the plaintiff can move to remand {{c24::at any time}}.
cards.easyContent: A defendant may remove a case from state to federal court only if the case could have been filed in federal court (diversity or federal question). In diversity cases, removal is barred if any defendant is a citizen of the forum state, and improper removals may be remanded.
cards.mediumContent: Removal allows a defendant—but not a plaintiff—to move a case from state to federal court when the federal court would have had original subject-matter jurisdiction (diversity or federal question). All defendants must consent, removal must be to the federal district embracing the state court, and a defendant who files a permissive counterclaim waives removal. The defendant must remove within 30 days of service of the first removable paper, file a signed notice of removal in state and federal court stating the grounds and attaching all served documents, and give notice to all adverse parties. In diversity cases, the forum-defendant rule bars removal if any defendant is a citizen of the forum state. Improper removals are remanded: procedural defects must be raised within 30 days, but lack of subject-matter jurisdiction can be raised at any time.
cards.hardContent: Removal jurisdiction permits a defendant to remove a case originally filed in state court to federal court if the case could have been filed in federal court—i.e., there is federal question or diversity subject-matter jurisdiction. Only defendants may remove, all defendants must consent, and removal must be to the federal district embracing the state court where the action was filed. A defendant who files a permissive counterclaim in state court waives the right to remove. The defendant must remove within 30 days of service of the first removable document (usually service of process). To remove, the defendant files a signed notice of removal in both state and federal courts, stating the grounds for removal and attaching copies of all documents served in state court, and gives notice to all adverse parties. In diversity cases, the forum-defendant rule bars removal if any defendant is a citizen of the forum state—that is, a diversity case filed in a defendant’s home state cannot be removed. If removal is improper, the federal court can remand the case to state court; the plaintiff must move to remand for procedural defects within 30 days, but may seek remand for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction at any time.
cards.mnemonic: REMOVAL: REmove if federal, but Home D can’t go.
cards.clozeLite: Only a {{c1::defendant}} may {{c2::remove}} a case to federal court if {{c3::original SMJ (diversity or FQ)}} exists; the {{c4::forum-defendant rule}} bars removal when any {{c5::defendant is a citizen of the forum state}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 018. Erie Doctrine
cards.backPlain: In diversity cases, federal courts must apply state substantive law and federal procedural law. Use the following analysis to determine whether a state law is substantive and thus must be applied. 1. Is there a valid federal law on point? 1.1. Determine whether there is a valid federal provision (e.g., the Constitution, a federal statute, or a Federal Rule) that is on point and directly conflicts with state law. 1.2. If yes, the federal law governs (assuming it is valid under the Constitution or the Rules Enabling Act). 2. If no federal law is on point, apply the Erie tests 2.1. Outcome determinative test: Would applying or ignoring the state rule significantly affect the outcome of the case? If yes, the state law is substantive and should be applied. 2.2. Balance of interests test: Does either the federal or state system have a strong interest in applying its rule? If one has a clearly stronger interest, apply that law. 2.3. Forum shopping avoidance test: If the federal court ignores the state law, would it encourage litigants to flock to federal court (or avoid state court)? If yes, the state law is substantive and should be applied. 3. Matters always governed by state substantive law 3.1. Elements of a claim or defense. 3.2. Statutes of limitations. 3.3. Conflict/choice-of-law rules. 3.4. Rules for tolling the statute of limitations.
cards.frontPrompt: In a federal diversity case, how do you apply the Erie doctrine to decide whether to use state or federal law, and what issues are always governed by state law?

Determine whether there is a valid {{c4::federal provision}} (e.g., the Constitution, a federal statute, or a Federal Rule) that is {{c5::on point and directly conflicts}} with state law. 1.2. If yes, the {{c6::federal law governs}} (assuming it is valid under the Constitution or the {{c7::Rules Enabling Act}}). 2. If no federal law is on point, apply the Erie tests 2.1. {{c8::Outcome determinative test}}: Would applying or ignoring the state rule significantly affect the outcome of the case? If yes, the state law is substantive and should be applied. 2.2. {{c9::Balance of interests test}}: Does either the federal or state system have a strong interest in applying its rule? If one has a clearly stronger interest, apply that law. 2.3. {{c10::Forum shopping avoidance test}}: If the federal court ignores the state law, would it encourage litigants to {{c11::flock to federal court or avoid state court}}? If yes, the state law is substantive and should be applied. 3. Matters always governed by state substantive law 3.1. {{c12::Elements of a claim or defense}}. 3.2. {{c13::Statutes of limitations}}. 3.3. {{c14::Conflict/choice-of-law rules}}. 3.4. {{c15::Rules for tolling the statute of limitations}}.
cards.easyContent: Under the Erie doctrine, a federal court sitting in diversity applies state substantive law and federal procedural law. If a valid federal law directly conflicts with state law it controls; otherwise, the court uses outcome determinative, interest-balancing, and forum-shopping tests to decide.
cards.mediumContent: In diversity cases, Erie requires federal courts to apply state substantive law but federal procedural law. First, ask whether a valid federal source (Constitution, statute, or Federal Rule) directly conflicts with the state rule; if so, the federal rule governs if valid. If there is no federal law on point, determine whether the state rule is substantive by considering whether it is outcome determinative, whether federal or state interests are stronger, and whether ignoring the state rule would encourage forum shopping. Elements of claims and defenses, statutes of limitations (and their tolling), and conflict-of-law rules are always treated as state substantive law.
cards.hardContent: The Erie doctrine provides that a federal court in a diversity case must apply state substantive law and federal procedural law. The analysis proceeds in two steps. First, determine whether there is a valid federal provision—such as the Constitution, a federal statute, or a Federal Rule of Civil Procedure—that is on point and directly conflicts with the state law; if so, the federal law governs, assuming it is valid under the Constitution or Rules Enabling Act. If there is no federal law on point, the court must decide whether the state rule is substantive by applying the Erie tests: (1) outcome determinative—would applying or ignoring the state rule significantly affect the outcome of the case; (2) balance of interests—does either the state or federal system have a stronger interest in applying its rule; and (3) forum shopping avoidance—would ignoring the state rule encourage litigants to flock to or avoid federal court. Certain matters are always governed by state substantive law, including the elements of a claim or defense, statutes of limitations and rules for tolling them, and conflict/choice-of-law rules.
cards.mnemonic: Erie SCOPE: State COAs, SOL, and POE/conflicts rules.
cards.clozeLite: Erie: apply {{c1::state substantive law}} and {{c2::federal procedural law}}; always treat {{c3::elements of claims/defenses}}, {{c4::SOL & tolling}}, and {{c5::conflict-of-law rules}} as state substantive.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 019. Venue
cards.backPlain: Venue determines the proper judicial district in which the plaintiff may bring suit in federal court. 1. Determining proper venue For most actions, venue is proper in: 1.1. Any district where any defendant resides, if all defendants reside in the same state in which the district is located. 1.2. Any district in which a substantial part of the claim arose or in which a substantial part of the property that is the subject of the action is situated. 1.3. Fallback: If no district satisfies 1.1 or 1.2, venue is proper in any district in which any defendant is subject to personal jurisdiction with respect to the action. 2. Residency for venue purposes 2.1. People: A natural person resides where they are domiciled. 2.2. Corporations: A corporation resides in any state where it is subject to personal jurisdiction. In a state with more than one district, the corporation resides in any district where its contacts would be sufficient to subject it to personal jurisdiction if that district were a separate state. 2.3. Non-corporate businesses: A non-corporate business entity is a resident of all districts in which it was subject to personal jurisdiction when the action commenced (a broader standard than principal place of business). 2.4. Unincorporated associations: Residency is determined by the location of the association itself, not by the individual members.
cards.frontPrompt: How do you determine proper venue in federal court and how is residency defined for individuals and business entities for venue purposes?

Corporations: A corporation resides in any {{c8::state where it is subject to personal jurisdiction}}. In a state with more than one district, the corporation resides in any district where its {{c9::contacts would be sufficient for personal jurisdiction}} if that district were a separate state. 2.3. Non-corporate businesses: A non-corporate business entity is a resident of {{c10::all districts in which it was subject to personal jurisdiction}} when the action commenced (a broader standard than {{c11::principal place of business}}). 2.4. cards.easyContent: Venue chooses the proper federal judicial district. It is usually where any defendant resides (if all defendants are in the same state) or where a substantial part of the events or property at issue is located, with a fallback to any district where a defendant is subject to personal jurisdiction.
