cards.mediumContent: In federal court, venue is generally proper in any district where any defendant resides, if all defendants reside in the same state, or in any district where a substantial part of the events giving rise to the claim occurred or the property at issue is located. If no such district exists, venue falls back to any district where a defendant is subject to personal jurisdiction. For venue, individuals reside where they are domiciled; corporations in any state where they are subject to personal jurisdiction and, in multi-district states, in any district where their contacts would support personal jurisdiction if it were a separate state; non-corporate entities in every district where they are subject to personal jurisdiction at filing; and unincorporated associations based on the association’s own location, not each member.
cards.hardContent: Venue determines the correct federal judicial district for filing suit. For most actions, venue is proper in (1) any district in which any defendant resides, so long as all defendants reside in the same state in which that district is located; or (2) any district in which a substantial part of the claim arose or a substantial part of the property at issue is located. If neither of those options is available, venue is proper in any district in which any defendant is subject to personal jurisdiction with respect to the action. For venue purposes, a natural person resides where they are domiciled. A corporation resides in any state where it is subject to personal jurisdiction, and in a state with multiple districts, in any district where its contacts would suffice to subject it to personal jurisdiction if the district were a separate state. A non-corporate business entity is a resident of all districts in which it was subject to personal jurisdiction when the action commenced, which is broader than simply its principal place of business. The residency of an unincorporated association is determined by the location of the association itself, not the residences of its individual members.
cards.mnemonic: R-E-P: defendant Resides, site of Events/Property, or PJ fallback.
cards.clozeLite: Federal {{c1::venue}} is proper where any {{c2::defendant resides}} (if all in same state), where a {{c3::substantial part of events or property}} is located, or as a {{c4::personal-jurisdiction fallback}}. For venue, an {{c5::individual resides at domicile}} and a {{c6::corporation in any state/district with PJ}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 020. Venue Transfer
cards.backPlain: Federal law governs transfer of venue in civil cases. A case may be transferred from one federal district to another district in which the case could have been filed, or to a district to which all parties consent. Any party may move to transfer, but if the original venue is proper, the court may refuse. When venue is proper, the court has discretion to transfer based on the interest of justice and the convenience of parties and witnesses, using public and private factors. When venue is improper, the court may transfer in the interest of justice or dismiss. After transfer, special rules govern which court’s choice-of-law rules apply. Valid forum-selection clauses that specify a federal district are ordinarily enforced and usually control the choice among federal districts, subject to compelling public-factor objections.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the basic federal rules governing transfer of venue, including the court’s discretion, choice-of-law consequences, and the effect of forum-selection clauses?
cards.cloze: Federal law governs {{c1::transfer of venue}} in civil cases. A case may be transferred from one federal district to another district in which the case {{c2::could have been filed}}, or to a district to which {{c3::all parties consent}}. When venue is {{c4::proper}}, transfer is discretionary based on the {{c5::interest of justice}} and {{c6::convenience of parties and witnesses}}. When venue is {{c7::improper}}, the court may {{c8::transfer in the interest of justice or dismiss}}. After transfer, special rules govern which court’s {{c9::choice-of-law rules}} apply, and {{c10::valid forum-selection clauses}} usually control the choice of federal district absent {{c11::compelling public factors}}.
cards.easyContent: Federal law controls transfer of venue. A case can be moved to another federal district where it could have been filed, or to one all parties consent to. If venue is proper, transfer is discretionary based on convenience and the interest of justice. If venue is improper, the court may transfer in the interest of justice or dismiss. After transfer, choice-of-law consequences and any forum-selection clause help determine applicable law and forum.
cards.mediumContent: Venue transfer in federal court is governed by federal law and allows a case to be moved to a district where the case could have been brought or to which all parties consent. If the original venue is proper, the court may, in its discretion, transfer based on the interest of justice and the convenience of parties and witnesses, assessed through public and private factors. If the original venue is improper, the court may transfer in the interest of justice or dismiss. After transfer, the transferee court usually applies the transferor court’s choice-of-law rules unless the original venue was improper, in which case the transferee uses its own rules. Valid forum-selection clauses pointing to a federal district are ordinarily enforced unless compelling public factors counsel against transfer.
cards.hardContent: Federal law governs transfer of venue in civil actions. A case may be transferred from one federal district to another federal district in which the case could have been filed, or to any federal district to which all parties consent. Any party may move for transfer, but if the original venue is proper, the court may deny the motion. When venue in the original district is proper, transfer is discretionary and depends on the interest of justice and the convenience of parties and witnesses, evaluated through public factors (e.g., applicable law, which community should bear jury service, systemic interests) and private factors (e.g., convenience of parties and witnesses, locations of evidence and witnesses). When venue in the original district is improper, the court may either transfer the case in the interest of justice or dismiss it. After transfer, the transferee court generally applies the transferor court’s choice-of-law rules regardless of who sought transfer, except that if the original venue was improper, the transferee court applies its own choice-of-law rules. Valid forum-selection clauses specifying a federal district are ordinarily enforced through transfer, and the case must be sent to the chosen district unless compelling public factors strongly weigh against doing so.
cards.mnemonic: PIP + FS: Proper→Interest & Private/Public; Improper→transfer or dismiss; Forum-Selection controls.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) basic rule and standard for transfer when venue is proper, (2) transfer vs. dismissal when venue improper, (3) choice-of-law consequences of transfer, (4) effect of forum-selection clauses.
cards.clozeLite: If {{c1::venue is proper}}, transfer is {{c2::discretionary}} based on {{c3::convenience}} and {{c4::interest of justice}}; {{c5::improper venue}} → transfer or dismiss.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 021. Forum non conveniens
cards.backPlain: When there is a more appropriate forum for the litigation, but the case cannot be transferred there, a court may dismiss the action under the doctrine of forum non conveniens. 1. Adequate alternative forum 1.1. Because dismissal is consequential, a court will not grant forum non conveniens without finding that there is an adequate alternative forum. 1.2. When adequacy is in doubt, a court may stay the proceeding rather than dismiss, so that it can resume litigation if necessary. 2. Factors 2.1. The court evaluates forum non conveniens based on the same public and private factors as for venue transfer (e.g., convenience, applicable law, burden on local courts and jurors). 2.2. A strong showing of both public and private interests is generally required to justify dismissal or a stay.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the doctrine of forum non conveniens in federal civil procedure, and what must a court find and consider before dismissing or staying a case on that basis?
cards.cloze: When there is a more appropriate forum for the litigation, but the case cannot be {{c1::transferred}} there, a court may {{c2::dismiss the action}} under the doctrine of {{c3::forum non conveniens}}. 1. Adequate alternative forum 1.1. Because dismissal is consequential, a court will not grant forum non conveniens without finding that there is an {{c4::adequate alternative forum}}. 1.2. When adequacy is in doubt, a court may {{c5::stay the proceeding}} rather than dismiss, so that it can resume litigation if necessary. 2. Factors 2.1. The court evaluates forum non conveniens based on the same {{c6::public and private factors}} as for venue transfer (e.g., convenience, applicable law, burden on local courts and jurors). 2.2. A {{c7::strong showing}} of both public and private interests is generally required to justify {{c8::dismissal or a stay}}.
cards.easyContent: Forum non conveniens allows a court to dismiss (or sometimes stay) a case when there is a more appropriate forum that cannot be reached by transfer, but only if an adequate alternative forum exists. The court uses the same public and private interest factors as for venue transfer and requires a strong showing to dismiss or stay.
cards.mediumContent: Under forum non conveniens, if there is a more appropriate forum but the case cannot be transferred there (often because it is foreign or a state court), a court may dismiss the action, or in doubtful cases stay it, so litigation can proceed elsewhere. The court must first find that an adequate alternative forum exists, and then weigh the same public and private interest factors used in venue transfer analysis—such as convenience, applicable law, and burdens on local courts and jurors. A strong showing of both public and private interests is generally needed to justify dismissal or a stay.
cards.hardContent: Forum non conveniens permits a court to decline to exercise jurisdiction when there is a more appropriate forum for the litigation but the action cannot simply be transferred there, typically because the alternative is a foreign or state court. Before granting forum non conveniens, the court must find an adequate alternative forum; if adequacy is uncertain, the court may stay, rather than dismiss, so that it can resume proceedings if necessary. In deciding whether to dismiss or stay, the court applies the same public and private interest factors used in venue transfer analysis, including convenience to parties and witnesses, location of evidence, applicable law, and the burden on local courts and jurors. Only a strong showing that these public and private interests favor the alternative forum justifies dismissal or a stay under forum non conveniens.
cards.mnemonic: FNC: Foreign forum, Not-transferable, Compare factors.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::forum non conveniens}}, a court may {{c2::dismiss or stay}} when there is an {{c3::adequate alternative forum}} and {{c4::public and private interest factors}} strongly favor it.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 022. Service of Process
cards.backPlain: Service of process is delivery to the defendant by the plaintiff of the summons and complaint, which satisfies the notice requirement for personal jurisdiction. Subsequent papers filed with the court (e.g., motions, answers) do not require formal service. Service requirements: 1. What must be served 1.1. Summons: formal notice of the suit, signed by the court clerk, telling the defendant when and where to appear and identifying the court, the parties, and the plaintiff's attorney; and 1.2. Copy of the complaint. 2. Timing 2.1. Service must be completed within 90 days of filing the case. 2.2. If not satisfied, the case is dismissed without prejudice, unless the plaintiff shows good cause for delay. 3. Who may serve 3.1. Any non-party who is at least 18 years old may serve process.
cards.frontPrompt: What is service of process in federal civil procedure, and what are the basic requirements as to what must be served, timing, and who may serve?
cards.cloze: Service of process is delivery to the {{c1::defendant}} by the {{c2::plaintiff}} of the {{c3::summons and complaint}}, which satisfies the {{c4::notice requirement for personal jurisdiction}}. Subsequent papers filed with the court (e.g., motions, answers) do {{c5::not require formal service}}. Service requirements: 1. What must be served 1.1. {{c6::Summons}}: formal notice of the suit, signed by the court clerk, telling the defendant when and where to appear and identifying the court, the parties, and the plaintiff's attorney; and 1.2. Copy of the {{c7::complaint}}. 2. Timing 2.1. Service must be completed within {{c8::90 days}} of filing the case. 2.2. If not satisfied, the case is {{c9::dismissed without prejudice}}, unless the plaintiff shows {{c10::good cause for delay}}. 3. Who may serve 3.1. Any {{c11::non-party}} who is at least {{c12::18 years old}} may serve process.
cards.easyContent: Service of process is the formal delivery of the summons and complaint to the defendant, giving notice for personal jurisdiction. It must be made within 90 days of filing by a non-party at least 18 years old, and includes both the summons and a copy of the complaint.
cards.mediumContent: Service of process is the plaintiff’s delivery of the summons and complaint to the defendant, which satisfies the constitutional notice requirement for personal jurisdiction. The defendant must receive a summons signed by the clerk identifying the court, parties, plaintiff’s attorney, and when and where to appear, plus a copy of the complaint. Service must be completed within 90 days after the complaint is filed; failure results in dismissal without prejudice unless the plaintiff shows good cause. Any non-party who is at least 18 years old may serve process. Later filings, like motions and answers, do not require formal service of process.
cards.hardContent: In federal civil procedure, service of process is the delivery of the summons and complaint by the plaintiff to the defendant, thereby satisfying the notice requirement for personal jurisdiction. The defendant must be served with (1) a summons—formal notice of the suit, signed by the court clerk, stating when and where to appear, and identifying the court, the parties, and the plaintiff’s attorney—and (2) a copy of the complaint. Service must be accomplished within 90 days of filing the case; otherwise, the action is dismissed without prejudice unless the plaintiff shows good cause for the delay. Service may be carried out by any non-party who is at least 18 years old. Subsequent papers filed with the court, such as motions and answers, do not require this level of formal service.
cards.mnemonic: SCC 90 by 18+: Summons, Complaint, 90 days, non-party adult.
cards.clozeLite: Federal {{c1::service of process}} requires serving {{c2::summons + complaint}} within {{c3::90 days of filing}} by {{c4::any non-party age 18+}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 023. Methods of Service
cards.backPlain: Most common methods of service of process in federal court: 1. Personal service 1.1. Delivery of the summons and complaint directly to the defendant. 2. Substituted service 2.1. Leaving the summons and complaint with a third person at the defendant's usual abode. 2.2. The third person must be legally competent and must reside at the abode. 3. Service upon defendant's authorized agent 3.1. Service on an agent authorized by appointment or by law to receive service of process. 3.2. Receipt of service must be within the scope of the agency. 4. Any method permitted under state law 4.1. The federal court may use any method of service permitted by the law of the state where the federal court sits or where service is effected.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main methods of serving process in federal court, including personal, substituted, agent, and state-law methods?
cards.cloze: Most common methods of service of process in federal court: 1. {{c1::Personal service}} 1.1. Delivery of the summons and complaint directly to the defendant. 2. {{c2::Substituted service}} 2.1. Leaving the summons and complaint with a third person at the defendant's {{c3::usual abode}}. 2.2. The third person must be {{c4::legally competent}} and must {{c5::reside at the abode}}. 3. Service upon defendant's {{c6::authorized agent}} 3.1. Service on an agent authorized by {{c7::appointment or by law}} to receive service of process. 3.2. Receipt of service must be within the {{c8::scope of the agency}}. 4. Any method permitted under {{c9::state law}} 4.1. The federal court may use any method of service permitted by the law of the state {{c10::where the federal court sits}} or {{c11::where service is effected}}.
cards.easyContent: Federal process can be served by personal delivery to the defendant, by substituted service at the defendant’s usual abode on a competent resident, by serving an authorized agent, or by any method allowed by the state law where the federal court sits or where service is made.
cards.mediumContent: In federal court, the main methods of service of process are: (1) personal service—delivering the summons and complaint directly to the defendant; (2) substituted service—leaving them with a legally competent person who resides at the defendant’s usual abode; (3) service on the defendant’s authorized agent—an agent authorized by appointment or by law to receive service, within the scope of the agency; and (4) any method permitted under state law, either of the state where the federal court sits or the state where service is effected.
cards.hardContent: The principal methods of serving process in federal court include: personal service, which is direct delivery of the summons and complaint to the defendant; substituted service, which allows leaving the papers with a legally competent person who resides at the defendant’s usual abode; and service on the defendant’s authorized agent, so long as the agent is authorized by appointment or law to receive service and the receipt is within the scope of that authority. Additionally, Rule 4 allows the federal court to use any service method permitted by the law of the state where the federal court sits or the state where service is effected, expanding the available options beyond the federal rules’ specific methods.
cards.mnemonic: P-S-A-S: Personal, Substituted, Agent, State-law methods.
cards.clozeLite: Fed. process methods: {{c1::personal service}}, {{c2::substituted service at usual abode}}, {{c3::service on authorized agent}}, or {{c4::any method allowed by relevant state law}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 024. Waiver of Service
cards.backPlain: 1. Requesting waiver 1.1. The plaintiff may request that the defendant waive formal service by mailing the defendant the complaint and a formal request to waive service. 1.2. If the defendant denies the request or fails to respond, the plaintiff must serve through another acceptable method, and the defendant must pay for the cost of that service (unless good cause for failure to waive is shown). 2. Effect of waiver 2.1. If the defendant agrees to waive service, the defendant's time to answer the complaint is extended to 60 days from the date the waiver request was sent (instead of the normal 21 days after service). 3. Preservation of objections 3.1. Waiving service does not waive the right to object to venue or jurisdiction.
cards.frontPrompt: How does waiver of service work in federal court, including how it is requested, the consequences of refusing, the time to answer if waived, and what rights are preserved?
cards.cloze: 1. Requesting waiver 1.1. The {{c1::plaintiff}} may request that the {{c2::defendant}} waive formal service by {{c3::mailing}} the defendant the complaint and a formal request to waive service. 1.2. If the defendant denies the request or fails to respond, the plaintiff must serve through another acceptable method, and the defendant must {{c4::pay for the cost of that service}} (unless good cause for failure to waive is shown). 2. Effect of waiver 2.1. If the defendant agrees to waive service, the defendant's time to answer the complaint is extended to {{c5::60 days}} from the date the waiver request was sent (instead of the normal {{c6::21 days}} after service). 3. Preservation of objections 3.1. Waiving service does {{c7::not waive the right to object to venue or jurisdiction}}.
cards.easyContent: A plaintiff can mail a defendant a complaint and request that the defendant waive formal service; if the defendant refuses without good cause, the defendant must later pay the costs of service. If the defendant waives, the time to answer extends to 60 days from the mailing, and the defendant still may object to venue or jurisdiction.
cards.mediumContent: In federal court, a plaintiff may seek waiver of formal service by mailing the defendant the complaint and a formal waiver request. If the defendant refuses or does not respond without good cause, the plaintiff must use another valid service method, and the defendant must pay the costs of that service. If the defendant waives service, the time to answer is enlarged to 60 days from the date the waiver request was sent (rather than the standard 21 days after formal service). Importantly, agreeing to waive service does not waive the defendant’s right to later object to venue or jurisdiction.
cards.hardContent: Waiver of service is a cost-saving mechanism under the federal rules. The plaintiff may mail the defendant both the complaint and a formal request that the defendant waive formal service. If the defendant does not return the waiver without showing good cause, the plaintiff must serve by some other acceptable method, and the defendant will be required to pay the resulting service costs. If the defendant timely waives, the defendant gains extra time to answer—the period to respond is extended to 60 days from when the waiver request was sent, as opposed to the usual 21 days after actual service. Crucially, by waiving formal service the defendant does not forfeit the ability to object to venue or personal jurisdiction in a later motion or responsive pleading.
cards.mnemonic: WAIVE: Write, Avoid costs, Increase time, Venue & PJ kept.
cards.clozeLite: If D {{c1::refuses to waive service without good cause}}, D must {{c2::pay later service costs}}; a {{c3::timely waiver gives 60 days to answer}} and {{c4::does not waive venue or PJ objections}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 025. Interlocutory Injunctions
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition and purpose 1.1 Interlocutory injunctions are court orders requiring a person to do or cease doing a specific action before trial. 1.2 Their purpose is to prevent irreparable injury that will occur before there is a final judgment. 2. Security requirement 2.1 The movant must provide security that will be used to compensate the defendant for damage caused by the injunction if the plaintiff does not ultimately prevail.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an interlocutory injunction, what is its purpose, and what security requirement applies?
cards.cloze: 1. Definition and purpose 1.1 {{c1::Interlocutory injunctions}} are court orders requiring a person to do or cease doing a specific action {{c2::before trial}}. 1.2 Their purpose is to prevent {{c3::irreparable injury}} that will occur before there is a final judgment. 2. Security requirement 2.1 The {{c4::movant}} must provide {{c5::security}} that will be used to compensate the {{c6::defendant}} for damage caused by the injunction if the {{c7::plaintiff does not ultimately prevail}}.
cards.easyContent: An interlocutory injunction is a court order entered before trial to prevent irreparable injury, and the movant must post security to cover any damages if the plaintiff ultimately loses.
cards.mediumContent: An interlocutory injunction is a pretrial court order requiring a person to do or stop doing a specific act to prevent irreparable injury before final judgment. The movant must provide security to compensate the defendant for any damages caused by the injunction if the plaintiff does not ultimately prevail.
cards.hardContent: An interlocutory injunction is a court order entered before trial requiring a person to do or cease doing a specific action. Its purpose is to prevent irreparable injury that will occur before there is a final judgment. As a condition of obtaining such relief, the movant must provide security, which will be used to compensate the defendant for damage caused by the injunction if the plaintiff does not ultimately prevail on the merits.
cards.mnemonic: INTERLOCUTORY: Interim Order Needs Temporary Equity, Requires LOcked-in seCURITY.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::interlocutory injunction}} is a {{c2::pretrial court order}} to prevent {{c3::irreparable injury}}; the movant must {{c4::provide security for damages}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 026. Preliminary Injunctions
cards.backPlain: 1. Traditional 4-part test for a preliminary injunction 1.1 Irreparable injury (no adequate remedy at law). 1.2 Reasonable likelihood of success on the merits. 1.3 Balance of hardships favors granting the injunction. 1.4 Public interest supports granting the injunction. 2. Procedural notes 2.1 Notice and a hearing are required for the adverse party. 2.2 Preliminary injunctions are appealable.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the elements of the traditional four-part test for a preliminary injunction, and what key procedural rules apply?
cards.cloze: 1. Traditional 4-part test for a {{c1::preliminary injunction}} 1.1 {{c2::Irreparable injury}} ({{c3::no adequate remedy at law}}). 1.2 {{c4::Reasonable likelihood of success on the merits}}. 1.3 {{c5::Balance of hardships}} favors granting the injunction. 1.4 {{c6::Public interest}} supports granting the injunction. 2. Procedural notes 2.1 {{c7::Notice and a hearing}} are required for the adverse party. 2.2 Preliminary injunctions are {{c8::appealable}}.
cards.easyContent: A preliminary injunction requires irreparable injury, likely success on the merits, a balance of hardships favoring the movant, and consistency with the public interest, and it can only be issued after notice and a hearing and is appealable.
cards.mediumContent: To obtain a preliminary injunction, the movant must show: (1) irreparable injury with no adequate remedy at law, (2) a reasonable likelihood of success on the merits, (3) a balance of hardships favoring the injunction, and (4) that the public interest supports it. The court must give the adverse party notice and a hearing, and preliminary injunctions are immediately appealable.
cards.hardContent: A preliminary injunction is an interlocutory order that issues only if the movant satisfies the traditional four-part test: (1) irreparable injury, meaning there is no adequate remedy at law; (2) a reasonable likelihood of success on the merits; (3) the balance of hardships between the parties favors granting the injunction; and (4) the public interest supports granting the relief. Procedurally, the adverse party must receive notice and an opportunity for a hearing, and a preliminary injunction is immediately appealable as of right.
cards.mnemonic: IRHP: Irreparable harm, Reasonable success, Hardships, Public interest.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::preliminary injunction}} requires {{c2::irreparable injury}}, {{c3::likely success on the merits}}, {{c4::hardships favoring the movant}}, and {{c5::public interest support}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 027. Temporary Restraining Orders (T ROs)
cards.backPlain: 1. Purpose and appealability 1.1 A temporary restraining order (TRO) is issued by the court when necessary to prevent immediate, irreparable injury to a party. 1.2 A TRO is not immediately appealable unless it is extended and treated as a preliminary injunction. 2. Expiration and extension 2.1 A TRO expires 14 days from issuance. 2.2 The court may extend a TRO for good cause or with the adverse party's consent. 2.3 If extended beyond the initial period, the TRO is treated as a preliminary injunction and thus becomes appealable. 3. Notice to the adverse party 3.1 Notice to the adverse party is not required if the moving party either: 3.1.1 Shows immediate and irreparable injury will result to her before the adverse party can be heard in opposition; or 3.1.2 Describes reasonable yet unsuccessful efforts made to give the adverse party notice. 4. Actual notice and enforcement 4.1 A party must have actual notice of the TRO before they can be held in contempt for violating it.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a temporary restraining order (TRO), how long does it last, when can it issue without notice, and when is it appealable?
cards.cloze: 1. Purpose and appealability 1.1 A {{c1::temporary restraining order (TRO)}} is issued by the court when necessary to prevent {{c2::immediate, irreparable injury}} to a party. 1.2 A TRO is {{c3::not immediately appealable}} unless it is {{c4::extended and treated as a preliminary injunction}}. 2. Expiration and extension 2.1 A TRO expires {{c5::14 days}} from issuance. 2.2 The court may extend a TRO for {{c6::good cause}} or with the {{c7::adverse party's consent}}. 2.3 If extended beyond the initial period, the TRO is treated as a {{c8::preliminary injunction}} and thus becomes {{c9::appealable}}. 3. Notice to the adverse party 3.1 Notice to the adverse party is {{c10::not required}} if the moving party either: 3.1.1 Shows {{c11::immediate and irreparable injury}} will result to her before the adverse party can be heard in opposition; or 3.1.2 Describes {{c12::reasonable yet unsuccessful efforts}} made to give the adverse party notice. 4. Actual notice and enforcement 4.1 A party must have {{c13::actual notice}} of the TRO before they can be held in {{c14::contempt}} for violating it.
cards.easyContent: A TRO is a short-term order to prevent immediate, irreparable injury; it usually lasts 14 days, can issue without notice in emergencies, and becomes appealable only if extended and treated as a preliminary injunction.
cards.mediumContent: A temporary restraining order is issued to prevent immediate, irreparable injury and is generally not immediately appealable. It expires 14 days after issuance, but the court may extend it for good cause or with the adverse party's consent; if extended, it is treated as a preliminary injunction and becomes appealable. A TRO can issue without notice if the movant shows immediate irreparable harm before the opponent can be heard or describes reasonable but unsuccessful efforts to give notice, and a party must have actual notice before being held in contempt for violating it.
cards.hardContent: A temporary restraining order (TRO) is an emergency order issued when necessary to prevent immediate, irreparable injury to a party. A TRO expires 14 days from issuance, but the court may extend it for good cause or with the adverse party's consent; if extended beyond the initial period, it is treated as a preliminary injunction and is then appealable. Notice to the adverse party is not required if the moving party shows that immediate and irreparable injury will result before the adverse party can be heard in opposition, or describes reasonable yet unsuccessful efforts to give notice. A party must have actual notice of the TRO before they can be held in contempt for violating it.
cards.mnemonic: TRO: Tiny, Rapid Order—14 days, can be ex parte, extended = prelim appealable.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::temporary restraining order}} prevents {{c2::immediate, irreparable injury}}, lasts {{c3::14 days}}, may be {{c4::ex parte in emergencies}}, and if {{c5::extended}} is treated as a {{c6::preliminary injunction and becomes appealable}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 028. Complaint
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition 1.1 The complaint is the initial pleading in a lawsuit, filed by the plaintiff, which begins an action and gives notice to opposing parties. 2. Required contents 2.1 Statement of jurisdiction 2.1.1 A short and plain statement of the grounds upon which the court's jurisdiction depends (i.e., why the court has subject-matter jurisdiction). 2.2 Statement of the claim 2.2.1 A short and plain statement of the plaintiff's claim, showing entitlement to relief. 2.2.2 Plausibility pleading standard: The complaint must contain sufficient factual matter to state a claim that is plausible on its face. 2.2.3 Allegations are accepted as true, but conclusory allegations are ignored. 2.2.4 Plausibility means factual content that allows the court to draw the reasonable inference that the defendant is liable. 2.2.5 Plausibility is more than possibility but less than probability; judges are encouraged to use their judicial experience and common sense. 2.3 Demand for judgment 2.3.1 A description of the relief sought (e.g., money damages, injunction, declaratory relief).
cards.frontPrompt: What is a complaint in federal civil procedure, and what are its required contents under the plausibility pleading standard?
cards.cloze: 1. Definition 1.1 The {{c1::complaint}} is the {{c2::initial pleading}} in a lawsuit, filed by the {{c3::plaintiff}}, which begins an action and gives notice to opposing parties. 2. Required contents 2.1 {{c4::Statement of jurisdiction}} 2.1.1 A {{c5::short and plain statement}} of the grounds upon which the court's {{c6::jurisdiction}} depends (why the court has {{c7::subject-matter jurisdiction}}). 2.2 {{c8::Statement of the claim}} 2.2.1 A {{c9::short and plain statement}} of the plaintiff's claim, showing {{c10::entitlement to relief}}. 2.2.2 {{c11::Plausibility pleading standard}}: The complaint must contain sufficient factual matter to state a claim that is {{c12::plausible on its face}}. 2.2.3 Allegations are {{c13::accepted as true}}, but {{c14::conclusory allegations are ignored}}. 2.2.4 Plausibility means {{c15::factual content that allows the court to draw the reasonable inference that the defendant is liable}}. 2.2.5 Plausibility is {{c16::more than possibility but less than probability}}; judges may use their {{c17::judicial experience and common sense}}. 2.3 {{c18::Demand for judgment}} 2.3.1 A description of the {{c19::relief sought}} (e.g., money damages, injunction, declaratory relief).
cards.easyContent: A complaint is the plaintiff's initial pleading that starts the lawsuit and must state the court's jurisdiction, a short and plain claim showing entitlement to relief under the plausibility standard, and a demand for the relief sought.
cards.mediumContent: The complaint is the initial pleading filed by the plaintiff that commences the action and gives notice to the defendant. It must contain: (1) a short and plain statement of the grounds for the court's subject-matter jurisdiction; (2) a short and plain statement of the claim showing entitlement to relief, with enough factual matter to make the claim plausible on its face (allegations are taken as true, but conclusory statements are disregarded); and (3) a demand for judgment describing the relief sought, such as damages or injunctive relief.
cards.hardContent: In federal civil procedure, the complaint is the plaintiff's initial pleading that begins the action and provides notice to opposing parties. It must include: (1) a short and plain statement of the grounds for the court's jurisdiction, explaining why the court has subject-matter jurisdiction; (2) a short and plain statement of the plaintiff's claim showing entitlement to relief, which under the plausibility pleading standard must contain sufficient factual matter to state a claim that is plausible on its face—courts accept factual allegations as true but ignore conclusory allegations, and plausibility requires factual content from which the court can reasonably infer defendant's liability, being more than mere possibility but less than probability, guided by judicial experience and common sense; and (3) a demand for judgment describing the relief sought, such as money damages, injunctive, or declaratory relief.
cards.mnemonic: Complaint contents = JCD: Jurisdiction, Claim, Demand.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::complaint}} is the plaintiff's initial pleading and must state {{c2::SMJ grounds}}, a {{c3::short and plain plausible claim}}, and a {{c4::demand for relief}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 029. Answer
cards.backPlain: The answer is the defendant's responsive pleading to the complaint. It must be filed within 21 days after service of process (or 14 days after a ruling on a Rule 12 motion) and must respond to each allegation and raise any affirmative defenses, or risk waiver. The defendant may also assert counterclaims—both compulsory and permissive—in the answer. Overview of subtopics: 1) Definition, purpose, and timing of the answer. 2) Forms of responses to the complaint's allegations, including the effect of failing to deny. 3) Affirmative defenses that must be pleaded and are otherwise waived. 4) Counterclaims that may or must be asserted in the answer (compulsory vs. permissive).
cards.frontPrompt: In federal civil procedure, what is an answer, when is it due, and what main types of content must it contain?
cards.cloze: The {{c1::answer}} is the {{c2::defendant's responsive pleading}} to the complaint. It must be filed within {{c3::21 days}} after service of process (or {{c4::14 days}} after a ruling on a {{c5::Rule 12 motion}}) and must {{c6::respond to each allegation}} and {{c7::raise any affirmative defenses}} (or risk waiver). The defendant may also assert {{c8::counterclaims}}—both {{c9::compulsory}} and {{c10::permissive}}—in the answer.
cards.easyContent: The answer is the defendant’s responsive pleading. It’s generally due 21 days after service (or 14 days after a Rule 12 ruling) and must address each allegation, raise any affirmative defenses, and can include counterclaims.
cards.mediumContent: In federal civil procedure, the answer is the defendant’s responsive pleading to the complaint. It must normally be filed within 21 days after service of process, or within 14 days after the court rules on a Rule 12 motion. In the answer, the defendant must respond to each allegation, must raise affirmative defenses or risk waiving them, and may assert both compulsory and permissive counterclaims against the plaintiff.
cards.hardContent: The answer is the defendant’s formal responsive pleading to a complaint in federal court. It must be filed within 21 days of service of process, or within 14 days after a ruling on a Rule 12 motion. Within the answer, the defendant must: (1) respond to each allegation in the complaint, (2) affirmatively plead certain defenses to avoid waiver, and (3) assert any counterclaims she wishes to bring, including compulsory counterclaims that must be joined in the same action and permissive counterclaims that may be brought separately. The detailed rules governing responses, waiver through failure to deny, the specific types of affirmative defenses, and the distinction between compulsory and permissive counterclaims are covered in the related child cards.
cards.mnemonic: Answer = RAD-C: Respond, Affirm defenses, Deadline, Counterclaims.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) definition and timing of the answer, (2) forms of responses and effect of failing to deny, (3) affirmative defenses and waiver, and (4) counterclaims (compulsory vs permissive).
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::answer}} is the defendant’s {{c2::responsive pleading}} due {{c3::21 days after service}} (or {{c4::14 days after a Rule 12 ruling}}) and must {{c5::respond to each allegation}} and {{c6::raise affirmative defenses}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 030. Rule 12 Motion
cards.backPlain: Federal Rule 12 provides several mechanisms for attacking the sufficiency or form of the pleadings. 1. Rule 12(b) defenses: A defendant may raise specified defenses by motion or in the answer, including jurisdictional, venue, joinder, and failure-to-state-a-claim defenses. Certain of these must be raised in the first Rule 12 response or are waived. 2. Timing and method: Rule 12(b), (c), and (h) defenses may be raised by motion or in the answer, but any Rule 12 motion must be filed before the answer if a responsive pleading is allowed. 3. Other Rule 12 motions: In addition to Rule 12(b) defenses, Rule 12 authorizes (a) a motion for a more definite statement when a pleading is too vague to answer; (b) a motion to strike improper material from a pleading; and (c) a motion for judgment on the pleadings when the pleadings show one party must win as a matter of law.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the overall structure of Federal Rule 12 motions and defenses used to attack the pleadings?
cards.cloze: Federal {{c1::Rule 12}} provides several mechanisms for attacking the {{c2::sufficiency or form of the pleadings}}. 1. {{c3::Rule 12(b) defenses}} may be raised by motion or in the answer, and some are {{c4::waived if not raised in the first Rule 12 response}}. 2. {{c5::Rule 12(b), (c), and (h) defenses}} may be raised by motion or in the answer, but any {{c6::Rule 12 motion}} must be filed {{c7::before the answer}} if a responsive pleading is allowed. 3. Other Rule 12 motions include a {{c8::motion for a more definite statement}}, a {{c9::motion to strike}}, and a {{c10::motion for judgment on the pleadings}}.
cards.easyContent: Rule 12 provides a set of motions and defenses used to attack the sufficiency or form of the pleadings, including Rule 12(b) defenses, motions for a more definite statement, motions to strike, and motions for judgment on the pleadings.
cards.mediumContent: Rule 12 organizes pre-answer and responsive challenges to the pleadings. A defendant can raise Rule 12(b) defenses by motion or in the answer (with some waived if not raised in the first Rule 12 response). Rule 12(b), (c), and (h) defenses may be raised by motion or in the answer, but any Rule 12 motion must be filed before the answer if a responsive pleading is allowed. Additional Rule 12 tools include motions for a more definite statement, to strike improper material, and for judgment on the pleadings when the pleadings show one party must win as a matter of law.
cards.hardContent: Federal Rule 12 provides a framework for attacking the validity or form of the pleadings. A defendant may raise Rule 12(b) defenses by motion or in the answer, including jurisdictional, venue, joinder, and failure-to-state-a-claim defenses, with some subject to waiver if not raised in the first Rule 12 response. Rule 12(b), (c), and (h) defenses may be raised by motion or in the answer, but any Rule 12 motion must be filed before the answer if a responsive pleading is allowed. In addition, Rule 12 authorizes a motion for a more definite statement when a pleading is so vague or ambiguous that a responsive pleading cannot reasonably be prepared; a motion to strike redundant, immaterial, impertinent, or scandalous matter (or the court may strike on its own); and a motion for judgment on the pleadings when the complaint and answer together show that one party must prevail as a matter of law.
cards.mnemonic: Rule 12 is a "PMS Jolt": Pre-answer, Motions, Strike, Judgment on pleadings.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) list of Rule 12(b) defenses and waiver rules; (2) motion for more definite statement and motion to strike; (3) motion for judgment on the pleadings.
cards.clozeLite: Rule 12 organizes {{c1::pre-answer and responsive challenges}} to the pleadings, including {{c2::Rule 12(b) defenses}}, {{c3::more definite statement}}, {{c4::motion to strike}}, and {{c5::judgment on the pleadings}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 031. Counterclaim
cards.backPlain: A counterclaim is an offensive claim, either compulsory or permissive, raised by the defendant against the plaintiff, which may be pleaded in the defendant's answer to the complaint. 1. Jurisdictional requirement: The defendant must ensure the court has jurisdiction to hear any counterclaim. Note: Compulsory counterclaims will almost always have supplemental jurisdiction. 2. Compulsory counterclaim (same transaction or occurrence): 2.1 A compulsory counterclaim is a claim by the defendant against the plaintiff that arises from the same transaction or occurrence as one of the plaintiff's claims. 2.2 It is required in the answer: it must be filed in the defendant's answer or it will be waived (i.e., the defendant cannot assert it in a separate action at a later time). 3. Permissive counterclaim (different transaction or occurrence): 3.1 A permissive counterclaim is a claim by the defendant against the plaintiff that does not arise from the same transaction or occurrence as any of the plaintiff's claims. 3.2 It is not required in the answer: it may be filed with the defendant's answer to the complaint, but does not have to be (i.e., it can be asserted in a separate action filed by the defendant).
cards.frontPrompt: What is a counterclaim, and how do compulsory and permissive counterclaims differ in terms of transaction or occurrence, jurisdiction, and waiver?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::counterclaim}} is an offensive claim, either {{c2::compulsory}} or {{c3::permissive}}, raised by the defendant against the plaintiff, which may be pleaded in the defendant's answer to the complaint. 1. {{c4::Jurisdictional requirement}}: The defendant must ensure the court has jurisdiction to hear any counterclaim. Note: {{c5::Compulsory counterclaims}} will almost always have {{c6::supplemental jurisdiction}}. 2. {{c7::Compulsory counterclaim}} (same transaction or occurrence): 2.1 A compulsory counterclaim is a claim by the defendant against the plaintiff that arises from the {{c8::same transaction or occurrence}} as one of the plaintiff's claims. 2.2 It is {{c9::required in the answer}}: it must be filed in the defendant's answer or it will be {{c10::waived}} (i.e., the defendant cannot assert it in a separate action at a later time). 3. {{c11::Permissive counterclaim}} (different transaction or occurrence): 3.1 A permissive counterclaim is a claim by the defendant against the plaintiff that {{c12::does not arise from the same transaction or occurrence}} as any of the plaintiff's claims. 3.2 It is {{c13::not required in the answer}}: it may be filed with the defendant's answer to the complaint, but does not have to be (i.e., it can be asserted in a {{c14::separate action}} filed by the defendant).
cards.easyContent: A counterclaim is a claim by the defendant against the plaintiff. If it arises from the same transaction or occurrence as the plaintiff’s claim, it is a compulsory counterclaim that must be brought in the answer or is waived; otherwise it is a permissive counterclaim that may be brought separately.
cards.mediumContent: A counterclaim is an offensive claim by the defendant against the plaintiff. The defendant must ensure there is jurisdiction, though compulsory counterclaims almost always fall within supplemental jurisdiction. Compulsory counterclaims arise from the same transaction or occurrence as the plaintiff's claim and must be pleaded in the answer or are waived. Permissive counterclaims arise from a different transaction or occurrence, are not required in the answer, and may be brought in a separate action.
cards.hardContent: A counterclaim is an offensive claim, either compulsory or permissive, raised by the defendant against the plaintiff, generally pleaded in the defendant's answer. The defendant must ensure the court has jurisdiction over each counterclaim, but compulsory counterclaims will almost always qualify for supplemental jurisdiction because they arise from the same transaction or occurrence as the plaintiff's claim. A compulsory counterclaim arises from the same transaction or occurrence as one of the plaintiff's claims and must be asserted in the defendant's answer or it is waived, meaning it cannot later be brought in a separate action. In contrast, a permissive counterclaim does not arise from the same transaction or occurrence as any of the plaintiff's claims; it does not have to be included in the answer and may be asserted later in an independent action by the defendant.
cards.mnemonic: Compulsory = Connected & must Come Now; Permissive = Partitioned & Postpone.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::counterclaim}} is a claim by the {{c2::defendant against the plaintiff}}; {{c3::compulsory}} ones arise from the {{c4::same transaction or occurrence}} and are {{c5::waived if not pleaded in the answer}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 032. Cross Claims
cards.backPlain: A cross-claim is an offensive claim asserted by a co-party. For example, if the plaintiff sues D1 and D2, D1 may assert a cross-claim against D2. 1. Requirements: Same transaction or occurrence. 1.1 A cross-claim must arise from the same transaction or occurrence as the underlying action. 1.2 A cross-claim is never compulsory, even if it arises from the same transaction or occurrence, unlike a compulsory counterclaim. 2. Jurisdiction: Must have an independent basis for subject-matter jurisdiction. 2.1 Cross-claims will almost always satisfy supplemental jurisdiction requirements because they must arise from the same transaction or occurrence.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a cross-claim, what are its transaction-or-occurrence and jurisdiction requirements, and is it ever compulsory?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::cross-claim}} is an offensive claim asserted by a {{c2::co-party}}. For example, if the plaintiff sues D1 and D2, D1 may assert a cross-claim against D2. 1. Requirements: {{c3::Same transaction or occurrence}}. 1.1 A cross-claim must arise from the {{c4::same transaction or occurrence}} as the underlying action. 1.2 A cross-claim is {{c5::never compulsory}}, even if it arises from the same transaction or occurrence, unlike a {{c6::compulsory counterclaim}}. 2. Jurisdiction: Must have an {{c7::independent basis for subject-matter jurisdiction}}. 2.1 Cross-claims will almost always satisfy {{c8::supplemental jurisdiction}} requirements because they must arise from the same transaction or occurrence.
cards.easyContent: A cross-claim is a claim by one co-party against another (e.g., D1 against D2) that arises from the same transaction or occurrence as the underlying action. It is never compulsory, but usually falls within supplemental jurisdiction.
cards.mediumContent: A cross-claim is an offensive claim by a co-party, such as one defendant suing another in the same case. It must arise from the same transaction or occurrence as the underlying action, but unlike a compulsory counterclaim, it is never compulsory. Although there must be subject-matter jurisdiction for the cross-claim, that requirement is usually met via supplemental jurisdiction because of the same-transaction-or-occurrence link.
cards.hardContent: A cross-claim is an offensive claim asserted by a co-party, such as one defendant asserting a claim against another defendant in the same action. The cross-claim must arise from the same transaction or occurrence as the underlying action, which strongly supports the exercise of supplemental jurisdiction. However, a cross-claim is never compulsory, even if it arises from the same transaction or occurrence; the party may choose whether to assert it. There must be an independent basis for subject-matter jurisdiction over the cross-claim, but this is typically supplied by supplemental jurisdiction given the common nucleus of operative fact.
cards.mnemonic: Cross-claims cross co-parties, same deal, never must.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::cross-claim}} is a claim by a {{c2::co-party}} that {{c3::arises from the same transaction or occurrence}} and is {{c4::never compulsory}}, usually supported by {{c5::supplemental jurisdiction}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 033. Amending Pleadings
cards.backPlain: Parties may amend their pleadings once as a matter of course. Additional amendments may be granted with consent of the other parties or with court permission (amendment without right). 1. Amendment as a matter of course: 1.1 Within 21 days after service of the pleading; or 1.2 If the pleading is one that requires a response, within 21 days of service of the responsive pleading or pre-answer motion (e.g., a Rule 12 motion). For example, if the defendant answers the plaintiff's complaint, the plaintiff has 21 days from service of the answer to amend the complaint as a matter of course. 1.3 A party has 14 days, or the time remaining on the initial 21-day deadline (whichever is longer), to respond to an amended pleading. 2. Amendment without right: 2.1 With the written consent of the adverse party; or 2.2 With leave of court (i.e., the court's permission), sought by motion. Leave should be granted freely when justice so requires (a lenient standard). In deciding whether to grant leave, the court looks to: 2.2.1 The length of and reasons for the movant's delay; 2.2.2 Potential prejudice to the parties; and 2.2.3 Futility of amendment.
cards.frontPrompt: When and how may a party amend pleadings as a matter of course, and what are the requirements and standards for amendment without right?
cards.cloze: Parties may amend their pleadings once as a {{c1::matter of course}}. Additional amendments may be granted with consent of the other parties or with court permission ({{c2::amendment without right}}). 1. {{c3::Amendment as a matter of course}}: 1.1 Within {{c4::21 days}} after service of the pleading; or 1.2 If the pleading is one that requires a response, within {{c5::21 days}} of service of the {{c6::responsive pleading or pre-answer motion}} (e.g., a Rule 12 motion). For example, if the defendant answers the plaintiff's complaint, the plaintiff has 21 days from service of the answer to amend the complaint as a matter of course. 1.3 A party has {{c7::14 days}}, or the time remaining on the initial 21-day deadline (whichever is longer), to respond to an amended pleading. 2. {{c8::Amendment without right}}: 2.1 With the {{c9::written consent of the adverse party}}; or 2.2 With {{c10::leave of court}} (i.e., the court's permission), sought by motion. Leave should be granted freely when {{c11::justice so requires}} (a lenient standard). In deciding whether to grant leave, the court looks to: 2.2.1 The {{c12::length of and reasons for the movant's delay}}; 2.2.2 Potential {{c13::prejudice}} to the parties; and 2.2.3 {{c14::Futility}} of amendment.
cards.easyContent: A party may amend a pleading once as a matter of course within 21 days of serving it (or of a responsive pleading or Rule 12 motion). After that, amendments require either the other side’s written consent or leave of court, which should be freely given when justice so requires.
cards.mediumContent: Each party can amend a pleading once as a matter of course: within 21 days after serving it, or, if a response is required, within 21 days after service of a responsive pleading or Rule 12 motion. The opposing party then gets at least 14 days (or the balance of the original 21-day period) to respond to the amended pleading. Further amendments require either written consent of the adverse party or leave of court, which is to be freely granted when justice so requires. Courts consider delay, prejudice, and futility in deciding whether to allow amendment without right.
cards.hardContent: Parties may amend pleadings once as a matter of course. This can be done within 21 days after service of the pleading, or, if the pleading requires a response, within 21 days after service of a responsive pleading or a pre-answer motion under Rule 12. After an amended pleading is served, the opposing party has 14 days, or the time remaining on the original 21-day response period (whichever is longer), to respond. Additional amendments require either the written consent of the adverse party or leave of court, sought by motion. Leave of court should be given freely when justice so requires under a lenient standard. In deciding whether to grant leave, courts generally consider the length of and reasons for the movant's delay, any potential prejudice to the parties, and whether the amendment would be futile.
cards.mnemonic: 21-day free shot, then need Consent or Court (C or C).
cards.clozeLite: A party may amend a pleading once {{c1::as a matter of course within 21 days}}; later amendments require {{c2::written consent of the adverse party}} or {{c3::leave of court, freely given when justice so requires}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 034. Amending Pleadings
cards.backPlain: Relation back: The relation back doctrine applies when a party amends a pleading to add a new claim or defendant after the statute of limitations has run. If relation back is allowed, the amended pleading will be treated as if it was filed when the original pleading was filed. 1. Requirements for relation back: 1.1 New claim: An amendment adding a new claim will relate back if the new claim concerns the same conduct, transaction, or occurrence as the original pleading, i.e., if the new claim is based on the same general set of facts as the original pleading. 1.2 New or substituted defendant: An amendment adding or substituting a defendant will relate back if: 1.2.1 The amendment concerns the same conduct, transaction, or occurrence as the original pleading; and 1.2.2 Within 90 days of filing of the original pleading: 1.2.2.1 The new defendant knew of or received notice of the action; and 1.2.2.2 The new defendant knew or should have known that, but for a mistake, she would have been named originally. This typically applies when the plaintiff sued the wrong defendant first, but the right defendant was aware of the mistake.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the relation-back doctrine for amended pleadings, and what are the requirements for relation back when adding a new claim or a new or substituted defendant after the statute of limitations has run?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Relation back}}: The relation back doctrine applies when a party amends a pleading to add a new claim or defendant after the {{c2::statute of limitations}} has run. If relation back is allowed, the amended pleading will be treated as if it was filed when the original pleading was filed. 1. Requirements for relation back: 1.1 {{c3::New claim}}: An amendment adding a new claim will relate back if the new claim concerns the {{c4::same conduct, transaction, or occurrence}} as the original pleading, i.e., if the new claim is based on the same general set of facts as the original pleading. 1.2 {{c5::New or substituted defendant}}: An amendment adding or substituting a defendant will relate back if: 1.2.1 The amendment concerns the {{c6::same conduct, transaction, or occurrence}} as the original pleading; and 1.2.2 Within {{c7::90 days}} of filing of the original pleading: 1.2.2.1 The new defendant {{c8::knew of or received notice of the action}}; and 1.2.2.2 The new defendant {{c9::knew or should have known}} that, but for a {{c10::mistake}}, she would have been named originally. This typically applies when the plaintiff sued the wrong defendant first, but the right defendant was aware of the mistake.
cards.easyContent: Relation back lets certain amended pleadings filed after the limitations period count as if filed on the original date. A new claim relates back if it arises from the same conduct, transaction, or occurrence; a new defendant relates back only if the same-transaction test is met and the new defendant had timely notice and knew of a naming mistake.
cards.mediumContent: Under the relation-back doctrine, an amended pleading adding a new claim or defendant after the statute of limitations has run can be treated as filed on the date of the original pleading. A new claim relates back when it arises from the same conduct, transaction, or occurrence as the original pleading. A new or substituted defendant can be added if the amendment involves the same conduct, transaction, or occurrence and, within 90 days of filing the original pleading, the new defendant had notice of the action and knew or should have known that, but for a mistake in identity, she would have been named in the original complaint.
cards.hardContent: The relation-back doctrine allows an amended pleading filed after the statute of limitations has expired to be treated as filed on the date of the original pleading. For a new claim, relation back is permitted when the new claim concerns the same conduct, transaction, or occurrence as the original pleading—essentially the same general set of operative facts. For a new or substituted defendant, relation back requires both that the amendment arise from the same conduct, transaction, or occurrence as the original pleading and that, within 90 days after filing the original pleading, the new defendant had notice of the action and knew or should have known that, but for a mistake concerning the proper party's identity, she would have been named originally. This commonly applies when the plaintiff initially sues the wrong defendant but the correct defendant was aware of the error.
cards.mnemonic: New defendant? Think STaN-M: Same Transaction, Notice, Mistake.
cards.clozeLite: Relation back lets an amended {{c1::claim}} or {{c2::defendant}} after SOL be treated as filed on the {{c3::original date}} if it arises from the {{c4::same conduct, transaction, or occurrence}} and the new defendant had {{c5::notice and knew of a naming mistake within 90 days}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 035. Rule 11 Certification
cards.backPlain: Rule 11 requires the attorney or pro se party to sign all pleadings, written motions, and other papers. The signature acts as a certification that, to the best of the signor's knowledge, after all reasonable inquiry: 1. The filing is not for an improper purpose (e.g., harassment, delay). 2. Non-frivolous legal contentions made are warranted by law. 3. Factual contentions have evidentiary support, or are likely to have evidentiary support and are specifically so identified.
cards.frontPrompt: What does an attorney or pro se party certify by signing a paper under Federal Rule 11?
cards.cloze: Rule 11 requires the {{c1::attorney or pro se party}} to sign all pleadings, written motions, and other papers. The signature acts as a {{c2::certification}} that, to the best of the signor's knowledge, after {{c3::all reasonable inquiry}}: 1. The filing is not for an {{c4::improper purpose}} (e.g., harassment, delay). 2. {{c5::Non-frivolous legal contentions}} made are warranted by law. 3. {{c6::Factual contentions}} have {{c7::evidentiary support}}, or are likely to have evidentiary support and are {{c8::specifically so identified}}.
cards.easyContent: By signing a paper under Rule 11, an attorney or pro se party certifies that, after reasonable inquiry, the filing is not for an improper purpose and that the legal and factual contentions are supported.
cards.mediumContent: Rule 11 requires the attorney or pro se party to sign all pleadings, written motions, and other papers. The signature certifies that, after all reasonable inquiry, the filing is not for an improper purpose, legal contentions are non-frivolous and warranted by law, and factual contentions have evidentiary support or are likely to and are specifically identified as such.
cards.hardContent: Rule 11 requires the attorney or pro se party to sign all pleadings, written motions, and other papers. The signature operates as a certification that, to the best of the signor's knowledge, after all reasonable inquiry: (1) the filing is not for an improper purpose (such as harassment or delay); (2) non-frivolous legal contentions made are warranted by existing law or by a non-frivolous argument for changing the law; and (3) factual contentions have evidentiary support, or will likely have evidentiary support after further investigation, and are specifically so identified when they are only expected to be supported later.
cards.mnemonic: Rule 11 = PLEaF: Proper, Legal, Evidentiary Facts
cards.clozeLite: By signing under {{c1::Rule 11}}, a lawyer certifies {{c2::no improper purpose}}, {{c3::non-frivolous legal contentions}}, and {{c4::evidentiary support for facts or likely support}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 036. Rule 11 Sanctions
cards.backPlain: The court may issue sanctions for Rule 11 violations, either on the court's own initiative or on an opposing party's motion. 1. Limits on monetary sanctions: the court may not impose monetary sanctions on represented parties for frivolous legal contentions, but may impose them on the attorney. 2. Safe harbor (party-initiated motions only): 2.1 A Rule 11 motion is served but may not be filed with the court for 21 days, creating a safe harbor. 2.2 During this 21-day period, the opposing party may withdraw the offending document or otherwise remedy the problem. 2.3 If the problem is not remedied or withdrawn within 21 days, the motion can be filed. 2.4 The judge need not provide a safe harbor when acting on the court's own initiative. 3. Opportunity to be heard: before imposing sanctions, the court must give the attorney or party a chance to be heard (often, but not necessarily, an oral hearing). 4. Monetary vs. non-monetary sanctions: the Rules discourage monetary sanctions by urging non-monetary sanctions (such as reprimands, education, or directives) and by creating a default rule that monetary sanctions are payable to the court rather than to the movant.
cards.frontPrompt: How are Rule 11 sanctions initiated, what is the 21-day safe harbor, and what limits and preferences apply to monetary sanctions?
cards.cloze: The court may issue {{c1::sanctions}} for Rule 11 violations, either on the {{c2::court's own initiative}} or on an {{c3::opposing party's motion}}. 1. Limits on monetary sanctions: the court may not impose {{c4::monetary sanctions on represented parties for frivolous legal contentions}}, but may impose them on the attorney. 2. {{c5::Safe harbor}} (party-initiated motions only): 2.1 A Rule 11 motion is served but may not be filed with the court for {{c6::21 days}}, creating a safe harbor. 2.2 During this 21-day period, the opposing party may {{c7::withdraw the offending document or otherwise remedy the problem}}. 2.3 If the problem is not remedied or withdrawn within 21 days, the motion can be filed. 2.4 The judge need not provide a safe harbor when acting {{c8::on the court's own initiative}}. 3. Opportunity to be heard: before imposing sanctions, the court must give the attorney or party a {{c9::chance to be heard}}. 4. Monetary vs. non-monetary sanctions: the Rules {{c10::discourage monetary sanctions}} by urging {{c11::non-monetary sanctions}} and by creating a default rule that monetary sanctions are {{c12::payable to the court rather than to the movant}}.
cards.easyContent: Rule 11 sanctions can be imposed by the court on its own or on motion, but a party’s motion must give a 21-day safe harbor to withdraw or fix the filing, and monetary sanctions are limited and generally discouraged.
cards.mediumContent: The court may impose Rule 11 sanctions either on its own initiative or on an opposing party’s motion. For a party-initiated motion, the moving party must serve—but not file—the motion and allow a 21‑day safe harbor for the opponent to withdraw or correct the challenged paper. The court cannot impose monetary sanctions on a represented party for frivolous legal contentions, though it may sanction the attorney. Sanctioned persons must have an opportunity to be heard, and the Rules favor non-monetary sanctions, with any monetary sanctions normally payable to the court, not the movant.
cards.hardContent: The court may issue sanctions for Rule 11 violations either sua sponte or on an opposing party’s motion. When a party seeks sanctions, it must serve the Rule 11 motion but may not file it for 21 days, providing a safe harbor in which the opposing party can withdraw the offending document or otherwise remedy the problem; only if it is not corrected within 21 days may the motion be filed. The judge need not provide a safe harbor when acting on the court’s own initiative. Before imposing sanctions, the court must give the attorney or party a chance to be heard. The court may not impose monetary sanctions on a represented party for frivolous legal contentions (though it can sanction the attorney), and the Rules discourage monetary sanctions by preferring non-monetary measures and by providing that monetary sanctions are generally payable to the court, not to the movant.
cards.mnemonic: SAFE: Serve, Allow 21, Favor non-monetary, Exclude client fines for law.
cards.clozeLite: Rule 11 sanctions may be {{c1::court-initiated or by motion}}, with a {{c2::21-day safe harbor}} for party motions; {{c3::no monetary sanctions on represented parties for frivolous law}}, and {{c4::non-monetary sanctions are preferred}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 037. Permissive Joinder
cards.backPlain: Under permissive joinder, the plaintiff seeks to join non-parties as co-plaintiffs or co-defendants. 1. Joining additional plaintiffs: joining additional plaintiffs relies on their willingness to join; a non-party that the plaintiff seeks to join as a co-plaintiff must agree to join. 2. Joining additional defendants: joining additional defendants lies in the hands of the plaintiff; a non-party that the plaintiff seeks to join as a co-defendant cannot refuse joinder. 3. Requirements: 3.1 Same transaction or occurrence: joined parties must assert a right to relief arising from the same transaction or occurrence as the original plaintiff's claim. Defendants may be joined if the right to relief asserted against them arises from the same transaction or occurrence. 3.2 Common question of law or fact: there must be at least one common question of law or fact in the joined parties' claims or in the claims against them. Example: after a bus accident, all injured passengers and bystanders join as plaintiffs; a common issue is the driver's negligence, while other issues (e.g., damages) are tried individually for each plaintiff. 4. Jurisdiction: the court must have jurisdiction over the joined parties and claims (including personal jurisdiction and subject-matter jurisdiction). 5. Distinction from impleader: permissive joinder involves joinder of non-parties by the plaintiff, whereas impleader involves joinder of non-parties by a defending party.
cards.frontPrompt: When may a plaintiff use permissive joinder to add parties, and what are the transactional, common-question, and jurisdictional requirements?
cards.cloze: Under {{c1::permissive joinder}}, the {{c2::plaintiff}} seeks to join non-parties as {{c3::co-plaintiffs or co-defendants}}. 1. Joining additional plaintiffs: joining additional plaintiffs relies on their {{c4::willingness to join}}; a non-party that the plaintiff seeks to join as a co-plaintiff must agree to join. 2. Joining additional defendants: joining additional defendants lies in the hands of the {{c5::plaintiff}}; a non-party that the plaintiff seeks to join as a co-defendant {{c6::cannot refuse joinder}}. 3. Requirements: 3.1 {{c7::Same transaction or occurrence}}: joined parties must assert a right to relief arising from the same transaction or occurrence as the original plaintiff's claim; defendants may be joined if the right to relief asserted against them arises from the same transaction or occurrence. 3.2 {{c8::Common question of law or fact}}: there must be at least one common question of law or fact in the joined parties' claims or in the claims against them. 4. {{c9::Jurisdiction}}: the court must have jurisdiction over the joined parties and claims (including personal jurisdiction and subject-matter jurisdiction). 5. Distinction from {{c10::impleader}}: permissive joinder involves joinder of non-parties by the plaintiff, whereas impleader involves joinder of non-parties by a defending party.
cards.easyContent: Permissive joinder lets a plaintiff add co-plaintiffs or co-defendants when the claims arise from the same transaction or occurrence, share at least one common question of law or fact, and the court has jurisdiction over the parties and claims.
cards.mediumContent: Under permissive joinder, a plaintiff may join non-parties as co-plaintiffs (if they consent) or co-defendants (who cannot refuse joinder) if the joined parties’ claims or the claims against them arise from the same transaction or occurrence as the original plaintiff’s claim and share at least one common question of law or fact. The court must also have personal jurisdiction and subject-matter jurisdiction over all joined parties and claims. Permissive joinder is initiated by the plaintiff, unlike impleader, which is initiated by a defending party.
cards.hardContent: Permissive joinder allows the plaintiff to join non-parties as co-plaintiffs or co-defendants. Additional plaintiffs may be joined only if they agree to join, while additional defendants cannot refuse joinder if properly brought in. Joinder is proper only if (1) the joined parties assert a right to relief arising from the same transaction or occurrence as the original plaintiff’s claim (and, for defendants, the right to relief asserted against them arises from the same transaction or occurrence), and (2) there is at least one common question of law or fact in the joined parties’ claims or in the claims against them. The court must have both personal and subject-matter jurisdiction over all joined parties and claims. Permissive joinder is distinct from impleader, which involves joinder of non-parties by a defending party, rather than by the plaintiff.
cards.mnemonic: PERM: Parties from same Event, Related issue, Meets jurisdiction.
cards.clozeLite: Permissive joinder lets a {{c1::plaintiff}} add parties if claims arise from the {{c2::same transaction or occurrence}} and share {{c3::a common question of law or fact}}, with proper {{c4::personal and subject-matter jurisdiction}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 038. Compulsory Joinder
cards.backPlain: Absent parties may be forced to join a case if they are deemed necessary parties. Named defendants can seek dismissal for failure to join a Rule 19 party. 1. Necessary parties: absentees are necessary when either: 1.1 Without the absentee, the court cannot grant complete relief, considering whether multiple suits might follow if the absentee is not made a party. 1.2 The absentee has a legal interest that may be impaired or impeded if the case proceeds without them. 1.3 The absentee has an interest that creates a risk of multiple or inconsistent rulings and obligations. The test is not whether joinder would be merely efficient. Joint tortfeasors, for example, are not necessary parties. 2. Requirements for joinder: an absentee can be joined as a necessary party if: 2.1 There is personal jurisdiction over the absentee; and 2.2 Joining the absentee will not destroy subject-matter jurisdiction (e.g., diversity). 3. Indispensable parties: if a necessary party cannot be joined, ask whether the party is so indispensable that the case should be dismissed. The court looks at these factors: 3.1 Whether an alternative forum is available. 3.2 The likelihood of prejudice to the parties or others if the case goes forward. 3.3 Whether the court can shape potential relief to avoid prejudice. 3.4 Whether the plaintiff would have an adequate remedy if the case is dismissed.
cards.frontPrompt: Under Rule 19, when is an absent party considered necessary, what are the requirements to join them, and when must the case be dismissed for failure to join an indispensable party?
cards.cloze: Absent parties may be forced to join a case if they are deemed {{c1::necessary parties}}. Named defendants can seek {{c2::dismissal for failure to join a Rule 19 party}}. 1. Necessary parties: absentees are necessary when either: 1.1 Without the absentee, the court cannot grant {{c3::complete relief}}, considering whether multiple suits might follow if the absentee is not made a party. 1.2 The absentee has a {{c4::legal interest}} that may be {{c5::impaired or impeded}} if the case proceeds without them. 1.3 The absentee has an interest that creates a risk of {{c6::multiple or inconsistent rulings and obligations}}. The test is not whether joinder would be merely {{c7::efficient}}. {{c8::Joint tortfeasors}} are not necessary parties. 2. Requirements for joinder: an absentee can be joined as a necessary party if: 2.1 There is {{c9::personal jurisdiction}} over the absentee; and 2.2 Joining the absentee will not {{c10::destroy subject-matter jurisdiction}} (e.g., diversity). 3. {{c11::Indispensable parties}}: if a necessary party cannot be joined, ask whether the party is so indispensable that the case should be dismissed. The court looks at these factors: 3.1 Whether an {{c12::alternative forum}} is available. 3.2 The likelihood of {{c13::prejudice}} to the parties or others if the case goes forward. 3.3 Whether the court can {{c14::shape potential relief to avoid prejudice}}. 3.4 Whether the plaintiff would have an {{c15::adequate remedy}} if the case is dismissed.
cards.easyContent: Compulsory joinder (Rule 19) requires certain necessary parties to be joined if feasible; if they cannot be joined and are indispensable, the case must be dismissed.
cards.mediumContent: Under Rule 19, an absent party is necessary if (1) the court cannot grant complete relief without them, (2) they have a legal interest that would be impaired, or (3) their absence risks multiple or inconsistent obligations (joint tortfeasors are not necessary simply for efficiency). A necessary party can be joined only if the court has personal jurisdiction over them and joinder will not destroy subject-matter jurisdiction. If a necessary party cannot be joined, the court decides whether they are indispensable—considering availability of another forum, risk of prejudice, ability to shape relief to avoid prejudice, and whether the plaintiff has an adequate remedy if the case is dismissed—and may dismiss the case if they are indispensable.
cards.hardContent: Compulsory joinder under Rule 19 addresses absent parties who must be joined if feasible. An absentee is a necessary party if, without them, the court cannot afford complete relief among existing parties, they have a legal interest that would be impaired or impeded, or their absence creates a substantial risk of multiple or inconsistent rulings and obligations; mere efficiency is not enough, and joint tortfeasors are typically not necessary. A necessary party may be joined only if the court can exercise personal jurisdiction over them and joinder will not destroy subject-matter jurisdiction, such as diversity.
