cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 055. Voluntary Dismissal
cards.backPlain: A plaintiff may voluntarily dismiss her case, either with or without leave of court. Dismissal will be without prejudice (the plaintiff can bring the claims again), unless an exception applies. 1. Dismissal without leave of court: 1.1 This is allowed before the defendant serves an answer or a motion for summary judgment. 1.2 The plaintiff voluntarily dismisses by filing a written notice of dismissal or a stipulation signed by all parties who have appeared. 1.3 Dismissal is without prejudice, provided this is the first time that the plaintiff has dismissed her case. 1.4 Otherwise, it is with prejudice. 2. Dismissal with leave of court: 2.1 This is required if there has been an answer, a motion, or a prior dismissal. 2.2 The court has discretion to grant dismissal on such terms and conditions as it deems proper. 2.3 Dismissal is without prejudice unless the court states otherwise. 2.4 Pending counterclaim: if the defendant has filed a counterclaim, the plaintiff cannot voluntarily dismiss without the defendant's consent.
cards.frontPrompt: When and how can a plaintiff voluntarily dismiss a federal civil action, and when is the dismissal with or without prejudice?
cards.cloze: A plaintiff may {{c1::voluntarily dismiss}} her case, either with or without {{c2::leave of court}}. Dismissal will be {{c3::without prejudice}} (the plaintiff can bring the claims again), unless an exception applies. 1. {{c4::Dismissal without leave of court}}: 1.1 This is allowed {{c5::before the defendant serves an answer or a motion for summary judgment}}. 1.2 The plaintiff voluntarily dismisses by filing a {{c6::written notice of dismissal}} or a {{c7::stipulation signed by all parties who have appeared}}. 1.3 Dismissal is without prejudice, provided this is the {{c8::first time that the plaintiff has dismissed her case}}. 1.4 Otherwise, it is {{c9::with prejudice}}. 2. {{c10::Dismissal with leave of court}}: 2.1 This is required if there has been an {{c11::answer, a motion, or a prior dismissal}}. 2.2 The court has {{c12::discretion}} to grant dismissal on such {{c13::terms and conditions as it deems proper}}. 2.3 Dismissal is without prejudice unless the {{c14::court states otherwise}}. 2.4 {{c15::Pending counterclaim}}: if the defendant has filed a counterclaim, the plaintiff cannot voluntarily dismiss without the {{c16::defendant's consent}}.
cards.easyContent: A plaintiff can voluntarily dismiss a case once as of right before the defendant serves an answer or summary judgment motion, and that first voluntary dismissal is without prejudice. After an answer, motion, or prior dismissal, the plaintiff needs leave of court, and dismissals may be with prejudice or subject to limits, especially if a counterclaim is pending.
cards.mediumContent: A plaintiff may voluntarily dismiss without leave of court by filing a notice or stipulation before the defendant serves an answer or summary judgment motion; the first such dismissal is without prejudice, later ones are with prejudice. After an answer, motion, or prior dismissal, the plaintiff needs leave of court; the court may dismiss on proper terms and the dismissal is without prejudice unless the court states otherwise. If the defendant has filed a counterclaim, the plaintiff cannot dismiss without the defendant’s consent.
cards.hardContent: A plaintiff may voluntarily dismiss her case with or without leave of court. Without leave of court, dismissal is allowed before the defendant serves an answer or a motion for summary judgment, by filing a written notice of dismissal or a stipulation signed by all parties who have appeared. That dismissal is without prejudice if it is the first time the plaintiff has dismissed her case; otherwise it is with prejudice. With leave of court, dismissal is required if there has been an answer, a motion, or a prior dismissal. The court has discretion to grant dismissal on such terms and conditions as it deems proper, and the dismissal is without prejudice unless the court states otherwise. If the defendant has filed a counterclaim, the plaintiff cannot voluntarily dismiss without the defendant’s consent.
cards.mnemonic: 1st free, 2nd fee: first dismissal free, later costly.
cards.clozeLite: A plaintiff may {{c1::voluntarily dismiss without leave of court}} by notice or stipulation {{c2::before an answer or summary judgment motion}}; the {{c3::first such dismissal is without prejudice}} and {{c4::later ones are with prejudice}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 056. Default & Default Judgment
cards.backPlain: A default judgment against a defendant may be entered when the defendant fails to plead or otherwise defend a properly served complaint. 1. Procedure: 1.1 The plaintiff files a motion for default judgment against the defendant. 1.2 The clerk enters default on the docket if the plaintiff shows that the defendant failed to respond within 21 days of being served (60 days if service was waived). 1.3 Entry of default does not automatically entitle the plaintiff to recovery. 1.4 The clerk or the judge must then enter a judgment of default. 2. Default judgment by court clerk: The clerk may enter default judgment if: 2.1 The defendant has not responded at all. 2.2 The claim is for money damages. 2.3 The plaintiff provides an affidavit of the sum owed. 2.4 The defendant is not a minor or incompetent. 3. Default judgment by court: If the elements above for clerk entry are not met, the court may still enter a default judgment and may hold a hearing on damages. If the defendant has appeared at some point in response to the plaintiff's complaint, the defendant must get 7 days' notice of a hearing on the default motion. 4. Recovery: Recovery on default is limited to the amount demanded in the complaint. 5. Setting aside default judgment: The court may set aside a default judgment for good cause shown within one year, usually satisfied if the defendant can show excusable neglect, mistake, or fraud.
cards.frontPrompt: When can a default judgment be entered in federal court, what are the clerk versus court requirements, and how can a default judgment be set aside?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::default judgment}} against a defendant may be entered when the defendant {{c2::fails to plead or otherwise defend}} a properly served complaint. 1. {{c3::Procedure}}: 1.1 The plaintiff files a {{c4::motion for default judgment}} against the defendant. 1.2 The {{c5::clerk enters default on the docket}} if the plaintiff shows that the defendant failed to respond within {{c6::21 days}} of being served ({{c7::60 days}} if service was waived). 1.3 Entry of default does not automatically entitle the plaintiff to {{c8::recovery}}. 1.4 The {{c9::clerk or the judge}} must then enter a {{c10::judgment of default}}. 2. {{c11::Default judgment by court clerk}}: The clerk may enter default judgment if: 2.1 The defendant has {{c12::not responded at all}}. 2.2 The claim is for {{c13::money damages}}. 2.3 The plaintiff provides an {{c14::affidavit of the sum owed}}. 2.4 The defendant is not a {{c15::minor or incompetent}}. 3. {{c16::Default judgment by court}}: If the elements above for clerk entry are not met, the court may still enter a default judgment and may hold a {{c17::hearing on damages}}. If the defendant has appeared at some point in response to the plaintiff's complaint, the defendant must get {{c18::7 days' notice}} of a hearing on the default motion. 4. {{c19::Recovery}}: Recovery on default is limited to the {{c20::amount demanded in the complaint}}. 5. {{c21::Setting aside default judgment}}: The court may set aside a default judgment for {{c22::good cause shown within one year}}, usually satisfied if the defendant can show {{c23::excusable neglect, mistake, or fraud}}.
cards.easyContent: A default judgment may be entered when the defendant fails to plead or otherwise defend, but entry of default alone does not guarantee recovery. The clerk can enter judgment in simple, sum-certain money cases; otherwise the court must do so, and a default judgment can be set aside for good cause, such as excusable neglect, mistake, or fraud, within one year.
cards.mediumContent: If a properly served defendant fails to plead or otherwise defend, the plaintiff may move for default judgment. The clerk first enters default on the docket when the defendant has not responded within 21 days (or 60 days if service was waived), but judgment still must be entered by the clerk or court. The clerk may enter default judgment if the defendant has not appeared, the claim is for money damages for a sum certain shown by affidavit, and the defendant is not a minor or incompetent. Otherwise, the court must enter default judgment and may hold a damages hearing, giving a defendant who appeared at least 7 days’ notice. Recovery is limited to the amount demanded in the complaint. The court may set aside default judgment for good cause within one year, typically based on excusable neglect, mistake, or fraud.
cards.hardContent: A default judgment may be entered when a properly served defendant fails to plead or otherwise defend. The plaintiff moves for default judgment, and the clerk first enters default on the docket if the defendant failed to respond within 21 days of service (60 days if service was waived). Entry of default does not itself entitle the plaintiff to recovery; a default judgment must still be entered by the clerk or judge. The clerk may enter default judgment only if the defendant has not responded at all, the claim is for money damages, the plaintiff submits an affidavit of the sum owed, and the defendant is not a minor or incompetent. If any of these are lacking, the court must enter default judgment and may hold a hearing on damages; if the defendant has appeared at any point, the defendant must receive 7 days’ notice of the default hearing. Recovery on default is limited to the amount demanded in the complaint. A default judgment may be set aside for good cause shown within one year, usually based on excusable neglect, mistake, or fraud.
cards.mnemonic: CLERK: Clear sum, Legal adult, Empty response, Record affidavit, K.O. judgment.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Clerk}} may enter default judgment only if {{c2::no appearance}}, {{c3::sum-certain money claim with affidavit}}, and {{c4::defendant not a minor or incompetent}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Failure to State a Claim & Motion for Judgment on the Pleadings
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 057. Failure to State a Claim & Motion for Judgment on the Pleadings
cards.front: Failure to State a Claim & Motion for Judgment on the Pleadings
cards.backPlain: Under Rule 12, a defendant may move to dismiss for failure to state a claim or move for judgment on the pleadings due to the plaintiff's failure to bring a plausible claim. The defendant is arguing that, even assuming all allegations in the plaintiff's complaint or pleadings are true, the plaintiff cannot win. If granted, the plaintiff will usually be given leave to amend her complaint. Failure to state a claim vs. motion for judgment on the pleadings: 1. Timing of filing: 1.1 Before the defendant files an answer: a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim. 1.2 After the defendant files an answer: a Rule 12(c) motion for judgment on the pleadings. 2. Materials reviewed by court: 2.1 On a Rule 12(b)(6) motion, the court reviews the sufficiency of the plaintiff's complaint alone. 2.2 On a Rule 12(c) motion, the court reviews all pleadings.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the difference between a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim and a Rule 12(c) motion for judgment on the pleadings in federal court?
cards.cloze: Under {{c1::Rule 12}}, a defendant may move to dismiss for {{c2::failure to state a claim}} or move for {{c3::judgment on the pleadings}} due to the plaintiff's failure to bring a {{c4::plausible claim}}. The defendant is arguing that, even assuming all allegations in the plaintiff's complaint or pleadings are true, the plaintiff cannot win. If granted, the plaintiff will usually be given {{c5::leave to amend}} her complaint. Failure to state a claim vs. motion for judgment on the pleadings: 1. {{c6::Timing of filing}}: 1.1 Before the defendant files an answer: a {{c7::Rule 12(b)(6)}} motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim. 1.2 After the defendant files an answer: a {{c8::Rule 12(c)}} motion for judgment on the pleadings. 2. {{c9::Materials reviewed by court}}: 2.1 On a Rule 12(b)(6) motion, the court reviews the sufficiency of the {{c10::plaintiff's complaint alone}}. 2.2 On a Rule 12(c) motion, the court reviews {{c11::all pleadings}}.
cards.easyContent: Both Rule 12(b)(6) and Rule 12(c) challenge whether the plaintiff has stated a plausible claim assuming the facts are true. Rule 12(b)(6) is filed before the answer and is based on the complaint alone; Rule 12(c) is after the answer and is based on all pleadings.
cards.mediumContent: Under Rule 12, a defendant may seek dismissal for failure to state a claim or judgment on the pleadings by arguing that, even if all alleged facts are true, the plaintiff has not stated a plausible claim for relief. A Rule 12(b)(6) motion is made before the defendant files an answer and is decided by looking only at the complaint, while a Rule 12(c) motion is made after the answer and is decided on all pleadings. If such a motion is granted, courts usually allow the plaintiff leave to amend.
cards.hardContent: Under Rule 12, a defendant can attack the sufficiency of the plaintiff’s claim by arguing that, even assuming all allegations are true, the plaintiff has not pleaded a plausible claim and therefore cannot win. A Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim is filed before the defendant’s answer and is evaluated based solely on the sufficiency of the plaintiff’s complaint. A Rule 12(c) motion for judgment on the pleadings is filed after the answer and is evaluated based on all pleadings. If either motion is granted, the plaintiff is ordinarily given leave to amend the complaint.
cards.mnemonic: "B before C": 12(b)(6) before answer; 12(c) after, all pleadings.
cards.clozeLite: Rule {{c1::12(b)(6)}} is made {{c2::before the answer}} and looks only at the {{c3::complaint}}; Rule {{c4::12(c)}} is {{c5::after the answer}} and based on {{c6::all pleadings}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 058. Summary Judgment
cards.backPlain: Either party may file a motion for summary judgment asking the court to enter judgment. The motion must be filed no later than 30 days after the close of discovery. 1. Burden for moving party: There is no genuine dispute of material fact, and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. In other words, no reasonable person could find for the non-moving party. The motion is based on pleadings and evidence submitted. 2. Burden-shifting: If a party moves for summary judgment, the burden shifts to the non-moving party to show that a triable issue exists. The non-moving party may submit a request for more time to take discovery (and must specify the discovery sought and how it will help). 3. Evidence: The evidence is examined in the light most favorable to the non-moving party. The court can look at the whole record of admissible evidence. Note: this distinguishes summary judgment from Rule 12(b)(6) or 12(c) motions, in which the court may only look at the complaint or pleadings. 4. Partial summary judgment: The court can grant summary judgment on only certain claims or issues.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the standard and timing for summary judgment in federal court, and how does it differ from Rule 12 motions?
cards.cloze: Either party may file a motion for {{c1::summary judgment}} asking the court to enter judgment. The motion must be filed no later than {{c2::30 days after the close of discovery}}. 1. {{c3::Burden for moving party}}: There is {{c4::no genuine dispute of material fact}}, and the moving party is {{c5::entitled to judgment as a matter of law}}. In other words, no reasonable person could find for the non-moving party. The motion is based on {{c6::pleadings and evidence submitted}}. 2. {{c7::Burden-shifting}}: If a party moves for summary judgment, the burden shifts to the non-moving party to show that a {{c8::triable issue}} exists. The non-moving party may submit a request for more time to take discovery (and must specify the {{c9::discovery sought}} and {{c10::how it will help}}). 3. {{c11::Evidence}}: The evidence is examined in the {{c12::light most favorable to the non-moving party}}. The court can look at the {{c13::whole record of admissible evidence}}. Note: this distinguishes summary judgment from {{c14::Rule 12(b)(6)}} or {{c15::12(c)}} motions, in which the court may only look at the {{c16::complaint or pleadings}}. 4. {{c17::Partial summary judgment}}: The court can grant summary judgment on only certain {{c18::claims or issues}}.
cards.easyContent: Summary judgment allows either party to win as a matter of law when there is no genuine dispute of material fact and no reasonable jury could find for the other side. It is filed within 30 days after discovery closes and is decided on the full evidentiary record, unlike Rule 12 motions, which are limited to the pleadings.
cards.mediumContent: A motion for summary judgment must be filed no later than 30 days after the close of discovery. The moving party must show there is no genuine dispute of material fact and that it is entitled to judgment as a matter of law, based on the pleadings and submitted evidence. The burden then shifts to the non-moving party to show a triable issue or to request more time for specific discovery. The court views the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party and may consider the entire record of admissible evidence. This evidentiary review distinguishes summary judgment from Rule 12(b)(6) or 12(c) motions, which are confined to the complaint or pleadings. Courts may grant partial summary judgment on particular claims or issues.
cards.hardContent: Either party may move for summary judgment, which must be filed no later than 30 days after the close of discovery. The moving party bears the initial burden to demonstrate that there is no genuine dispute of material fact and that it is entitled to judgment as a matter of law, based on the pleadings and evidence submitted; essentially, no reasonable person could find for the non-moving party. Once that showing is made, the burden shifts to the non-moving party to show that a triable issue exists, or to request additional time for specific discovery explaining what is sought and how it will create a genuine dispute. The court views all evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party and may look to the whole record of admissible evidence. Unlike Rule 12(b)(6) and 12(c) motions, which are limited to the complaint or pleadings, summary judgment involves an evidentiary record. The court may grant full or partial summary judgment, resolving only certain claims or discrete issues.
cards.mnemonic: No GDMF: No Genuine Dispute of Material Fact, then judgment as a matter of law.
cards.clozeLite: Summary judgment under {{c1::Rule 56}} requires {{c2::no genuine dispute of material fact}} and {{c3::entitlement to judgment as a matter of law}}, based on {{c4::an evidentiary record beyond the pleadings}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 059. Alternative Dispute Resolution
cards.backPlain: Federal courts must have an ADR program, and the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure actively encourage settlement through various means, including mandatory settlement conferences. 1. ADR: Alternative dispute resolution generally refers to any means of settling disputes outside the courtroom, including arbitration and mediation. 2. Mandatory settlement conference: A court-appointed advisor meets with the parties privately and offers an evaluation of the weaknesses of their respective cases. 3. Settlement offers: A party defending a claim may make a formal settlement offer at least 14 days before the date set for trial. 4. Settlement for less than offer: If the claimant rejects a settlement offer and then obtains a judgment less favorable than the unaccepted offer, the claimant must pay costs incurred by the offering party after the offer was made. Ordinarily, costs do not include attorney's fees. The exception involves litigation in situations where federal fee-shifting statutes define fees to be part of costs.
cards.frontPrompt: What forms of alternative dispute resolution and settlement incentives are recognized in federal civil procedure, and what are the key cost consequences of rejecting a settlement offer?
cards.cloze: Federal courts must have an {{c1::ADR program}}, and the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure actively encourage {{c2::settlement}} through various means, including {{c3::mandatory settlement conferences}}. 1. {{c4::ADR}}: {{c5::Alternative dispute resolution}} generally refers to any means of settling disputes {{c6::outside the courtroom}}, including {{c7::arbitration}} and {{c8::mediation}}. 2. {{c9::Mandatory settlement conference}}: A {{c10::court-appointed advisor}} meets with the parties privately and offers an {{c11::evaluation of the weaknesses}} of their respective cases. 3. {{c12::Settlement offers}}: A party defending a claim may make a {{c13::formal settlement offer}} at least {{c14::14 days before}} the date set for trial. 4. {{c15::Settlement for less than offer}}: If the claimant rejects a settlement offer and then obtains a judgment {{c16::less favorable than the unaccepted offer}}, the claimant must pay {{c17::costs incurred by the offering party after the offer was made}}. Ordinarily, costs do not include {{c18::attorney's fees}}. The exception involves litigation where {{c19::federal fee-shifting statutes}} define fees to be part of costs.
cards.easyContent: Federal courts must have ADR programs, and the rules encourage settlement through ADR methods like arbitration and mediation and tools like settlement conferences and formal offers. If a plaintiff rejects a qualifying settlement offer and then wins less than that offer, the plaintiff must pay the defendant’s post-offer costs.
cards.mediumContent: Federal civil procedure requires courts to support ADR programs and encourages settlement using ADR processes such as arbitration and mediation, as well as mandatory settlement conferences where a court-appointed advisor privately evaluates case weaknesses. A defending party may serve a formal settlement offer at least 14 days before trial. If the claimant rejects that offer and then obtains a judgment less favorable than the offer, the claimant must pay the offering party’s post-offer costs, though costs usually exclude attorney’s fees unless a federal fee-shifting statute treats fees as part of costs.
cards.hardContent: Federal courts must maintain ADR programs, and the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure promote settlement through devices such as mandatory settlement conferences. ADR—alternative dispute resolution—encompasses methods of resolving disputes outside the courtroom, including arbitration and mediation. In addition, a party defending a claim may make a formal settlement offer at least 14 days before the trial date. If the claimant rejects the offer and then obtains a judgment less favorable than the unaccepted offer, the claimant must pay the offering party’s costs incurred after the offer was made. Ordinarily, those costs do not include attorney’s fees, but an exception applies when federal fee-shifting statutes define attorney’s fees as part of costs.
cards.mnemonic: ADR: Always Discuss Resolution—arbitration, mediation, and cost-shifting settlement offers.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::defending party}} may serve a {{c2::formal settlement offer}} at least {{c3::14 days before trial}}; if the {{c4::claimant wins less than the offer}}, the claimant must pay {{c5::post-offer costs}} (excluding attorney’s fees absent {{c6::fee-shifting statute}}).

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Right to a Jury Trial & Voir Dire
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 060. Right to a Jury Trial & Voir Dire
cards.front: Right to a Jury Trial, Voir Dire, and Bench Trials – Overview
cards.backPlain: This card covers the federal rules governing (1) the Seventh Amendment right to a civil jury trial and basic jury mechanics, (2) voir dire and the use of for-cause and peremptory challenges, and (3) non-jury (bench) trials and the judge’s fact-finding duties. 1. Seventh Amendment civil jury trial - Applies to civil actions at law (not suits in equity where only equitable relief is sought). - Requires a timely jury demand; otherwise the right is waived. - Juries consist of 6–12 jurors, with unanimous verdicts unless the parties stipulate otherwise. - In mixed legal/equitable cases, the jury decides factual issues underlying legal claims first; the judge then decides any remaining equitable issues. 2. Voir dire (jury selection) - Parties may remove jurors either for cause or via peremptory challenges. - For-cause strikes are unlimited but must be based on bias, prejudice, or relationship. - Each side gets three peremptory challenges, which must be exercised in a race- and gender-neutral manner. 3. Non-jury (bench) trials - Parties may elect a bench trial or trial on documentary evidence alone. - In a bench trial, the judge serves as fact-finder and must issue findings of fact and separate conclusions of law.
cards.frontPrompt: At a high level, how do federal courts handle the right to a civil jury trial, voir dire (jury selection), and non-jury (bench) trials?
cards.cloze: This card covers the federal rules governing (1) the {{c1::Seventh Amendment right}} to a civil jury trial and basic jury mechanics, (2) {{c2::voir dire}} and the use of {{c3::for-cause}} and {{c4::peremptory}} challenges, and (3) {{c5::non-jury (bench) trials}} and the judge’s {{c6::fact-finding duties}}.
cards.easyContent: Federal civil trial procedure includes: (1) the Seventh Amendment right to a jury in actions at law with rules on demand, size, and unanimity; (2) voir dire with unlimited for-cause and limited, race- and gender-neutral peremptory strikes; and (3) bench trials where the judge is fact-finder and must issue findings of fact and conclusions of law.
cards.mediumContent: The federal framework includes: (1) a Seventh Amendment jury right in civil actions at law if timely demanded, with 6–12 unanimous jurors and the jury deciding legal-claim facts before the judge decides equitable issues; (2) voir dire where parties can use unlimited for-cause strikes for biased or related jurors and three race- and gender-neutral peremptory challenges; and (3) non-jury (bench) trials or documentary trials where the judge decides the case and must enter findings of fact and separate conclusions of law.
cards.hardContent: This overview card ties together: (1) the Seventh Amendment right to a civil jury trial in actions at law (not pure equity), including the requirement of a timely jury demand, jury size and unanimity rules, and the allocation of fact-finding between jury and judge in mixed law/equity cases; (2) the voir dire process, including unlimited for-cause strikes for bias or relationship and three peremptory challenges per side that must be race- and gender-neutral; and (3) the structure of non-jury (bench) trials and documentary trials, where the judge serves as fact-finder and must issue findings of fact and separate conclusions of law.
cards.mnemonic: 7th = 6–12 jurors; V for Voir dire; B for Bench trials.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) Seventh Amendment civil jury right and mechanics; (2) voir dire, for-cause, and peremptory challenges; (3) bench trials and judge’s fact-finding duties.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Seventh Amendment}} gives a civil jury right in {{c2::actions at law}} if {{c3::timely demanded}}, with {{c4::6–12 unanimous jurors}} deciding legal facts before {{c5::equitable issues}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 061. Jury Instructions and Verdict
cards.backPlain: 1. Jury instructions 1.1 Parties may file requested jury instructions to be given to the jury during deliberations. Instructions are usually given to the jury at the close of the evidence. 1.2 Proposed instructions: before final arguments, the court gives the parties its proposed jury instructions. 1.3 Objections: parties must have an opportunity to object before final arguments and before the instructions are given to the jury. Failure to object in a timely manner waives the issue for appeal. 2. Jury verdicts 2.1 Court’s role: the court decides the type of verdict to be used. 2.2 General verdict: the jury finds for the plaintiff or defendant and decides the amount of damages or other relief due. 2.3 Special verdict: the jury is asked to make specific factual findings, and the court applies the law to those facts. The court submits questions to the jury regarding each ultimate fact and then makes legal conclusions based on the jury’s findings. Parties must object to proposed jury questions before the jury deliberates. 2.4 General verdict with interrogatories: the court may require a general verdict and also ask the jury to answer specific written questions concerning ultimate facts. The purpose is to ensure the jury properly considered important issues.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the rules in federal court governing jury instructions, objections to them, and the different types of jury verdicts?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Jury instructions}} 1.1 Parties may file requested jury instructions to be given to the jury during deliberations. Instructions are usually given to the jury at the {{c2::close of the evidence}}. 1.2 {{c3::Proposed instructions}}: before final arguments, the court gives the parties its proposed jury instructions. 1.3 {{c4::Objections}}: parties must have an opportunity to object before {{c5::final arguments}} and before the instructions are given to the jury. Failure to object in a timely manner {{c6::waives the issue for appeal}}. 2. {{c7::Jury verdicts}} 2.1 Court’s role: the court decides the {{c8::type of verdict}} to be used. 2.2 {{c9::General verdict}}: the jury finds for the {{c10::plaintiff or defendant}} and decides the amount of {{c11::damages or other relief}} due. 2.3 {{c12::Special verdict}}: the jury is asked to make specific {{c13::factual findings}}, and the court {{c14::applies the law to those facts}}. The court submits questions to the jury regarding each {{c15::ultimate fact}} and then makes legal conclusions based on the jury’s findings. Parties must object to proposed jury questions before the jury {{c16::deliberates}}. 2.4 {{c17::General verdict with interrogatories}}: the court may require a general verdict and also ask the jury to answer specific written questions concerning {{c18::ultimate facts}}. The purpose is to {{c19::ensure the jury properly considered important issues}}.
cards.easyContent: Parties can request jury instructions and must object to improper ones before final arguments or the issue is waived on appeal. The court chooses whether the jury returns a general verdict, a special verdict with factual findings, or a general verdict with written interrogatories on key facts.
cards.mediumContent: In federal court, parties may submit requested jury instructions, and the judge usually instructs the jury at the close of the evidence. Before final arguments, the court circulates its proposed instructions, and parties must object before arguments and before the instructions are given; failure to object waives appellate review. The court also selects the form of verdict: in a general verdict, the jury decides liability (for plaintiff or defendant) and the amount of damages or relief; in a special verdict, the jury answers factual questions and the judge applies the law; and in a general verdict with interrogatories, the jury returns a general verdict and answers specific written questions on ultimate facts to ensure it properly addressed key issues.
cards.hardContent: Federal practice allows parties to file requested jury instructions, which are typically given at the close of the evidence. Before final arguments, the court provides its proposed instructions, and the parties must be given a chance to object both before final arguments and before the instructions are read; a failure to object timely waives the issue for appeal. The court also determines the type of jury verdict. With a general verdict, the jury finds for the plaintiff or the defendant and determines the amount of damages or other relief. With a special verdict, the court submits written questions on each ultimate fact, the jury makes specific factual findings, and the court applies the law to those facts and enters judgment. With a general verdict accompanied by interrogatories, the jury both renders a general verdict and answers specific written questions regarding ultimate facts, which helps ensure the jury properly considered the important factual issues.
cards.mnemonic: G-S-GI: General, Special, General with Interrogatories.
cards.clozeLite: Failure to {{c1::object to jury instructions}} {{c2::before final arguments and before they are given}} {{c3::waives appellate review}}. Federal verdicts: {{c4::general}}, {{c5::special}}, {{c6::general with interrogatories}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Judgment as a Matter of Law
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 062. Judgment as a Matter of Law
cards.front: Judgment as a Matter of Law
cards.backPlain: In extraordinary circumstances, a judge can take a case from the jury and render a decision on an issue. This can occur during trial (judgment as a matter of law, JMOL) or after a jury verdict (renewed judgment as a matter of law, RJMOL). The court views the evidence in the light most favorable to the non‑moving party. 1. Judgment as a matter of law (JMOL) 1.1 A JMOL motion may be brought by either party before the case is submitted to the jury. 1.2 Timing: the defendant can move for JMOL at the close of the plaintiff’s evidence or at the close of all evidence; the plaintiff can move at the close of all evidence. 2. JMOL standard 2.1 The court can grant JMOL on an issue if a reasonable jury would not have a sufficient evidentiary basis to disagree as to the result (i.e., reasonable people could not disagree). 3. Renewed motion for judgment as a matter of law (RJMOL) 3.1 After the court enters judgment based on a jury verdict, the losing party can file an RJMOL seeking entry of judgment in its favor. 3.2 Timing: the motion must be filed within 28 days after entry of judgment. 3.3 Prerequisite: an RJMOL can be filed only if that party previously made a JMOL motion at the appropriate time during trial. 4. RJMOL standard 4.1 The standard is the same as for JMOL: the court may grant RJMOL if there is insufficient evidence for a reasonable jury to have reached the verdict (i.e., reasonable people could not disagree as to the correct result).
cards.frontPrompt: When may a federal court grant judgment as a matter of law (JMOL) or renewed JMOL (RJMOL), and what are the timing requirements and standards for each?
cards.cloze: In extraordinary circumstances, a judge can take a case from the jury and render a decision on an issue. This can occur during trial ({{c1::judgment as a matter of law, JMOL}}) or after a jury verdict ({{c2::renewed judgment as a matter of law, RJMOL}}). The court views the evidence in the light most favorable to the {{c3::non‑moving party}}. 1. {{c4::Judgment as a matter of law (JMOL)}} 1.1 A JMOL motion may be brought by either party before the case is {{c5::submitted to the jury}}. 1.2 Timing: the {{c6::defendant}} can move for JMOL at the {{c7::close of the plaintiff’s evidence}} or at the {{c8::close of all evidence}}; the {{c9::plaintiff}} can move at the {{c10::close of all evidence}}. 2. {{c11::JMOL standard}} 2.1 The court can grant JMOL on an issue if a {{c12::reasonable jury}} would not have a {{c13::sufficient evidentiary basis}} to disagree as to the result (i.e., {{c14::reasonable people could not disagree}}). 3. {{c15::Renewed motion for judgment as a matter of law (RJMOL)}} 3.1 After the court enters judgment based on a jury verdict, the {{c16::losing party}} can file an RJMOL seeking entry of judgment in its favor. 3.2 Timing: the motion must be filed within {{c17::28 days}} after entry of judgment. 3.3 Prerequisite: an RJMOL can be filed only if that party previously made a {{c18::JMOL motion}} at the appropriate time during trial. 4. {{c19::RJMOL standard}} 4.1 The standard is the same as for JMOL: the court may grant RJMOL if there is {{c20::insufficient evidence}} for a reasonable jury to have reached the verdict (i.e., {{c21::reasonable people could not disagree}} as to the correct result).
cards.easyContent: JMOL lets a judge take a case from the jury when, viewing the evidence for the non‑movant, no reasonable jury could find otherwise; RJMOL is the same standard after verdict, filed within 28 days and only if JMOL was previously made.
cards.mediumContent: A party may move for judgment as a matter of law (JMOL) any time before the case is submitted to the jury. The defendant may move at the close of the plaintiff’s evidence or at the close of all evidence; the plaintiff may move at the close of all evidence. The court, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the non‑moving party, may grant JMOL if a reasonable jury would not have a sufficient evidentiary basis to disagree as to the result. After a verdict and judgment, the losing party may file a renewed JMOL (RJMOL) within 28 days of entry of judgment, but only if it previously made a timely JMOL motion at trial. RJMOL is evaluated under the same standard as JMOL: whether there was sufficient evidence for a reasonable jury to reach the verdict.
cards.hardContent: Judgment as a matter of law (JMOL) allows a federal judge, in extraordinary circumstances, to take a case from the jury and decide an issue when the evidence, viewed in the light most favorable to the non‑moving party, is such that a reasonable jury would lack a sufficient evidentiary basis to disagree about the outcome. Either party may move for JMOL before the case is submitted to the jury: the defendant may move at the close of the plaintiff’s case‑in‑chief or again at the close of all evidence, and the plaintiff may move at the close of all evidence. After the jury returns a verdict and the court enters judgment, the losing party may seek a renewed judgment as a matter of law (RJMOL). RJMOL must be filed within 28 days after entry of judgment, and it is available only if that party previously made a JMOL motion at the appropriate time during trial. The standard for RJMOL is identical to that for JMOL—the court asks whether there was sufficient evidence for a reasonable jury to reach the verdict or whether reasonable people could not disagree as to the correct result.
cards.mnemonic: JMOL = Jury Missing One Legal basis; RJMOL = Repeat JMOL in 28 days.
cards.clozeLite: JMOL may be granted when, viewing evidence for the {{c1::non‑moving party}}, {{c2::no reasonable jury}} would have a {{c3::sufficient evidentiary basis}} to disagree; {{c4::RJMOL}} uses the {{c5::same standard within 28 days}} after judgment, only if JMOL was timely moved for at trial.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 063. Motion for a New Trial
cards.backPlain: Either party may file a motion for a new trial if judgment was entered but serious errors occurred at trial. The motion must be filed within 28 days after entry of judgment. 1. Grounds for a new trial (potential errors include, but are not limited to): 1.1 Prejudicial error: a serious legal or procedural error that makes the judgment unfair (e.g., the judge misstates the law or gives incorrect jury instructions). 1.2 Prejudicial misconduct: misconduct by a party, attorney, juror, etc. (e.g., the jury considers evidence that was excluded at trial). 1.3 Judgment against the weight of the evidence: the jury erred in reaching its verdict given the evidence before it. 1.4 Newly discovered evidence: important evidence that could not, with reasonable diligence, have been discovered in time for trial. 1.5 Excessive or inadequate damages: the court cannot increase a jury award (additur violates the Seventh Amendment), but the judge can order a new trial or offer remittitur if convinced the award is too high. 1.5.1 Remittitur: if the jury awards an amount that is so high it shocks the conscience, the court can order a new trial or offer the plaintiff a choice of accepting a lesser figure set by the court or undergoing a new trial. 2. Motion for new trial vs. JMOL or RJMOL 2.1 In granting a new trial, the court is not directing judgment in favor of a party but is instead saying the process should restart because there was some error necessitating a do‑over.
cards.frontPrompt: When can a party move for a new trial in federal court, what are common grounds, and how does a new‑trial motion differ from JMOL or RJMOL?
cards.cloze: Either party may file a {{c1::motion for a new trial}} if judgment was entered but serious errors occurred at trial. The motion must be filed within {{c2::28 days}} after entry of judgment. 1. {{c3::Grounds for a new trial}} (potential errors include, but are not limited to): 1.1 {{c4::Prejudicial error}}: a serious legal or procedural error that makes the judgment unfair (e.g., the judge {{c5::misstates the law}} or gives {{c6::incorrect jury instructions}}). 1.2 {{c7::Prejudicial misconduct}}: misconduct by a party, attorney, juror, etc. (e.g., the jury considers {{c8::evidence that was excluded}} at trial). 1.3 {{c9::Judgment against the weight of the evidence}}: the jury erred in reaching its verdict given the evidence before it. 1.4 {{c10::Newly discovered evidence}}: important evidence that could not, with {{c11::reasonable diligence}}, have been discovered in time for trial. 1.5 {{c12::Excessive or inadequate damages}}: the court cannot {{c13::increase}} a jury award ({{c14::additur}} violates the Seventh Amendment), but the judge can order a new trial or offer {{c15::remittitur}} if convinced the award is too high. 1.5.1 {{c16::Remittitur}}: if the jury awards an amount that is so high it {{c17::shocks the conscience}}, the court can order a new trial or offer the plaintiff a choice of accepting a {{c18::lesser figure set by the court}} or undergoing a new trial. 2. {{c19::Motion for new trial vs. JMOL or RJMOL}} 2.1 In granting a new trial, the court is not {{c20::directing judgment}} in favor of a party but is instead saying the process should {{c21::restart}} because there was some error necessitating a {{c22::do‑over}}.
cards.easyContent: A party may move for a new trial within 28 days after judgment when serious trial errors, misconduct, or an unjust verdict occurred; unlike JMOL or RJMOL, a new‑trial motion does not take the case away from the jury but restarts the trial process.
cards.mediumContent: Either party can seek a new trial within 28 days after entry of judgment if serious errors occurred during trial. Grounds include prejudicial legal or procedural errors (such as incorrect jury instructions), prejudicial misconduct by parties, lawyers, or jurors (such as considering excluded evidence), a verdict against the weight of the evidence, newly discovered evidence that could not have been found with reasonable diligence before trial, or excessive or inadequate damages. Although a federal court cannot increase a jury award (additur), it may order a new trial or offer remittitur, allowing the plaintiff to accept a reduced amount or face a new trial, if the award shocks the conscience. Unlike JMOL or RJMOL, which direct judgment as a matter of law, a new‑trial order simply grants a do‑over.
cards.hardContent: In federal court, either party may move for a new trial within 28 days after entry of judgment if serious trial errors justify starting over. Grounds are broad and include prejudicial legal or procedural error (such as misstatements of law or incorrect jury instructions), prejudicial misconduct by a party, attorney, or juror (for example, the jury considering excluded evidence), a verdict that is against the weight of the evidence, newly discovered evidence that could not, with reasonable diligence, have been discovered in time for trial, and excessive or inadequate damages. The Seventh Amendment bars additur, so the court cannot increase a jury award, but it may grant a new trial or offer remittitur when the award is so high it shocks the conscience, giving the plaintiff the choice between accepting a reduced award set by the court or undergoing a new trial. Unlike JMOL or RJMOL, which replace the jury’s verdict with a judicial judgment, a motion for a new trial merely restarts the trial process to correct the underlying errors.
cards.mnemonic: NEW TRIAL: New Errors, Weighty verdict, Excessive damages warrant redo.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::motion for a new trial}} must be filed within {{c2::28 days after judgment}} and is based on {{c3::serious trial error, misconduct, unjust verdict, or shocking damages}}, but {{c4::unlike JMOL/RJMOL}} it {{c5::restarts the trial instead of directing judgment}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Motion to Set Aside Judgment or Order
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 064. Motion to Set Aside Judgment or Order
cards.front: Motion to Set Aside Judgment or Order
cards.backPlain: Under Federal Rule 60(b), a court may relieve a party from a final judgment or order for several specified grounds (mistake or excusable neglect, newly discovered evidence, fraud or misconduct, void judgment, or satisfied judgment) and, in extraordinary cases, for any other reason that justifies relief. Different grounds are subject to different timing rules: some must be brought within a reasonable time and no more than one year after judgment, while others only have a reasonable‑time requirement.
cards.frontPrompt: On what general grounds and within what overall time limits may a federal court set aside a final judgment or order under Rule 60(b)?
cards.cloze: Under Federal {{c1::Rule 60(b)}}, a court may relieve a party from a {{c2::final judgment or order}} for several specified grounds and, in {{c3::extraordinary cases}}, for any other reason that justifies relief. Different grounds are subject to different {{c4::timing rules}}: some must be brought within a {{c5::reasonable time}} and no more than {{c6::one year}} after judgment, while others only have a {{c7::reasonable‑time}} requirement.
cards.easyContent: Rule 60(b) lets a federal court set aside a final judgment or order for specific reasons (like mistake, new evidence, fraud, void or satisfied judgment) and, rarely, for other extraordinary reasons, subject to strict timing rules.
cards.mediumContent: Under Rule 60(b), a federal court can relieve a party from a final judgment or order for several enumerated grounds and for a narrow catchall in extraordinary circumstances. Some grounds—like mistake, newly discovered evidence, and fraud—have a one‑year outer limit (plus a reasonable‑time requirement); others—like void or satisfied judgments and other reasons—must be raised within a reasonable time only.
cards.hardContent: Federal Rule 60(b) authorizes relief from a final judgment or order on multiple specific grounds and one residual ground. The specific grounds include mistake or excusable neglect, newly discovered evidence that meets strict criteria, fraud or misconduct by the opposing party, void judgments, and judgments that have been satisfied, released, or discharged. In addition, the rule allows relief for any other reason that justifies relief, but this catchall is reserved for truly extraordinary circumstances. The timing limits depend on the ground: motions based on mistake, newly discovered evidence, or fraud must be filed within a reasonable time and in any event no more than one year after entry of judgment, while motions based on a void judgment, satisfaction, or other reasons must be made within a reasonable time.
cards.mnemonic: MNFSJO: Mistake, New evidence, Fraud, void judgment, Satisfied judgment, Other extraordinary reasons.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) specific grounds (1–5); (2) catchall extraordinary relief; (3) timing rules for 1–3 versus 4–6.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::Rule 60(b)}}, a court may relieve a party from a {{c2::final judgment or order}} for {{c3::enumerated grounds}} or a narrow {{c4::catchall in extraordinary circumstances}}, subject to {{c5::strict time limits}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 065. Appeals and Final Judgment Rule
cards.front: Appeals and Final Judgment Rule – Overview
cards.backPlain: Appeals involve both **standards of review** and **limits on appellate jurisdiction**. 1. Standards of review: appellate courts review questions of law de novo, are highly deferential to trial-level findings of fact, and review discretionary rulings only for abuse of discretion. 2. Final Judgment Rule: an appeal generally lies only from a final judgment that resolves the entire case on the merits; otherwise, the appellate court lacks jurisdiction. 3. Exceptions/interlocutory appeals: certain orders—such as injunctions, class certification decisions, some controlling legal questions certified for appeal, and separate final judgments as to some claims or parties—are immediately appealable despite the lack of a final judgment. 4. Timing: a notice of appeal must be filed in the trial court within 30 days after entry of the appealable judgment or order.
cards.frontPrompt: How do appellate standards of review relate to the Final Judgment Rule and its main exceptions (including basic timing for appeal)?
cards.cloze: Appeals involve both {{c1::standards of review}} and {{c2::limits on appellate jurisdiction}}. 1. Standards of review: appellate courts review {{c3::questions of law de novo}}, are highly deferential to {{c4::findings of fact}}, and review {{c5::discretionary rulings}} only for {{c6::abuse of discretion}}. 2. {{c7::Final Judgment Rule}}: an appeal generally lies only from a {{c8::final judgment}} that resolves the {{c9::entire case on the merits}}; otherwise, the appellate court lacks jurisdiction. 3. Exceptions/interlocutory appeals: certain orders—such as {{c10::injunctions}}, {{c11::class certification decisions}}, some {{c12::controlling legal questions certified for appeal}}, and {{c13::separate final judgments}} as to some claims or parties—are immediately appealable despite the lack of a final judgment. 4. Timing: a {{c14::notice of appeal}} must be filed in the trial court within {{c15::30 days}} after entry of the appealable judgment or order.
cards.easyContent: Appeals turn on (1) standards of review (law de novo, facts deferential, discretion for abuse of discretion) and (2) the Final Judgment Rule with limited interlocutory exceptions. A notice of appeal is generally due within 30 days of the appealable judgment or order.
cards.mediumContent: Appellate review has two main pieces: standards of review and appealability. Questions of law (and mixed questions) are reviewed de novo, factual findings are reviewed deferentially (clear error or reasonable jury), and discretionary rulings for abuse of discretion. Under the Final Judgment Rule, only a final judgment resolving the entire case on the merits is appealable, subject to narrow interlocutory exceptions (e.g., injunctions, class certification, certain certified controlling legal questions, and separate final judgments as to some claims or parties). A notice of appeal must be filed within 30 days of the appealable judgment or order.
cards.hardContent: Appeals are governed by distinct standards of review and by jurisdictional limits on which decisions may be appealed. Questions of law and mixed questions are reviewed de novo. Findings of fact from non-jury trials are not reversed unless clearly erroneous, and jury findings are upheld unless no reasonable jury could have reached the same conclusion. Discretionary matters, such as evidentiary rulings, are reviewed for abuse of discretion. Under the Final Judgment Rule, appellate courts generally have jurisdiction only over final judgments—ultimate decisions on the merits that dispose of the entire case. Certain orders, however, are immediately appealable despite not ending the case, including orders relating to injunctions, orders granting or denying class certification, some certified controlling legal questions whose immediate review may materially advance the litigation, and separate final judgments entered as to some claims or parties. A notice of appeal must be filed in the trial court within 30 days after entry of the appealable judgment or order.
cards.mnemonic: L-F-D-30: Law de novo, Facts defer, Discretion abuse, 30 days to appeal.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) standards of review (law, fact, mixed, discretion); (2) Final Judgment Rule and timing; (3) interlocutory/exception categories.
cards.clozeLite: Appellate review uses {{c1::de novo}} for law, {{c2::deferential review}} for facts, and {{c3::abuse of discretion}} for discretion, plus the {{c4::Final Judgment Rule}} and a {{c5::30-day}} notice deadline.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 066. Interlocutory Appeals & Extraordinary Writs
cards.backPlain: Although the basic rule is that only final orders are appealable, several types of non-final (interlocutory) orders can be reviewed before final judgment: 1. Certain interlocutory orders are reviewable as of right (e.g., orders concerning injunctions, receivers, some patent orders where only an accounting remains, and certain property orders like attachment). 2. Discretionary interlocutory review is available under the Interlocutory Appeals Act for certified controlling legal issues and for class certification decisions. 3. Under the collateral order exception, some orders that are collateral to the merits, very important, and effectively unreviewable after final judgment may be appealed immediately. 4. If no appeal is available and irreparable harm would result, a party may seek an extraordinary writ (such as mandamus or prohibition) to compel or prohibit lower court action when normal appellate routes are inadequate.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main paths for obtaining review of interlocutory orders and unappealable orders before final judgment in federal court?
cards.cloze: Although the basic rule is that only {{c1::final orders}} are appealable, several types of non-final ({{c2::interlocutory}}) orders can be reviewed before final judgment, including: (1) certain interlocutory orders reviewable {{c3::as of right}}; (2) {{c4::discretionary interlocutory review}} under the {{c5::Interlocutory Appeals Act}} and for {{c6::class certification}} decisions; (3) the {{c7::collateral order exception}} for important, collateral, effectively unreviewable orders; and (4) {{c8::extraordinary writs}} such as {{c9::mandamus}} or {{c10::prohibition}} when normal routes of appeal are inadequate and irreparable harm is threatened.
cards.easyContent: Most appeals are from final judgments, but certain interlocutory orders can be reviewed early as of right, others via certified interlocutory appeals or class certification review, some under the collateral order doctrine, and truly unreviewable yet harmful orders via extraordinary writs.
cards.mediumContent: Federal appellate jurisdiction generally requires a final judgment, but there are key exceptions. Some interlocutory orders are appealable as of right, such as those concerning injunctions, receivers, certain patent decisions, and property attachments. Discretionary review is available under the Interlocutory Appeals Act for certified controlling legal issues and for orders granting or denying class certification. Under the collateral order exception, an order can be immediately appealed if it is collateral to the merits, too important to be denied review, and effectively unreviewable after final judgment. If no appeal is otherwise available and irreparable harm would result, a party can seek an extraordinary writ (mandamus or prohibition) to compel or restrain a lower court when the normal appellate process is inadequate.
cards.hardContent: While the final judgment rule is the default in federal appellate practice, multiple mechanisms allow pre-judgment review of certain non-final orders. First, specific interlocutory orders are appealable as of right, including orders concerning injunctions, the appointment of receivers, patent cases where only an accounting remains, and certain property-related orders such as attachments. Second, discretionary interlocutory review is available: under the Interlocutory Appeals Act, an appellate court may hear an appeal from a non-final order when the trial judge certifies that the order involves a controlling issue of law with substantial ground for difference of opinion and that an immediate appeal may materially advance the ultimate termination of the litigation; separately, orders granting or denying class certification may be immediately reviewed. Third, under the collateral order exception, an order can be appealed if it is sufficiently distinct from the merits (collateral), too important to be denied review, and effectively unreviewable on appeal from a final judgment. Finally, when no ordinary appeal is available and a party faces irreparable harm, the party may petition for an extraordinary writ, such as mandamus or prohibition, to compel or prohibit lower court action, but only on a showing that normal appellate routes are inadequate.
cards.mnemonic: I-R-P-P plus IAC and Writs: Injunctions, Receivers, Patent, Property; Interlocutory Appeals, class, collateral, writs.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) interlocutory orders reviewable as of right, (2) Interlocutory Appeals Act and class certification, (3) collateral order exception, (4) extraordinary writs.
cards.clozeLite: Aside from {{c1::appealable-as-of-right interlocutory orders}}, parties may use {{c2::certified interlocutory appeals}}, {{c3::class-certification review}}, the {{c4::collateral order doctrine}}, or {{c5::extraordinary writs}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 067. Claim Preclusion ( Res Judicata)
cards.backPlain: A party that has had an opportunity to litigate a claim cannot relitigate the claim once final judgment has been rendered. Claim preclusion (res judicata) is an affirmative defense. 1. Requirements: 1.1 Same parties: the second case was brought by the same party against the same party (e.g., same plaintiff against same defendant). An entity in privity with a party is considered the same party (e.g., an employee and employer are the same party for claim preclusion purposes). 1.2 Same claim: the same claim is at issue in the first and subsequent suits. A "claim" refers to the transaction or series of transactions or occurrences giving rise to the action. Even if not previously raised, a claim can be precluded if it is sufficiently related to prior claims. 1.3 Final judgment on the merits in original claim: there was a final judgment on the merits in the first action. A judgment is final even if it is being appealed. A dismissal with prejudice operates as a judgment on the merits. Technical dismissals (e.g., lack of subject matter jurisdiction, personal jurisdiction, or improper venue) are not on the merits because they do not evaluate the substance of the plaintiff's claim.
cards.frontPrompt: What is claim preclusion (res judicata), and what are the requirements for it to bar a later lawsuit?
cards.cloze: A party that has had an opportunity to litigate a claim cannot relitigate the claim once {{c1::final judgment}} has been rendered. {{c2::Claim preclusion}} ({{c3::res judicata}}) is an {{c4::affirmative defense}}. 1. Requirements: 1.1 {{c5::Same parties}}: the second case was brought by the same party against the same party (e.g., same plaintiff against same defendant). An entity in {{c6::privity}} with a party is considered the same party (e.g., an employee and employer are the same party for claim preclusion purposes). 1.2 {{c7::Same claim}}: the same claim is at issue in the first and subsequent suits. A "claim" refers to the {{c8::transaction or series of transactions or occurrences}} giving rise to the action. Even if not previously raised, a claim can be precluded if it is sufficiently related to prior claims. 1.3 {{c9::Final judgment on the merits}} in original claim: there was a final judgment on the merits in the first action. A judgment is final even if it is being {{c10::appealed}}. A {{c11::dismissal with prejudice}} operates as a judgment on the merits. Technical dismissals (e.g., lack of subject matter jurisdiction, personal jurisdiction, or improper venue) are {{c12::not on the merits}} because they do not evaluate the substance of the plaintiff's claim.
cards.easyContent: Claim preclusion (res judicata) prevents a party who had a full opportunity to litigate from relitigating the same claim after a final judgment on the merits between the same parties. It is an affirmative defense.
cards.mediumContent: Claim preclusion (res judicata) bars a later lawsuit when: (1) the later suit is between the same parties or their privies; (2) it involves the same claim, defined as the same transaction or series of transactions giving rise to the action; and (3) the first case ended in a final judgment on the merits. A dismissal with prejudice counts as on the merits; technical dismissals for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, personal jurisdiction, or improper venue do not.
cards.hardContent: Claim preclusion (res judicata) is an affirmative defense that prevents a party who has had an opportunity to litigate a claim from relitigating that claim once final judgment has been rendered. It applies when three requirements are met: (1) same parties: the later case is between the same parties as the first case, or those in privity with them, such that, for example, an employee and employer may be treated as the same party; (2) same claim: the second suit involves the same claim, meaning it arises out of the same transaction or series of transactions or occurrences as the first case, and claims that could have been brought but were not may be barred if sufficiently related; and (3) final judgment on the merits: the first action ended in a final judgment on the merits, which remains final even if on appeal. A dismissal with prejudice operates as a judgment on the merits, whereas technical dismissals for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, personal jurisdiction, or improper venue are not on the merits because they do not address the substance of the plaintiff’s claim.
cards.mnemonic: P-C-J: same Parties, same Claim, prior Judgment on merits.
cards.clozeLite: Claim preclusion bars a later lawsuit when: {{c1::same parties or privies}}, {{c2::same claim (same transaction)}}, and {{c3::a prior final judgment on the merits}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 068. Issue Preclusion (Collateral Estoppel)
cards.backPlain: Issue preclusion (collateral estoppel) prevents relitigation of particular issues of fact or law that have been actually litigated and previously determined. It is narrower than claim preclusion; it does not necessarily preclude the whole claim, just the same issue. The issue must have been actually litigated, unlike claim preclusion, which only requires an opportunity to litigate. 1. Requirements: 1.1 Final judgment on the merits: the first case ended with a valid, final judgment on the merits. 1.2 Same issue: the same issue was actually litigated and determined in the first case. 1.3 Issue was essential to the judgment: the judgment would have been different in the first case absent litigation of this issue. It must be clear how the issue was decided by the original trier of fact. 1.4 Asserted against actual party to previous case: the party against whom issue preclusion is asserted was a party (or in privity with a party) in the prior case. 2. Who may assert issue preclusion: 2.1 Mutuality (traditional view): only parties to prior litigation can assert issue preclusion. 2.2 Non-mutuality (modern view): in many jurisdictions, issue preclusion may be asserted by those who were not parties in the prior litigation, subject to fairness limits (e.g., offensive vs. defensive use).
cards.frontPrompt: What is issue preclusion (collateral estoppel), what are its requirements, and who may assert it?
cards.cloze: Issue preclusion ({{c1::collateral estoppel}}) prevents relitigation of particular {{c2::issues of fact or law}} that have been {{c3::actually litigated}} and previously {{c4::determined}}. It is {{c5::narrower than claim preclusion}}; it does not necessarily preclude the whole claim, just the same issue. The issue must have been actually litigated, unlike claim preclusion, which only requires an {{c6::opportunity to litigate}}. 1. Requirements: 1.1 {{c7::Final judgment on the merits}}: the first case ended with a valid, final judgment on the merits. 1.2 {{c8::Same issue}}: the same issue was actually litigated and determined in the first case. 1.3 Issue was {{c9::essential to the judgment}}: the judgment would have been different in the first case absent litigation of this issue. It must be clear how the issue was decided by the original trier of fact. 1.4 Asserted against {{c10::actual party to previous case}}: the party against whom issue preclusion is asserted was a party (or in privity with a party) in the prior case. 2. Who may assert issue preclusion: 2.1 {{c11::Mutuality}} (traditional view): only parties to prior litigation can assert issue preclusion. 2.2 {{c12::Non-mutuality}} (modern view): in many jurisdictions, issue preclusion may be asserted by those who were not parties in the prior litigation, subject to fairness limits (e.g., offensive vs. defensive use).
cards.easyContent: Issue preclusion (collateral estoppel) bars relitigation of specific issues of fact or law that were actually litigated and necessarily decided in a prior case that ended in a final judgment on the merits against the same party.
cards.mediumContent: Issue preclusion, or collateral estoppel, prevents a party from relitigating an issue of fact or law that was actually litigated, determined, and essential to a valid, final judgment on the merits in a prior case. It can only be asserted against someone who was a party (or in privity) in the first case. Traditionally, only parties to the prior case could assert it (mutuality), but many modern courts allow non-mutual assertion, subject to fairness considerations.
cards.hardContent: Issue preclusion (collateral estoppel) bars relitigation of particular issues of fact or law that were actually litigated and previously determined. Unlike claim preclusion, which can bar entire claims based on an opportunity to litigate, issue preclusion is narrower and requires actual litigation and decision of the issue. Its requirements are: (1) a valid, final judgment on the merits in the first case; (2) the same issue was actually litigated and determined in that case; (3) the issue was essential to the judgment, such that the outcome would have been different absent that determination and the prior decision makes clear how the issue was resolved; and (4) the party against whom preclusion is asserted was a party or in privity with a party in the prior action. As to who may assert it, under the traditional mutuality rule only parties to the prior litigation could invoke issue preclusion, whereas many modern jurisdictions allow non-mutual issue preclusion, permitting a non-party to the first suit to assert preclusion, subject to fairness limits and distinctions between offensive and defensive use.
cards.mnemonic: F-S-E-P: Final judgment, Same issue, Essential, same Party.
cards.clozeLite: Issue preclusion {{c1::prevents relitigation of an issue}} that was {{c2::actually litigated}}, {{c3::determined}}, and {{c4::essential to a valid, final judgment}} against a {{c5::party or privy}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 069. Issue Preclusion
cards.backPlain: Offensive and defensive use of prior judgment: non-mutual issue preclusion may be used defensively or offensively, although courts are reluctant to allow offensive use. 1. Defensive use of prior judgment: 1.1 The defendant seeks to prevent the plaintiff from relitigating an issue the plaintiff lost in a prior suit against a different party. 1.2 Defensive non-mutual issue preclusion is allowed if the party against whom issue preclusion is asserted had a full and fair opportunity to litigate the issue previously. 1.3 Example: a defendant in a second case can preclude the plaintiff from relitigating an issue the plaintiff lost to another defendant in a prior case; this is permitted because the party asserting issue preclusion was not a party in the prior litigation. 2. Offensive use of prior judgment: 2.1 The plaintiff seeks to prevent the defendant from relitigating an issue that the defendant previously lost in a prior suit against a different party. 2.2 Offensive non-mutual issue preclusion is highly disfavored and rarely allowed. 2.3 The court will allow offensive use only if deemed fair after balancing factors. 2.4 Factors considered include: 2.4.1 Whether the party against whom the prior judgment is asserted had a full and fair opportunity to litigate. 2.4.2 Whether that party could foresee multiple suits being filed. 2.4.3 Whether the party asserting issue preclusion controlled or could have joined the prior litigation. 2.4.4 Whether there are any inconsistent judgments on the record.
cards.frontPrompt: How can non-mutual issue preclusion be used defensively and offensively, and what factors govern whether offensive use is allowed?
cards.cloze: Offensive and defensive use of prior judgment: {{c1::non-mutual issue preclusion}} may be used {{c2::defensively}} or {{c3::offensively}}, although courts are reluctant to allow offensive use. 1. {{c4::Defensive}} use of prior judgment: 1.1 The {{c5::defendant}} seeks to prevent the {{c6::plaintiff}} from relitigating an issue the plaintiff lost in a prior suit against a different party. 1.2 Defensive non-mutual issue preclusion is allowed if the party against whom issue preclusion is asserted had a {{c7::full and fair opportunity}} to litigate the issue previously. 1.3 Example: a defendant in a second case can preclude the plaintiff from relitigating an issue the plaintiff lost to another defendant in a prior case; this is permitted because the party asserting issue preclusion was not a party in the prior litigation. 2. {{c8::Offensive}} use of prior judgment: 2.1 The {{c9::plaintiff}} seeks to prevent the {{c10::defendant}} from relitigating an issue that the defendant previously lost in a prior suit against a different party. 2.2 Offensive non-mutual issue preclusion is {{c11::highly disfavored}} and rarely allowed. 2.3 The court will allow offensive use only if deemed {{c12::fair}} after balancing factors. 2.4 Factors considered include: 2.4.1 Whether the party against whom the prior judgment is asserted had a {{c13::full and fair opportunity}} to litigate. 2.4.2 Whether that party could {{c14::foresee multiple suits}} being filed. 2.4.3 Whether the party asserting issue preclusion {{c15::controlled or could have joined}} the prior litigation. 2.4.4 Whether there are any {{c16::inconsistent judgments}} on the record.
cards.easyContent: Non-mutual issue preclusion can be used defensively by a new defendant to stop a plaintiff from relitigating an issue the plaintiff already lost, and can sometimes be used offensively by a new plaintiff against a defendant who previously lost that issue, though offensive use is disfavored and allowed only when fair.
cards.mediumContent: Defensive non-mutual issue preclusion occurs when a new defendant invokes a prior judgment to prevent a plaintiff from relitigating an issue the plaintiff lost in earlier litigation; it is generally allowed if the plaintiff previously had a full and fair opportunity to litigate. Offensive non-mutual issue preclusion occurs when a new plaintiff seeks to prevent a defendant from relitigating an issue the defendant lost earlier; courts are reluctant to permit it and will consider factors such as whether the defendant had a full and fair opportunity to litigate, could foresee multiple suits, whether the new plaintiff controlled or could have joined the prior case, and whether there are inconsistent prior judgments.
cards.hardContent: Non-mutual issue preclusion allows someone who was not a party to the prior case to use a prior judgment either defensively or offensively. Defensive non-mutual issue preclusion is when a new defendant seeks to bar a plaintiff from relitigating an issue the plaintiff previously lost against a different defendant; it is generally permitted if the plaintiff had a full and fair opportunity to litigate the issue before. Offensive non-mutual issue preclusion is when a new plaintiff seeks to prevent a defendant from relitigating an issue the defendant lost in an earlier suit against a different plaintiff. Offensive use is highly disfavored and rarely allowed; courts apply a fairness test, considering whether the defendant had a full and fair opportunity to litigate previously, whether the defendant could reasonably foresee multiple suits arising from the same conduct, whether the new plaintiff controlled or could have joined the earlier action, and whether prior judgments on the issue are inconsistent.
cards.mnemonic: D = Defendant uses it; O = "Oh no" unless fair.
cards.clozeLite: Defensive non-mutual issue preclusion lets a {{c1::new defendant}} stop a {{c2::plaintiff}} from relitigating an issue lost earlier; offensive use by a {{c3::new plaintiff}} is {{c4::disfavored}} and allowed only when {{c5::fairness factors}} are satisfied.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 007-1. PJ Fairness – Due Process Standard
cards.backPlain: Even if the defendant has sufficient minimum contacts with the forum, due process imposes an additional fairness requirement on the exercise of personal jurisdiction. • Standard: The exercise of personal jurisdiction must be fair and must not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice. • Framework: Courts apply this fairness requirement by weighing three main factors: 1. Relatedness of the contacts and the claim. 2. Convenience to the defendant. 3. The forum state’s interest in hearing the case. All three factors are balanced together to decide whether asserting personal jurisdiction comports with due process.
cards.frontPrompt: How does due process limit personal jurisdiction through a fairness requirement, and what are the main categories of factors courts consider?
cards.cloze: Even if the defendant has sufficient {{c1::minimum contacts}} with the forum, due process imposes an additional {{c2::fairness}} requirement on the exercise of personal jurisdiction. • Standard: The exercise of personal jurisdiction must be {{c3::fair}} and must not offend {{c4::traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice}}. • Framework: Courts apply this fairness requirement by weighing three main factors: {{c5::(1) relatedness of the contacts and the claim, (2) convenience to the defendant, and (3) the forum state's interest in hearing the case}}. All three factors are {{c6::balanced together}} to decide whether asserting personal jurisdiction comports with due process.
cards.easyContent: Beyond minimum contacts, due process requires that exercising personal jurisdiction be fair and not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice, assessed by relatedness, convenience, and the forum’s interest.
cards.mediumContent: Even with minimum contacts, a court must still ask whether exercising personal jurisdiction is fair under due process. The exercise of jurisdiction cannot offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice. Courts balance three categories of factors: relatedness of contacts and claim, convenience to the defendant, and the forum state’s interest.
cards.hardContent: Due process has a separate fairness component that limits personal jurisdiction even where minimum contacts exist. The constitutional standard is that the exercise of personal jurisdiction must be fair and must not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice. Courts implement this standard through a balancing test that examines three main factors: (1) the relatedness between the defendant’s forum contacts and the plaintiff’s claim; (2) whether litigating in the forum would be so inconvenient as to severely disadvantage the defendant; and (3) whether the forum state has a substantial interest in providing a forum for the dispute. The combined weight of these factors determines whether jurisdiction is consistent with due process.
cards.mnemonic: Fairness FRC: Fairness, Relatedness, Convenience, forum’s interest.
cards.clozeLite: Even with {{c1::minimum contacts}}, PJ must be {{c2::fair}} and not offend {{c3::traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice}}, using {{c4::three fairness factors}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: PJ Fairness – Relatedness, Specific & General Jurisdiction
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 007-2. PJ Fairness – Relatedness, Specific & General Jurisdiction
cards.front: PJ Fairness – Relatedness, Specific & General Jurisdiction
cards.backPlain: Fairness in personal jurisdiction first looks at the relatedness between the defendant’s contacts with the forum and the plaintiff’s claim. 1. Relatedness of contacts and claim • Question: Does the plaintiff’s claim arise from or relate to the defendant’s contacts with the forum state? 2. Specific jurisdiction • Definition: Specific jurisdiction exists when the plaintiff’s claim arises from or relates to the defendant’s in-state contacts. • Minimum contacts: Only minimum contacts with the forum need to be established. • Scope: The defendant can only be sued in that forum for claims arising from those in-state contacts. 3. General jurisdiction • Definition: General jurisdiction is appropriate when the plaintiff’s claim does not arise from the defendant’s in-state contacts, but the defendant’s overall contacts with the forum are so substantial that it is essentially at home there. • Contacts: The defendant must have systematic and continuous contacts with the forum state. • "At home" examples (for a corporation): The place of incorporation or the principal place of business in the forum state. • Scope: If general jurisdiction is found, the defendant can be sued in that forum for any claim, whether arising in or outside of the forum.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the relatedness factor in the fairness analysis distinguish specific from general personal jurisdiction, and what are the requirements and consequences of each?
cards.cloze: Fairness in personal jurisdiction first looks at the {{c1::relatedness}} between the defendant’s contacts with the forum and the plaintiff’s claim. 1.
