Relatedness of contacts and claim • Question: Does the plaintiff’s claim {{c2::arise from or relate to}} the defendant’s contacts with the forum state? 2. {{c3::Specific jurisdiction}} • Definition: Exists when the plaintiff’s claim {{c4::arises from or relates to the defendant’s in-state contacts}}. • Minimum contacts: Only {{c5::minimum contacts}} with the forum need to be established. • Scope: The defendant can only be sued in that forum for claims {{c6::arising from those in-state contacts}}. 3. {{c7::General jurisdiction}} • Definition: Appropriate when the plaintiff’s claim {{c8::does not arise from the defendant’s in-state contacts}}, but the defendant’s contacts with the forum are so substantial that it is {{c9::essentially at home}} there. • Contacts: The defendant must have {{c10::systematic and continuous}} contacts with the forum state. • "At home" examples (for a corporation): The {{c11::place of incorporation}} or the {{c12::principal place of business}} in the forum state. • Scope: If general jurisdiction is found, the defendant can be sued in that forum for {{c13::any claim, whether arising in or outside of the forum}}.
cards.easyContent: The relatedness factor asks whether the claim arises from the defendant’s forum contacts. If it does, specific jurisdiction applies: only minimum contacts are needed and suits are limited to those contacts. If it does not, general jurisdiction may apply if the defendant’s contacts are so systematic and continuous that it is essentially at home, allowing any claim.
cards.mediumContent: Relatedness frames whether a court is exercising specific or general jurisdiction. Specific jurisdiction exists when the plaintiff’s claim arises from or relates to the defendant’s forum contacts; only minimum contacts are required and suits are limited to those contacts. General jurisdiction applies when the claim does not arise from the forum contacts, but the defendant’s systematic and continuous contacts make it essentially at home (typically place of incorporation or principal place of business), permitting suit on any claim.
cards.hardContent: Within the fairness analysis for personal jurisdiction, courts consider whether the plaintiff’s claim arises from or is related to the defendant’s contacts with the forum. If the claim arises from or relates to those in-state contacts, the court is considering specific jurisdiction: only minimum contacts need to be established, and the defendant may be sued in that forum only for claims tied to those contacts. If the claim does not arise from in-state contacts, the court looks to general jurisdiction: this exists only where the defendant’s contacts are so systematic and continuous that it is essentially at home in the forum, such as a corporation’s place of incorporation or principal place of business. When general jurisdiction is present, the defendant may be sued in that forum for any claim, regardless of where it arose.
cards.mnemonic: RS-GE: Relatedness Splits—Specific = arises; General = essentially home.
cards.clozeLite: Relatedness distinguishes {{c1::specific}} from {{c2::general}} jurisdiction: specific needs a claim {{c3::arising from or relating to forum contacts}}; general requires defendant {{c4::essentially at home}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 007-3. PJ Fairness – Convenience Factor
cards.backPlain: As part of the fairness inquiry in personal jurisdiction, courts consider whether the chosen forum is convenient or would severely disadvantage the defendant. Convenience factor • Core question: Would jurisdiction in the forum severely disadvantage the defendant? • Relevant considerations: – Distance to the courthouse and travel burden. – The defendant’s inability to travel (e.g., health, financial constraints). – The defendant’s lack of familiarity with the court system. • Severity requirement: Inconvenience must be so great that the defendant is inherently placed at a severe disadvantage compared to the plaintiff. Ordinary inconvenience of litigation is not enough to defeat jurisdiction.
cards.frontPrompt: In the fairness analysis for personal jurisdiction, how do courts evaluate the convenience factor, and how severe must the burden on the defendant be to matter?
cards.cloze: As part of the fairness inquiry in personal jurisdiction, courts consider whether the chosen forum is convenient or would {{c1::severely disadvantage}} the defendant. Convenience factor • Core question: Would jurisdiction in the forum {{c2::severely disadvantage the defendant}}? • Relevant considerations: – {{c3::Distance}} to the courthouse and travel burden. – The defendant’s {{c4::inability to travel}} (e.g., health, financial constraints). – The defendant’s {{c5::lack of familiarity with the court system}}. • Severity requirement: Inconvenience must be so great that the defendant is inherently placed at a {{c6::severe disadvantage compared to the plaintiff}}. {{c7::Ordinary inconvenience}} of litigation is not enough to defeat jurisdiction.
cards.easyContent: The convenience factor asks whether litigating in the forum would severely disadvantage the defendant. The burden must be extreme; ordinary inconvenience is not enough to defeat personal jurisdiction.
cards.mediumContent: For fairness, courts consider whether the forum is so inconvenient that it would severely disadvantage the defendant. They look to distance, the defendant’s ability to travel, and familiarity with the court system. Only extreme inconvenience that puts the defendant at a severe disadvantage relative to the plaintiff weighs strongly against jurisdiction.
cards.hardContent: The convenience factor in the fairness analysis examines whether requiring the defendant to litigate in the forum would be so burdensome as to be fundamentally unfair. Courts assess the distance to the forum, the practical travel burden, and the defendant’s ability to appear in person (including health and financial constraints), as well as the defendant’s familiarity with or access to the court system. The standard is high: the inconvenience must be so substantial that the defendant is placed at a severe disadvantage compared to the plaintiff. Mere ordinary inconvenience or expense of litigation in a distant forum is insufficient to defeat personal jurisdiction.
cards.mnemonic: CONVENIENCE counts only for CRUSHING burden, not common hassle.
cards.clozeLite: Convenience matters only if the forum is {{c1::so inconvenient it severely disadvantages the defendant}}; {{c2::ordinary inconvenience isn’t enough}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 007-4. PJ Fairness – Forum State’s Interest
cards.backPlain: In assessing fairness of personal jurisdiction, courts also consider the forum state’s interest in hearing the case. State’s interest factor • Core question: Does the forum state have a legitimate interest in allocating its limited judicial resources to hearing this matter? • Bases for strong state interest may include: – Protecting its residents or providing them with a convenient forum. – Regulating conduct that affects the state. – Enforcing its laws or policies. • Weaker state interest: The forum state’s interest is less compelling when: – The case involves nonresident actors. – The relevant acts occurred outside the forum (nonresident acts). – The case involves significant complexity that burdens the forum’s limited resources without a strong local connection.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the forum state’s interest factor into the fairness analysis for personal jurisdiction, and when is that interest weaker?
cards.cloze: In assessing fairness of personal jurisdiction, courts also consider the {{c1::forum state's interest}} in hearing the case. State’s interest factor • Core question: Does the forum state have an {{c2::interest in allocating its limited judicial resources}} to hearing this matter? • Weaker state interest: The forum state’s interest is less compelling when: – The case involves {{c3::nonresident actors}}. – The relevant acts are {{c4::nonresident acts}} (occurred outside the forum). – The case involves {{c5::significant complexity}} that burdens the forum’s resources without a strong local connection.
cards.easyContent: Courts weigh the forum state’s interest in providing a forum and using its limited resources. This interest is weaker when the parties and acts are nonresident and the case is complex with little local connection.
cards.mediumContent: The forum state’s interest is part of the PJ fairness analysis. Courts ask whether the state has a legitimate reason to expend its limited judicial resources, such as protecting residents or enforcing its laws. The interest is weaker when the dispute involves nonresident actors, out-of-state conduct, or highly complex litigation with little connection to the forum.
cards.hardContent: As part of the fairness inquiry, courts evaluate the forum state’s institutional and policy interests in adjudicating the dispute. A strong interest may exist when the state is protecting its residents, regulating conduct that affects it, or enforcing its substantive policies. Conversely, the state’s interest is diminished where the litigation concerns nonresident parties, conduct that occurred outside the state, or highly complex matters that would significantly burden the court system without a substantial local connection. A weak state interest weighs against the fairness of exercising personal jurisdiction.
cards.mnemonic: STATE: Safeguard locals, Apply laws, Tiny interest Elsewhere.
cards.clozeLite: In PJ {{c1::fairness}} analysis, courts weigh the forum state’s {{c2::interest in protecting residents and enforcing its laws}}, which is weaker for {{c3::nonresident parties and out-of-state conduct}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Venue Transfer – Basic Rule & Proper-Venue Transfers
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 020-1. Venue Transfer – Basic Rule & Proper-Venue Transfers
cards.front: Venue Transfer – Basic Rule & Proper-Venue Transfers
cards.frontPrompt: Under federal law, when venue is proper in the original district, when and how may a civil case be transferred to another federal district, and what factors guide the court’s discretion?
cards.backPlain: Basic rule and authority - Federal law governs transfer of venue in civil cases. - A case may be transferred from one federal district to another federal district: - To a district in which the case could have been filed originally (proper subject-matter jurisdiction, personal jurisdiction, and venue); or - To any district to which all parties consent. - Any party may move to transfer venue, but the court may refuse if the original venue is proper. Proper venue in the original district - If venue in the original district is proper, the court may order transfer in its discretion based on: 1. The interest of justice; and 2. The convenience of parties and witnesses. Public and private factors - In exercising its discretion, the court considers: - Public factors: - What law applies; - Which community should be burdened with jury service; and - Other systemic interests (e.g., court congestion, local interest in the controversy). - Private factors: - Convenience of the parties and witnesses; - Location of evidence and witnesses; and - Practical considerations that make trial easy, expeditious, and inexpensive.
cards.cloze: Federal law governs {{c1::transfer of venue}} in civil cases. A case may be transferred from one federal district to another federal district either to a district {{c2::where the case could have been filed originally}} or to a district {{c3::to which all parties consent}}. Any party may move for transfer, but the court may refuse if the original venue is {{c4::proper}}. When venue in the original district is proper, the court may order transfer in its {{c5::discretion}} based on the {{c6::interest of justice}} and the {{c7::convenience of parties and witnesses}}. In applying this standard, the court considers both {{c8::public factors}} (such as what law applies, which community should bear jury service, and systemic interests) and {{c9::private factors}} (including convenience of the parties and witnesses and the location of evidence and witnesses).
cards.easyContent: Federal law governs transfer. A case can be moved to another district where it could have been filed or to which all parties consent. If venue is proper in the original court, transfer is discretionary and depends on the interest of justice and convenience, judged using public and private factors.
cards.mediumContent: Transfer of venue in federal court is governed by federal law and permits moving a case to another federal district where it could have been brought or to which all parties consent. If the original venue is proper, the court has discretion to transfer based on the interest of justice and the convenience of parties and witnesses. The court weighs public factors (e.g., applicable law, local interest, which community should serve as jurors, court congestion) and private factors (e.g., convenience of parties and witnesses, location of evidence, practical trial considerations).
cards.hardContent: Federal law controls transfer of venue. A civil case may be transferred from one federal district to another federal district that is a district where the case could have been filed originally—that is, a district with proper subject-matter jurisdiction, personal jurisdiction over defendants, and venue—or to a district to which all parties consent. Any party may move to transfer, but if the original venue is proper, the court may deny the motion. When venue in the original district is proper, transfer is discretionary and depends on the interest of justice and the convenience of parties and witnesses. In deciding whether to transfer, courts weigh public factors (which law applies, which community should be burdened with jury service, local interest in the dispute, systemic efficiency, docket congestion) and private factors (relative convenience of parties and witnesses, locations of documents and physical evidence, and practical considerations that make trial easy, expeditious, and inexpensive).
cards.mnemonic: Proper transfer: I.C.E. – Interest, Convenience, evaluated by public/private factors.
cards.clozeLite: If {{c1::venue is proper}}, a federal case may be {{c2::transferred}} to a district {{c3::where it could have been brought or all parties consent}}, based on {{c4::interest of justice}} and {{c5::convenience}} using {{c6::public and private factors}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Venue Transfer – Improper Venue: Transfer vs. Dismissal
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 020-2. Venue Transfer – Improper Venue: Transfer vs. Dismissal
cards.front: Venue Transfer – Improper Venue: Transfer vs. Dismissal
cards.frontPrompt: If a federal civil case is filed in a district with improper venue, what options does the court have, and what standard governs transfer?
cards.backPlain: Improper venue in the original district - If venue in the original district is improper, the court has two basic options: 1. Transfer the case to a proper federal district; or 2. Dismiss the case. Transfer standard - When venue is improper, the court may transfer the case "in the interest of justice." - Transfer is often preferred over dismissal to avoid penalizing the plaintiff for a reasonable mistake and to preserve claims that might otherwise be time-barred. Effect of improper venue on transfer - The case must be transferred to a federal district where it could have been brought (proper subject-matter jurisdiction, personal jurisdiction, and venue) or, in some circumstances, to a district to which all parties consent. - The usual discretionary factors (convenience and the interest of justice) still guide the decision whether to transfer rather than dismiss.
cards.cloze: If venue in the original district is {{c1::improper}}, the court may either {{c2::transfer the case in the interest of justice}} or {{c3::dismiss the case}}. When venue is improper, transfer is often favored to serve the {{c4::interest of justice}}, especially where dismissal might bar the claims (for example, by limitations). The case must be transferred to a federal district where it {{c5::could have been brought}} or, in appropriate circumstances, to a district to which {{c6::all parties consent}}.
cards.easyContent: If venue is improper, the court can either transfer the case to a proper district in the interest of justice or dismiss it. Transfer is usually preferred to avoid unfairly barring the claim.
cards.mediumContent: When a federal civil action is filed in a district with improper venue, the court may either dismiss the case or transfer it to a district where it could have been brought. Transfer is allowed and often favored when it is in the interest of justice, especially if dismissal could time-bar the claims. The transferee court must be a federal district that is proper for the case or one to which all parties consent.
cards.hardContent: If venue in the original federal district is improper, the court has two primary options: (1) dismiss the case; or (2) transfer it to a federal district where the case could have been brought, in the interest of justice. The "interest of justice" standard generally favors transfer over dismissal when plaintiffs made a reasonable mistake or where dismissal risks barring the claim due to statutes of limitation. The transferee court must be a federal district with proper subject-matter jurisdiction, personal jurisdiction, and venue, or a district to which all parties consent. While the court still enjoys discretion, the presence of improper venue shifts the analysis toward curing the defect by transfer rather than simply denying a transfer request.
cards.mnemonic: Improper venue? T&D: Transfer or Dismiss in justice.
cards.clozeLite: If {{c1::venue is improper}}, a federal court may {{c2::dismiss}} or {{c3::transfer}} the case {{c4::in the interest of justice}} to a district {{c5::where it could have been brought or all consent}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 020-3. Venue Transfer – Choice-of-Law Consequences
cards.frontPrompt: After a federal civil case is transferred to another district, whose choice-of-law rules does the transferee court apply, and how does it depend on whether the original venue was proper or improper?
cards.backPlain: General rule after transfer - After transfer of a federal civil case, the transferee court must decide which jurisdiction’s choice-of-law rules to apply. Proper original venue - If venue in the original (transferor) court was proper: - The transferee court applies the choice-of-law rules of the original court (the transferor forum), regardless of which party sought the transfer. - This prevents a party from gaining a change in applicable law simply by obtaining transfer. Improper original venue – exception - Exception: If the original venue was improper: - The transferee court applies its own choice-of-law rules, not those of the original court. - Because the original venue was improper, there is no interest in preserving the choice-of-law approach of the original forum.
cards.cloze: After transfer, the {{c1::transferee court}} must decide which {{c2::choice-of-law rules}} to apply. If venue in the original district was {{c3::proper}}, the transferee court applies the {{c4::choice-of-law rules of the original (transferor) court}}, regardless of which party sought the transfer. This prevents a party from obtaining more favorable substantive law simply by transferring the case. Exception: If the original venue was {{c5::improper}}, the transferee court applies {{c6::its own choice-of-law rules}}, rather than those of the original court.
cards.easyContent: After transfer, if the original venue was proper, the new court applies the old court’s choice-of-law rules. If the original venue was improper, the new court applies its own choice-of-law rules.
cards.mediumContent: When a federal case is transferred from one district to another, the transferee court usually applies the transferor court’s choice-of-law rules, as long as the original venue was proper. This rule applies regardless of which party sought transfer and prevents forum shopping for more favorable law. If, however, the original venue was improper, the transferee court instead applies its own choice-of-law rules.
cards.hardContent: Following transfer of a civil case between federal district courts, the transferee court must determine which jurisdiction’s choice-of-law rules govern. Under the general rule, when the original venue was proper, the transferee court is required to apply the choice-of-law rules of the transferor court, regardless of whether the plaintiff or the defendant requested transfer. This maintains the substantive-law baseline that would have applied had the case remained in the original, proper forum and prevents parties from exploiting transfer to alter applicable law. However, when the original venue was improper, this rule does not apply. In that situation, the transferee court applies its own choice-of-law rules. Because the original district was not a proper venue, there is no interest in preserving its choice-of-law regime, and the transferee forum’s rules govern.
cards.mnemonic: P→T, I→O: Proper→Transferor rules; Improper→Own rules.
cards.clozeLite: If venue was {{c1::proper}}, transferee uses {{c2::transferor court’s choice-of-law rules}}; if venue was {{c3::improper}}, transferee uses {{c4::its own choice-of-law rules}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 020-4. Venue Transfer – Forum-Selection Clauses
cards.frontPrompt: How do valid forum-selection clauses specifying a federal district affect transfer of venue, and what limits does the court consider?
cards.backPlain: Forum-selection clauses and transfer - A forum-selection clause is a contractual provision in which the parties agree to litigate disputes in a specified forum. - When the clause specifies a federal district as the chosen forum, and the clause is valid, federal courts strongly favor enforcing it through transfer. Effect on transfer - If there is a valid forum-selection clause specifying a federal district: - The case must ordinarily be transferred to the indicated federal district. - The forum-selection clause is given controlling weight in all but the most exceptional cases. Limits – public-interest factors - The court may refuse to transfer only if public-interest factors present a compelling reason not to honor the clause. - Relevant public-interest factors include: - Court congestion and administrative difficulties; - The local interest in having localized controversies decided at home; - The familiarity of the forum with the governing law; and - Avoidance of unnecessary problems in conflict of laws or in application of foreign law. - Private convenience factors (e.g., the plaintiff’s choice of forum, convenience of witnesses) generally carry less weight when a valid forum-selection clause exists.
cards.cloze: A {{c1::forum-selection clause}} is a contractual provision selecting a forum for disputes. When a {{c2::valid}} forum-selection clause specifies a {{c3::federal district}} as the chosen forum, federal courts ordinarily {{c4::transfer the case to that district}}. The clause is given {{c5::controlling weight}} in all but the most exceptional cases. The court may refuse to transfer only if {{c6::public-interest factors}} present a {{c7::compelling reason}} not to enforce the clause. Relevant public-interest factors include court congestion, local interest in the dispute, the forum’s familiarity with the governing law, and avoiding unnecessary conflict-of-laws or foreign-law problems. Private convenience factors generally carry reduced weight when a valid forum-selection clause exists.
cards.easyContent: If the parties have a valid forum-selection clause choosing a particular federal district, the case will almost always be transferred there. Only compelling public-interest factors can justify refusing to follow the clause.
cards.mediumContent: Valid forum-selection clauses that name a specific federal district are ordinarily enforced through transfer. Courts treat the clause as controlling and will transfer the case to the selected federal district unless powerful public-interest factors—such as local interest, docket concerns, or conflict-of-law problems—make enforcement unreasonable. Private convenience factors are largely discounted when a valid clause exists.
cards.hardContent: Forum-selection clauses provide that disputes between the parties will be litigated in a specific forum. When such a clause designates a federal district, and the clause is valid, federal courts strongly favor enforcing it by transferring the case to the named district. In practice, a valid clause is given controlling weight in all but the most exceptional cases, and the case must ordinarily be transferred to the agreed federal district. A court may decline to enforce the clause through transfer only when public-interest factors present a compelling reason not to do so. These factors include court congestion and administrative difficulties, the local interest in having localized controversies decided at home, the forum’s familiarity with the governing substantive law, and the need to avoid unnecessary conflict-of-laws or foreign-law complications. By contrast, private convenience factors—such as the plaintiff’s choice of forum or the convenience of witnesses—are usually given reduced weight because the parties already contracted for a particular federal forum.
cards.mnemonic: FS clause: "Follow the Selection" unless strong public interests say no.
cards.clozeLite: A valid {{c1::forum-selection clause}} naming a {{c2::specific federal district}} is {{c3::ordinarily enforced through transfer}}, unless {{c4::powerful public-interest factors}} make enforcement unreasonable.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 029-1. Answer – Definition, Purpose, and Timing
cards.frontPrompt: In federal civil procedure, what is an answer, what does it do, and when must it be filed?
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition and purpose of the answer 1.1 The answer is the defendant's response to the complaint. 1.2 In the answer, the defendant states defenses to each claim asserted and admits or denies each count of the plaintiff's complaint. 1.3 Defenses can be pleaded in the alternative. For example, in a breach of contract case, the defendant may deny that a contract existed but also assert that, if it did exist, the defendant performed. 2. Timing of the answer 2.1 The answer must be filed within 21 days after service of process. 2.2 If the defendant first files a Rule 12 motion, the answer is due within 14 days after the court rules on that motion.
cards.cloze: 1. Definition and purpose of the answer 1.1 The {{c1::answer}} is the {{c2::defendant's response}} to the complaint. 1.2 In the answer, the defendant {{c3::states defenses to each claim asserted}} and {{c4::admits or denies each count}} of the plaintiff's complaint. 1.3 Defenses can be {{c5::pleaded in the alternative}} (e.g., deny a contract existed but also assert performance if it did). 2. Timing of the answer 2.1 The answer must be filed within {{c6::21 days}} after {{c7::service of process}}. 2.2 If the defendant files a {{c8::Rule 12 motion}} first, the answer is due within {{c9::14 days}} after the court {{c10::rules on that motion}}.
cards.easyContent: The answer is the defendant’s responsive pleading that states defenses and admits or denies the plaintiff’s allegations. It’s generally due 21 days after service of process, or 14 days after a ruling on a Rule 12 motion.
cards.mediumContent: The answer is the defendant’s formal response to the complaint. In it, the defendant states defenses to each claim and admits or denies each count, and may plead defenses in the alternative (e.g., deny a contract but also claim performance if one existed). The answer must be filed within 21 days after service of process, or within 14 days after the court rules on a Rule 12 motion.
cards.hardContent: In federal civil procedure, the answer is the defendant’s responsive pleading to the complaint. It serves to frame the issues for litigation by stating defenses to each claim and admitting or denying each count of the plaintiff’s complaint. The defendant may plead defenses in the alternative, such as denying contract formation while also asserting full performance if a contract is found. The timing is strict: the defendant must file the answer within 21 days after service of process, or, if she first files a Rule 12 motion, within 14 days after the court rules on that motion.
cards.mnemonic: Answer timing: 21 after service, 14 after 12(b) ruling.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::answer}} is the defendant’s {{c2::responsive pleading}} admitting or denying allegations, due {{c3::21 days after service}} or {{c4::14 days after a Rule 12 ruling}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Answer – Responses to Allegations and Effect of Failing to Deny
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 029-2. Answer – Responses to Allegations and Effect of Failing to Deny
cards.frontPrompt: In an answer, what specific responses may a defendant make to the complaint’s allegations, and what is the effect of failing to deny an allegation?
cards.backPlain: 1. Required responses to allegations in the complaint 1.1 For each allegation in the complaint, the defendant must respond in the answer. 2. Available types of responses 2.1 Admit the allegation. 2.2 Deny the allegation. 2.2.1 Failure to deny an allegation (other than as to damages) can operate as an admission. 2.3 State that the defendant lacks sufficient information to admit or deny the allegation. 3. Practical effect 3.1 Issues admitted by failure to deny are treated as established, except that allegations relating solely to damages are not deemed admitted by silence.
cards.cloze: 1. Required responses to allegations 1.1 For each allegation, the defendant must respond in the answer. 2. Available types of responses 2.1 {{c1::Admit}} the allegation. 2.2 {{c2::Deny}} the allegation. 2.2.1 Failure to deny an allegation (other than as to {{c3::damages}}) can operate as an {{c4::admission}}. 2.3 State {{c5::lack of sufficient information}} to admit or deny the allegation. 3. Practical effect 3.1 Allegations not denied are generally {{c6::treated as admitted}}, except those relating solely to {{c7::damages}}.
cards.easyContent: In the answer, the defendant must respond to each allegation by admitting it, denying it, or stating lack of sufficient information. Failing to deny an allegation (other than damages) acts as an admission.
cards.mediumContent: The defendant’s answer must address each allegation in the complaint. For each allegation, the defendant may: (1) admit it, (2) deny it, or (3) state that she lacks sufficient information to admit or deny. If the defendant fails to deny an allegation (other than one relating solely to damages), that allegation is treated as admitted.
cards.hardContent: Federal pleading rules require that the defendant’s answer respond to each allegation in the complaint. The defendant has three basic options: admit the allegation, deny the allegation, or state that she lacks sufficient information to admit or deny (which has the effect of a denial if done in good faith). A critical consequence is that any allegation not specifically denied—except those relating solely to the amount of damages—can operate as an admission and will be treated as established for purposes of the litigation.
cards.mnemonic: Three responses: Admit, Deny, Don’t know; silence admits (not damages).
cards.clozeLite: In an answer, each allegation must be {{c1::admitted}}, {{c2::denied}}, or met with {{c3::lack of sufficient information}}; {{c4::failure to deny}} (except {{c5::damages}}) is an admission.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 029-3. Answer – Affirmative Defenses and Waiver
cards.frontPrompt: What must a defendant do in the answer to properly raise affirmative defenses, and what are some common examples and the consequence of failing to plead them?
cards.backPlain: 1. Requirement to plead affirmative defenses 1.1 Certain defenses are waived if not explicitly pleaded in the answer. 1.2 The defendant should set out these defenses as affirmative defenses in the answer. 2. Common affirmative defenses 2.1 Contributory negligence. 2.2 Claim preclusion (res judicata). 2.3 Statute of frauds. 2.4 Fraud. 2.5 Statute of limitations. 2.6 Self-defense. 3. Waiver 3.1 Affirmative defenses are typically waived if not pleaded in the answer. 3.2 Failure to plead them may bar the defendant from raising them later, absent leave to amend or other exceptional circumstances.
cards.cloze: 1. Requirement to plead affirmative defenses 1.1 Certain defenses are {{c1::waived if not explicitly pleaded}} in the answer. 1.2 These must be set out as {{c2::affirmative defenses}} in the answer. 2. Common affirmative defenses 2.1 {{c3::Contributory negligence}}. 2.2 {{c4::Claim preclusion (res judicata)}}. 2.3 {{c5::Statute of frauds}}. 2.4 {{c6::Fraud}}. 2.5 {{c7::Statute of limitations}}. 2.6 {{c8::Self-defense}}. 3. Waiver 3.1 Affirmative defenses are typically {{c9::waived}} if not {{c10::pleaded in the answer}}.
cards.easyContent: Certain defenses—like contributory negligence, claim preclusion, statute of frauds, fraud, statute of limitations, and self-defense—must be raised as affirmative defenses in the answer or they’re generally waived.
cards.mediumContent: Affirmative defenses must be expressly raised in the defendant’s answer. Common examples include contributory negligence, claim preclusion (res judicata), statute of frauds, fraud, statute of limitations, and self-defense. If the defendant fails to plead these defenses in the answer, they are typically deemed waived unless the court permits amendment.
cards.hardContent: The rules require defendants to affirmatively plead certain defenses in the answer, rather than simply denying the plaintiff’s allegations. These affirmative defenses include, among others, contributory negligence, claim preclusion (res judicata), statute of frauds, fraud, statute of limitations, and self-defense. Because these defenses introduce new matters that can defeat or limit liability even if the complaint is true, they must be explicitly set out in the answer. Failure to do so generally results in waiver of the defense, meaning the defendant cannot rely on it later unless she obtains leave to amend or fits within a recognized exception.
cards.mnemonic: Answer AFFIRMATIVELY: C-FLSSJ (Contrib, Fraud, Limit, SoF, Self-defense, Judicata).
cards.clozeLite: Affirmative defenses must be {{c1::expressly raised in the answer}}; common ones include {{c2::contributory negligence}}, {{c3::claim preclusion}}, {{c4::statute of frauds}}, and {{c5::statute of limitations}} or they’re {{c6::waived}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 029-4. Answer – Counterclaims (Compulsory vs. Permissive)
cards.frontPrompt: How are counterclaims asserted in the answer in federal civil procedure, and what is the distinction between compulsory and permissive counterclaims?
cards.backPlain: 1. Counterclaims in the answer 1.1 The defendant's claims against the plaintiff may be asserted in the answer as counterclaims. 2. Types of counterclaims 2.1 Compulsory counterclaims 2.1.1 A compulsory counterclaim arises out of the same transaction or occurrence as the plaintiff's claim. 2.1.2 It must generally be brought in the same action or it is barred. 2.2 Permissive counterclaims 2.2.1 A permissive counterclaim does not arise out of the same transaction or occurrence. 2.2.2 It may be brought in the same action but may also be brought separately in a different lawsuit. 3. Procedural point 3.1 Both compulsory and permissive counterclaims may be asserted in the answer, subject to jurisdictional and other procedural requirements.
cards.cloze: 1. Counterclaims in the answer 1.1 The defendant's claims against the plaintiff may be asserted in the answer as {{c1::counterclaims}}. 2. Types of counterclaims 2.1 {{c2::Compulsory}} counterclaims 2.1.1 Arise out of the {{c3::same transaction or occurrence}} as the plaintiff's claim. 2.1.2 Must generally be {{c4::brought in the same action}} or are {{c5::barred}}. 2.2 {{c6::Permissive}} counterclaims 2.2.1 Do {{c7::not}} arise out of the same transaction or occurrence. 2.2.2 May be brought in the {{c8::same action}} or {{c9::separately}} in another lawsuit. 3. Procedural point 3.1 Both types may be asserted in the answer, subject to {{c10::jurisdictional}} and other procedural requirements.
cards.easyContent: The defendant can assert counterclaims against the plaintiff in the answer. Compulsory counterclaims arise from the same transaction or occurrence and must be brought in the same case, or they’re usually lost. Permissive counterclaims don’t, and can be brought in the same case or separately.
cards.mediumContent: In the answer, the defendant may assert her own claims against the plaintiff as counterclaims. Compulsory counterclaims are those arising out of the same transaction or occurrence as the plaintiff’s claim and generally must be brought in the same action or they are barred. Permissive counterclaims do not arise out of the same transaction or occurrence; they may, but need not, be joined in the same action and can instead be brought in a separate lawsuit.
cards.hardContent: Federal procedure allows the defendant to assert claims against the plaintiff in the answer as counterclaims. A compulsory counterclaim is one that arises out of the same transaction or occurrence as the plaintiff’s claim; it must ordinarily be asserted in the same action or it will be barred by claim preclusion. A permissive counterclaim, by contrast, does not arise from the same transaction or occurrence and therefore may be brought either in the same action (if jurisdictional requirements are met) or in a separate lawsuit. Both types of counterclaims are typically asserted in the answer.
cards.mnemonic: COmpulsory = COre T/O; Permissive = apart, optional.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::compulsory counterclaim}} {{c2::arises from the same transaction or occurrence}} and {{c3::must be brought in the same action or is barred}}; {{c4::permissive counterclaims}} {{c5::do not share the same transaction or occurrence and may be brought separately}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 030-1. Rule 12(b) Defenses and Waiver
cards.backPlain: A defendant may attack the validity of the plaintiff's complaint through Rule 12(b) defenses, which may be raised by motion or in the answer. 1. Rule 12(b) defenses: 1.1 Lack of subject-matter jurisdiction (SMJ); 1.2 Insufficiency of service of process*; 1.3 Lack of personal jurisdiction (PJ)*; 1.4 Failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted; 1.5 Improper venue*; 1.6 Failure to join a necessary party under Rule 19; and 1.7 Insufficiency of process*. 2. Waiver of certain 12(b) defenses: • Defenses marked with an asterisk (lack of PJ, improper venue, insufficiency of process, insufficiency of service of process) are waived if not included in the defendant's first Rule 12 motion or, if no Rule 12 motion is made, in the defendant's first responsive pleading, provided they were then available. 3. Method and timing: • Rule 12(b), (c), and (h) defenses may be raised by motion or in the answer. • A Rule 12 motion must be filed before the answer if a responsive pleading is allowed.
cards.frontPrompt: List the Rule 12(b) defenses and explain which are waived if not raised in the first Rule 12 response and how they must be raised.
cards.cloze: A defendant may attack the validity of the plaintiff's complaint through {{c1::Rule 12(b) defenses}}, which may be raised by motion or in the answer. 1. The {{c2::Rule 12(b) defenses}} are: 1.1 Lack of {{c3::subject-matter jurisdiction (SMJ)}}; 1.2 {{c4::Insufficiency of service of process}}*; 1.3 Lack of {{c5::personal jurisdiction (PJ)}}*; 1.4 {{c6::Failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted}}; 1.5 {{c7::Improper venue}}*; 1.6 {{c8::Failure to join a necessary party under Rule 19}}; and 1.7 {{c9::Insufficiency of process}}*. 2. {{c10::Waiver}}: Defenses marked with an asterisk ({{c11::PJ, venue, insufficiency of process, and insufficiency of service of process}}) are waived if not included in the defendant's {{c12::first Rule 12 motion}} or, if no Rule 12 motion is made, in the {{c13::first responsive pleading}}, provided they were then available. 3. {{c14::Rule 12(b), (c), and (h) defenses}} may be raised by motion or in the answer, but any {{c15::Rule 12 motion}} must be filed {{c16::before the answer}} if a responsive pleading is allowed.
cards.easyContent: Rule 12(b) lists specific defenses like lack of SMJ, lack of PJ, improper venue, failure to state a claim, failure to join a necessary party, and insufficiencies in process or service. Objections to personal jurisdiction, venue, process, and service are waived if not raised in the first Rule 12 response.
cards.mediumContent: The Rule 12(b) defenses are: lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, lack of personal jurisdiction, improper venue, insufficiency of process, insufficiency of service of process, failure to state a claim, and failure to join a necessary party under Rule 19. The defenses of lack of PJ, improper venue, and insufficiency of process or service are waived if not raised in the defendant’s first Rule 12 motion or, if no motion is made, the first responsive pleading, assuming they were then available. Rule 12(b), (c), and (h) defenses may be raised by motion or in the answer, but any Rule 12 motion must be filed before the answer if a responsive pleading is allowed.
cards.hardContent: A defendant may attack the plaintiff's complaint through Rule 12(b) defenses. The Rule 12(b) defenses are: (1) lack of subject-matter jurisdiction; (2) insufficiency of service of process*; (3) lack of personal jurisdiction*; (4) failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted; (5) improper venue*; (6) failure to join a necessary party under Rule 19; and (7) insufficiency of process*. The defenses marked with an asterisk—lack of personal jurisdiction, improper venue, insufficiency of process, and insufficiency of service of process—are waived if not included in the defendant's first Rule 12 motion or, if no Rule 12 motion is made, in the first responsive pleading, provided they were then available. Rule 12(b), (c), and (h) defenses may be raised by motion or in the answer, but any Rule 12 motion must be filed before the answer if a responsive pleading is allowed.
cards.mnemonic: PJ VIPS: Personal Jx, Venue, Insufficient Process, Service waived if omitted.
cards.clozeLite: Waived if omitted from the first Rule 12 response: {{c1::lack of personal jurisdiction}}, {{c2::improper venue}}, {{c3::insufficiency of process}}, and {{c4::insufficiency of service of process}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Rule 12(e) Motion for More Definite Statement and Rule 12(f) Motion to Strike
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 030-2. Rule 12(e) and Rule 12(f) Motions
cards.front: Rule 12(e) Motion for More Definite Statement; Rule 12(f) Motion to Strike
cards.backPlain: In addition to Rule 12(b) defenses, Rule 12 provides two important motions that focus on the clarity and content of the pleadings: 1. Motion for a more definite statement (Rule 12(e)): • If a complaint (or other pleading to which a responsive pleading is allowed) is so vague or ambiguous that the defendant cannot reasonably prepare a response, the defendant may move for a more definite statement. • The motion asks the court to require the plaintiff to clarify or specify the allegations so that a proper response can be drafted. 2. Motion to strike (Rule 12(f)): • The defendant may move to strike from the complaint (or any pleading) any redundant, immaterial, impertinent, or scandalous material. • The court may also act on its own (sua sponte) to strike such material.
cards.frontPrompt: When can a party use a Rule 12(e) motion for a more definite statement and a Rule 12(f) motion to strike, and what do these motions accomplish?
cards.cloze: Rule 12 provides motions that address the {{c1::clarity and content}} of the pleadings. 1. {{c2::Motion for a more definite statement (Rule 12(e))}}: • Available when a pleading is so {{c3::vague or ambiguous}} that the defendant cannot reasonably {{c4::prepare a response}}. • The motion asks the court to require the {{c5::pleader (usually the plaintiff)}} to {{c6::clarify or specify the allegations}}. 2. {{c7::Motion to strike (Rule 12(f))}}: • Allows a party to seek removal of {{c8::redundant, immaterial, impertinent, or scandalous}} material from a pleading. • The court may also {{c9::strike such material on its own (sua sponte)}}.
cards.easyContent: A Rule 12(e) motion for a more definite statement is used when a pleading is so vague or ambiguous that the defendant cannot reasonably respond. A Rule 12(f) motion to strike is used to remove redundant, immaterial, impertinent, or scandalous matter from a pleading, and the court can also strike such matter on its own.
cards.mediumContent: Rule 12(e) allows a defendant to move for a more definite statement when the complaint (or other pleading) is so vague or ambiguous that the defendant cannot reasonably prepare a response; the court may require the plaintiff to clarify or specify the allegations. Rule 12(f) authorizes a motion to strike redundant, immaterial, impertinent, or scandalous material from a pleading, and the court may also strike such material sua sponte.
cards.hardContent: Rule 12 includes motions that address the form and content of pleadings. Under Rule 12(e), if a complaint or other pleading to which a responsive pleading is allowed is so vague or ambiguous that a defendant cannot reasonably prepare a response, the defendant may move for a more definite statement, asking the court to require the pleader to clarify or specify allegations. Under Rule 12(f), a party may move to strike from a pleading any redundant, immaterial, impertinent, or scandalous material. The court also has authority to strike such material on its own initiative (sua sponte).
cards.mnemonic: Vague? 12(e) Explain. Trash? 12(f) Flush.
cards.clozeLite: Rule {{c1::12(e)}} lets a defendant seek a {{c2::more definite statement}} when a pleading is {{c3::so vague or ambiguous}}. Rule {{c4::12(f)}} lets a party {{c5::strike redundant, immaterial, impertinent, or scandalous material}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Rule 12(c) Motion for Judgment on the Pleadings
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 030-3. Rule 12(c) Motion for Judgment on the Pleadings
cards.front: Rule 12(c) Motion for Judgment on the Pleadings
cards.backPlain: Rule 12(c) allows either party to seek judgment based solely on the pleadings when they show that one party must prevail as a matter of law. 1. Who may move: • The plaintiff or the defendant may move for judgment on the pleadings. 2. Standard: • The motion is appropriate when, taking the allegations in the pleadings (typically the complaint plus the answer) as true where required, the pleadings show that one party must win as a matter of law. 3. Example: • If the defendant's answer admits all of the allegations in the plaintiff's complaint, then the plaintiff must win as a matter of law, and a Rule 12(c) motion by the plaintiff should be granted.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a Rule 12(c) motion for judgment on the pleadings, who can bring it, and when is it appropriate?
cards.cloze: Under {{c1::Rule 12(c)}}, either {{c2::the plaintiff or the defendant}} may move for {{c3::judgment on the pleadings}}. The motion is proper when the {{c4::pleadings (typically the complaint and the answer)}} show that {{c5::one party must prevail as a matter of law}}. Example: If the {{c6::defendant's answer admits all allegations}} in the plaintiff's complaint, the {{c7::plaintiff}} must win as a matter of law and may obtain judgment on the pleadings.
cards.easyContent: Rule 12(c) lets either party seek judgment based only on the pleadings when those pleadings show that one party must win as a matter of law.
cards.mediumContent: A Rule 12(c) motion for judgment on the pleadings can be brought by either the plaintiff or defendant after the pleadings are closed. It is appropriate when the complaint and answer, taken together, show that there is no dispute over the material facts and one party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law—such as when the defendant admits all allegations in the complaint.
cards.hardContent: Rule 12(c) authorizes a motion for judgment on the pleadings by either the plaintiff or the defendant once the pleadings are closed. The motion asks the court to decide the case based solely on the pleadings—typically the complaint and the answer—without looking at evidence. It is appropriate when, taking the nonmovant's well-pleaded factual allegations as true and drawing reasonable inferences in that party's favor, the pleadings show that one party must prevail as a matter of law. For example, if the defendant's answer admits all allegations in the plaintiff's complaint, the plaintiff is entitled to judgment on the pleadings.
cards.mnemonic: 12(C) = Closed pleadings, Clear law, Court decides.
cards.clozeLite: A Rule {{c1::12(c) motion for judgment on the pleadings}} can be brought by {{c2::either party}} {{c3::after the pleadings are closed}} when {{c4::no material facts are disputed}} and {{c5::one party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 040. Intervention – As of Right
cards.backPlain: A non-party absentee may intervene in a pending suit as of right. Intervention as of right must be allowed if either of the following is satisfied: 1. Interest + harm + inadequate representation 1.1. The absentee has an interest in the subject matter of the action; 1.2. The absentee’s interest will be harmed (practically impaired or impeded) if not joined; and 1.3. No existing party will adequately represent that interest. 2. Unconditional statutory right 2.1. The absentee has an unconditional statutory right to intervene (e.g., expressly granted by federal statute). If one of these bases exists and the motion is timely, the court must permit the absentee to intervene as a party.
cards.frontPrompt: When must a federal court allow a non-party to intervene as of right in a pending civil action?
cards.cloze: A non-party {{c1::absentee}} may intervene in a pending suit {{c2::as of right}}. Intervention as of right must be allowed if either of the following is satisfied: 1. {{c3::Interest + harm + inadequate representation}}: • The absentee has an {{c4::interest in the subject matter}} of the action; • The absentee’s interest will be {{c5::harmed (practically impaired or impeded)}} if not joined; and • No existing party will {{c6::adequately represent}} that interest. 2. {{c7::Unconditional statutory right}}: • The absentee has an {{c8::unconditional statutory right to intervene}}. If one of these bases exists and the motion is {{c9::timely}}, the court {{c10::must permit}} intervention.
cards.easyContent: Intervention as of right must be granted if an absentee has an interest that will be harmed if they are not joined and no existing party adequately represents that interest, or if a statute gives them an unconditional right to intervene.
cards.mediumContent: A non-party absentee is entitled to intervention as of right when: (1) the absentee has an interest related to the subject of the action, (2) that interest will be practically harmed if the absentee is not joined, and (3) existing parties do not adequately represent that interest, or when (4) a federal statute gives the absentee an unconditional right to intervene. If these conditions are met and the motion is timely, the court must allow the intervention.
cards.hardContent: Intervention as of right allows a non-party absentee to join a pending action when the law deems their participation mandatory. A court must permit intervention as of right when: (1) the absentee has a significantly protectable interest relating to the property or transaction that is the subject of the action; (2) disposing of the action in the absentee’s absence may as a practical matter impair or impede the absentee’s ability to protect that interest; and (3) the existing parties do not adequately represent the absentee’s interest. Alternatively, intervention as of right is also available when a federal statute expressly grants the absentee an unconditional right to intervene. Provided the motion is timely, satisfaction of either basis requires the court to allow intervention.
cards.mnemonic: Right to intervene needs IHI or Statute: Interest, Harm, Inadequate representation.
cards.clozeLite: Intervention {{c1::as of right}} requires {{c2::a significantly protectable interest}}, {{c3::practical impairment if absent}}, and {{c4::inadequate representation}} or {{c5::an unconditional statutory right}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 040. Intervention – Permissive
cards.backPlain: A non-party absentee may seek permissive intervention in a pending suit. Permissive intervention is allowed in the court’s discretion if any of the following apply: 1. Common question of law or fact 1.1. The absentee has a claim or defense that shares a common question of law or fact with the underlying action. 2. Conditional statutory right 2.1. The absentee has a conditional statutory right to intervene (a statute authorizes intervention under specified conditions). 3. Government officer or agency 3.1. The absentee is a government officer or agency; and 3.2. An existing claim or defense in the case relates to that officer/agency or to a statute, regulation, or order administered by the officer/agency. In exercising discretion, the court must consider whether intervention will unduly delay or prejudice the adjudication of the original parties’ rights.
cards.frontPrompt: When may a federal court allow permissive intervention in a civil action, and what limits does the court consider?
cards.cloze: A non-party absentee may seek {{c1::permissive intervention}} in a pending suit. Permissive intervention is allowed in the court’s {{c2::discretion}} if any of the following apply: 1. {{c3::Common question of law or fact}}: • The absentee has a claim or defense that shares a {{c4::common question of law or fact}} with the underlying action. 2. {{c5::Conditional statutory right}}: • The absentee has a {{c6::conditional statutory right to intervene}}. 3. {{c7::Government officer or agency}}: • The absentee is an {{c8::officer or agency}}; and • An existing claim or defense relates to that officer/agency or to a {{c9::statute, regulation, or order}} administered by the officer/agency. In deciding whether to allow permissive intervention, the court must consider whether intervention will {{c10::unduly delay or prejudice}} adjudication of the {{c11::original parties’ rights}}.
cards.easyContent: Permissive intervention is discretionary. A court may allow a non-party to intervene if they share a common question of law or fact with the case, have a conditional statutory right, or are a government officer or agency whose statute or regulation is at issue, so long as intervention does not unduly delay or prejudice the original parties.
cards.mediumContent: Permissive intervention allows a federal court, in its discretion, to let an absentee join a case. It is available where the absentee’s claim or defense shares a common question of law or fact with the underlying action, where a statute gives a conditional right to intervene, or where a government officer or agency seeks to intervene in a case involving a claim or defense related to that officer/agency or to a statute or regulation they administer. The court must weigh whether intervention would unduly delay or prejudice adjudication of the original parties’ rights.
cards.hardContent: Permissive intervention is a flexible joinder device that allows a federal court, in its discretion, to let a non-party absentee enter an ongoing lawsuit. The court may permit intervention when: (1) the absentee asserts a claim or defense that shares at least one common question of law or fact with the main action; (2) a statute grants the absentee a conditional right to intervene, typically upon satisfaction of specified criteria; or (3) the absentee is a government officer or agency and an existing claim or defense in the case concerns that officer/agency or a statute, regulation, or order administered by the officer/agency. Even if one of these grounds is satisfied, the court must still consider the potential for undue delay or prejudice to the original parties and may deny permissive intervention on that basis.
cards.mnemonic: Permissive CCC-Gov: Common question, Conditional statute, or Gov officer—no undue delay/prejudice.
cards.clozeLite: Permissive intervention lets an absentee join if {{c1::there is a common question of law or fact}}, {{c2::a statute grants a conditional right}}, or {{c3::a government officer/agency’s statute or regulation is at issue}}, so long as {{c4::it will not unduly delay or prejudice the original parties}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 040. Intervention – Diversity Jurisdiction Limits
cards.backPlain: In diversity cases, special subject-matter jurisdiction rules apply to intervenors. 1. Independent subject-matter jurisdiction 1.1. In diversity-only cases, an intervenor (whether of right or permissive) generally must establish an independent basis for subject-matter jurisdiction. 1.2. The intervenor must satisfy complete diversity and the amount-in-controversy requirement, unless another basis for federal jurisdiction applies (e.g., federal question). 2. No supplemental jurisdiction for diversity intervention 2.1. Supplemental jurisdiction does not extend to claims by or against intervenors when it would destroy diversity or circumvent the statutory diversity requirements. Thus, in a purely diversity case, an absentee cannot rely solely on supplemental jurisdiction to intervene; their claim must independently qualify for federal jurisdiction.
cards.frontPrompt: How does subject-matter jurisdiction work for intervenors in diversity cases in federal court?
cards.cloze: In {{c1::diversity}} cases, an intervenor generally must establish {{c2::independent subject-matter jurisdiction}}. 1. {{c3::Independent SMJ}}: • In diversity-only cases, an intervenor must independently satisfy {{c4::complete diversity}} and the {{c5::amount-in-controversy}} requirement (unless another jurisdictional basis, like federal question, applies). 2. {{c6::No supplemental jurisdiction for diversity intervention}}: • {{c7::Supplemental jurisdiction does not extend}} to claims by or against intervenors if doing so would {{c8::destroy diversity}} or otherwise circumvent statutory diversity requirements. Therefore, in a purely diversity case, an absentee cannot rely solely on {{c9::supplemental jurisdiction}} to intervene; the intervenor’s claim must {{c10::qualify independently}} for federal jurisdiction.
cards.easyContent: In a diversity case, an intervenor usually must have their own basis for federal jurisdiction. They must meet diversity and amount-in-controversy on their own, because supplemental jurisdiction does not cover diversity-based intervention.
cards.mediumContent: For intervention in a purely diversity case, the intervenor cannot simply rely on supplemental jurisdiction. Instead, the intervenor’s claim must have its own jurisdictional basis—typically independent complete diversity and the amount-in-controversy requirement. Supplemental jurisdiction will not support an intervenor’s claim if it would destroy or circumvent the diversity requirements.
cards.hardContent: When an absentee seeks to intervene in a federal action based solely on diversity jurisdiction, the intervention is subject to strict subject-matter rules. The intervenor’s claim must independently satisfy federal subject-matter jurisdiction, usually by meeting complete diversity and the statutory amount in controversy. Supplemental jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1367 generally does not extend to claims by or against intervenors in diversity-only cases where doing so would undermine the complete-diversity or amount-in-controversy requirements. As a result, an absentee cannot piggyback onto a diversity case via supplemental jurisdiction alone; the intervenor’s claim must, standing alone, qualify for federal jurisdiction.
cards.mnemonic: Intervenor in diversity must stand alone: no piggybacking with supplemental jurisdiction.
cards.clozeLite: In a purely diversity case, an {{c1::intervenor}} cannot rely on {{c2::supplemental jurisdiction}} and instead must have {{c3::independent complete diversity}} and {{c4::amount-in-controversy}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 040. Intervention vs. Compulsory Joinder
cards.backPlain: Intervention and compulsory joinder are distinct joinder mechanisms. 1. Intervention 1.1. A non-party absentee chooses to join the suit (voluntary). 1.2. The absentee can intervene as a plaintiff or defendant. 1.3. Governed by rules for intervention as of right or permissive intervention. 1.4. More lenient and flexible: used when absentees want to protect their interests by entering an ongoing case. 2. Compulsory joinder (required joinder of parties) 2.1. The court forces an absentee into the case when that person is necessary and, if feasible, indispensable to a just adjudication. 2.2. Narrow and used only when very necessary to protect parties or avoid inconsistent obligations. 2.3. If an indispensable absentee cannot be joined, the court may dismiss the action. 3. Key distinction 3.1. Intervention is voluntary entry by the absentee; compulsory joinder is mandatory inclusion ordered by the court. 3.2. Intervention focuses on the absentee’s desire and entitlement to join; compulsory joinder focuses on whether the case can fairly proceed without the absentee.
cards.frontPrompt: How does intervention differ from compulsory (required) joinder in federal civil procedure?
cards.cloze: Intervention and compulsory joinder are distinct joinder devices. 1. {{c1::Intervention}}: • A non-party absentee {{c2::voluntarily chooses}} to join the suit. • The absentee may join as a {{c3::plaintiff}} or {{c4::defendant}}. • Governed by {{c5::intervention as of right}} and {{c6::permissive intervention}} rules. • Generally {{c7::more lenient and flexible}}, used when absentees seek to protect their own interests in an ongoing case. 2. {{c8::Compulsory joinder}}: • The court {{c9::forces an absentee into the case}} when the person is {{c10::necessary or indispensable}} to a just adjudication. • It is {{c11::narrow}} and used only when very necessary to protect parties or avoid {{c12::inconsistent obligations}}. • If an indispensable absentee cannot be joined, the court may {{c13::dismiss the action}}. 3. Key distinction: • Intervention is {{c14::voluntary}} from the absentee’s perspective; compulsory joinder is {{c15::mandatory}} at the court’s direction.
cards.easyContent: Intervention is voluntary—an absentee chooses to join a case under the rules for intervention as of right or permissive intervention. Compulsory joinder is mandatory—the court forces a necessary or indispensable absentee into the case and may dismiss the case if the absentee cannot be joined.
cards.mediumContent: Intervention allows an absentee to voluntarily join an existing lawsuit as a plaintiff or defendant when the standards for intervention as of right or permissive intervention are met. Compulsory joinder, by contrast, concerns whether the court must bring an absentee into the case because the absentee is necessary or indispensable; if an indispensable party cannot be joined, the court may dismiss the case. Intervention is more lenient and focuses on the absentee’s opportunity to protect its interests; compulsory joinder is narrower and focuses on whether the litigation can fairly proceed without the absentee.
cards.hardContent: Intervention and compulsory (required) joinder serve different functions in federal civil procedure. Intervention is a mechanism for a non-party absentee to voluntarily enter an existing lawsuit, either as of right (when certain strict criteria or an unconditional statutory right are satisfied) or permissively (in the court’s discretion, based on common issues or statutory authorization). It is primarily concerned with allowing interested absentees to participate to protect their own interests. Compulsory joinder, in contrast, is concerned with whether an action can equitably proceed without a particular absentee. When a person is necessary and, if feasible, indispensable to a just adjudication, the court may require that person to be joined; if joinder is not feasible and the person is indispensable, the court may have to dismiss the case. Thus, intervention is a voluntary and more flexible device, whereas compulsory joinder is a narrow, mandatory mechanism triggered only when fairness and completeness of adjudication demand the absentee’s presence.
cards.mnemonic: Intervention is invited; compulsory joinder is conscripted.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Intervention}} lets an absentee {{c2::voluntarily join}} a case; {{c3::compulsory joinder}} {{c4::requires joining a necessary or indispensable party}} and may {{c5::dismiss if indispensable can’t be joined}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 041-1. Interpleader – Basic Concept and Parties
cards.backPlain: Interpleader is a joinder device that allows a property holder who faces multiple claims to the same property or fund to resolve all those claims in a single lawsuit. Key roles: - Stakeholder: the property holder exposed to multiple liability or inconsistent obligations. - Claimants: the adverse parties who each assert a right to the same property or fund. Core function: - The stakeholder initiates an interpleader action to compel all claimants to litigate their competing rights in one proceeding. - This protects the stakeholder from: - Multiple lawsuits about the same property; and - Inconsistent judgments regarding the same obligation or fund. Additional point: - A stakeholder plaintiff may also name itself as an adverse claimant defendant (for example, when it asserts some right or interest in the property or fund) so that all interests can be adjudicated together.
cards.frontPrompt: What is interpleader, who are the key parties involved, and why would a stakeholder use interpleader?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Interpleader}} is a joinder device that allows a {{c2::stakeholder}} (a property holder exposed to multiple liability) to bring all rival {{c3::claimants}} into a single lawsuit to resolve competing claims to the same property or fund. The {{c4::stakeholder}} initiates the action to avoid {{c5::multiple suits}} and {{c6::inconsistent judgments}}. A stakeholder plaintiff may also {{c7::name itself as an adverse claimant defendant}} so that its own interest can be adjudicated in the same proceeding.
cards.easyContent: Interpleader lets a property holder (stakeholder) who is facing conflicting claims to the same money or property sue everyone at once so the court can decide who gets it. The rival parties are claimants, and the stakeholder can even list itself as a claimant if it asserts its own interest.
cards.mediumContent: Interpleader is used when a single property holder (stakeholder) is subject to competing claims over the same property or fund. Instead of litigating multiple separate suits with a risk of inconsistent outcomes, the stakeholder files one interpleader action and joins all rival claimants, who then litigate among themselves to determine who is entitled. The stakeholder can also participate as an adverse claimant if it asserts its own right to the property.
cards.hardContent: Interpleader is a procedural mechanism for consolidating all adverse claims to the same property or fund in one action. The stakeholder—the person or entity holding the property or fund and facing potential multiple liability—initiates an interpleader suit and names as defendants all claimants, i.e., parties who assert rights to that property. The action compels the claimants to litigate their competing claims in a single forum, thereby protecting the stakeholder from multiple suits and inconsistent judgments. A stakeholder plaintiff can also name itself as an adverse claimant defendant when it asserts its own interest, so that all rights to the property or fund are resolved in one case.
cards.mnemonic: One pot, many spoons: one fund, all claimants in one case.
cards.clozeLite: Interpleader lets a {{c1::stakeholder}} facing {{c2::competing claims}} to the same fund file {{c3::one action}} joining all {{c4::claimants}} to avoid {{c5::multiple suits and inconsistent judgments}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 041-2. Interpleader – Rule 22 Requirements
cards.backPlain: Rule 22 interpleader is an ordinary federal civil action that uses the standard rules for subject-matter jurisdiction, personal jurisdiction, and venue. Subject-matter jurisdiction and amount in controversy: - Rule 22 itself does not create jurisdiction; the case must independently satisfy a basis for federal jurisdiction. - In diversity cases, this means: - Complete diversity: the stakeholder must be diverse from all claimants; and - Amount in controversy: the amount in controversy must exceed $75,000. Personal jurisdiction and venue: - Personal jurisdiction and venue are determined under the usual federal rules that apply in any civil case. - There is no special nationwide service or special venue rule for Rule 22 interpleader. Summary: - Think of Rule 22 interpleader as an interpleader action that must fit within ordinary diversity or federal-question jurisdiction, with complete diversity and >$75,000 required for a diversity-based case, and with normal personal jurisdiction and venue requirements.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the subject-matter jurisdiction, diversity, amount in controversy, and personal jurisdiction/venue requirements for Rule 22 interpleader?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Rule 22 interpleader}} is an ordinary federal civil action and does {{c2::not itself create subject-matter jurisdiction}}. In diversity cases, it therefore requires {{c3::complete diversity}} (the stakeholder diverse from all {{c4::claimants}}) and an {{c5::amount in controversy exceeding $75,000}}. {{c6::Personal jurisdiction}} and {{c7::venue}} are determined under the {{c8::usual federal rules}} that apply in any civil case—there is no special nationwide service or special venue rule for Rule 22 interpleader.
cards.easyContent: Rule 22 interpleader is just a normal federal lawsuit that happens to be an interpleader. It must independently satisfy federal subject-matter jurisdiction. If it’s based on diversity, it requires complete diversity between the stakeholder and all claimants and more than $75,000 in controversy, plus the usual personal jurisdiction and venue rules.
cards.mediumContent: Under Rule 22, interpleader is brought as an ordinary civil action. Rule 22 does not relax jurisdictional requirements: in a diversity case, the stakeholder must be completely diverse from each claimant, and the amount in controversy must exceed $75,000. Personal jurisdiction and venue are determined exactly as in any other federal case—there is no special nationwide service of process or special venue provision for Rule 22 interpleader.
cards.hardContent: Rule 22 interpleader is a rule-based mechanism that permits a stakeholder to join multiple adverse claimants in a single action, but it does not provide an independent grant of federal jurisdiction. Accordingly, in diversity-based Rule 22 interpleader, the stakeholder must satisfy the standard diversity requirements: (1) complete diversity between the stakeholder and all claimants; and (2) an amount in controversy exceeding $75,000. If federal-question jurisdiction is asserted, the interpleader claim must arise under federal law. Personal jurisdiction over the claimants and venue are governed by the usual federal statutes and rules applicable to any civil action—there is no nationwide service authorization or special venue provision unique to Rule 22.
cards.mnemonic: Rule 22 = Regular Rules: normal SMJ, diversity, PJ, venue.
cards.clozeLite: Rule 22 interpleader is {{c1::an ordinary civil action}} requiring {{c2::independent subject-matter jurisdiction}}, {{c3::complete diversity and > $75,000}} in diversity cases, and {{c4::ordinary PJ and venue rules}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Interpleader – Statutory Requirements and Procedural Advantages
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 041-3. Interpleader – Statutory Requirements and Procedural Advantages
cards.backPlain: Statutory interpleader is created by federal statute and provides relaxed jurisdictional thresholds and special procedural benefits. Jurisdictional requirements: - Diversity: - Only minimal diversity is required: at least one claimant must be diverse from at least one other claimant. - Amount in controversy: - The amount in controversy must be $500 or more. Service of process: - Nationwide service of process is proper on anyone in the United States. - This makes it easier to obtain personal jurisdiction over claimants located in different states. Venue: - Venue is proper in any federal district where any claimant resides. Summary: - Statutory interpleader lowers the diversity and amount-in-controversy thresholds compared to Rule 22 and adds nationwide service and broad venue, making it easier to bring all claimants into one federal forum.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the diversity and amount-in-controversy requirements for statutory interpleader, and what special rules apply to service of process and venue?
cards.cloze: In {{c1::statutory interpleader}}, only {{c2::minimal diversity}} is required—at least one {{c3::claimant}} must be diverse from at least one other claimant. The {{c4::amount in controversy}} need only be {{c5::$500 or more}}. Statutory interpleader also authorizes {{c6::nationwide service of process}} on anyone in the U.S. and permits {{c7::venue}} in any district where any {{c8::claimant resides}}.
cards.easyContent: Statutory interpleader has relaxed requirements: it needs only minimal diversity between claimants, at least $500 in controversy, nationwide service of process, and venue in any district where any claimant lives. These features make it much easier to get all claimants into federal court.
cards.mediumContent: Under statutory interpleader, the jurisdictional thresholds are lower and the procedural tools are broader than under Rule 22. Jurisdictionally, only minimal diversity is needed—at least two claimants from different states—and the amount in controversy must be at least $500. Procedurally, the statute authorizes nationwide service of process, enabling the court to assert personal jurisdiction over claimants across the country, and allows venue in any district where any claimant resides.
cards.hardContent: The federal interpleader statute creates a special form of interpleader with relaxed jurisdictional and procedural requirements. First, it requires only minimal diversity: it is sufficient that at least one claimant be a citizen of a different state from at least one other claimant. Second, the statutory minimum amount in controversy is only $500, far below the ordinary diversity threshold. Third, the statute expressly authorizes nationwide service of process, permitting the stakeholder to serve claimants anywhere in the United States and thereby facilitating personal jurisdiction over widely dispersed parties. Finally, venue is broadly permitted in any district where any claimant resides, easing consolidation of all claims in a single federal forum. These features make statutory interpleader significantly more accessible than Rule 22 interpleader.
cards.mnemonic: 5-0-0 MINI: $500, Minimal diversity, Nationwide service, Inclusive venue.
cards.clozeLite: Statutory interpleader needs {{c1::minimal diversity between claimants}}, {{c2::at least $500 in controversy}}, {{c3::nationwide service of process}}, and {{c4::venue where any claimant resides}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 041-4. Interpleader – Applied Example (Rule 22 vs Statutory)
cards.backPlain: Example: - The deceased had a life insurance policy with a corporation incorporated in Delaware with its principal place of business in California. - Claimants from New Jersey, Nevada, and California all claim interests in the policy proceeds. Analysis: - Rule 22 interpleader (diversity): - For complete diversity, the stakeholder (Delaware/California citizen) must be diverse from all claimants. - The California claimant destroys complete diversity because the stakeholder is also a citizen of California (via its principal place of business). - Therefore, Rule 22 interpleader based on diversity is improper due to lack of complete diversity. - Statutory interpleader: - Minimal diversity is satisfied because at least two claimants (e.g., New Jersey and Nevada, or New Jersey and California) are citizens of different states. - Assuming the amount in controversy is at least $500, statutory interpleader is proper. Conclusion: - In this scenario, Rule 22 interpleader is not available due to lack of complete diversity, but statutory interpleader is available because it requires only minimal diversity among claimants and a $500 amount in controversy.
cards.frontPrompt: Given a stakeholder life insurer incorporated in Delaware with its principal place of business in California and claimants from New Jersey, Nevada, and California, is Rule 22 interpleader proper? Is statutory interpleader proper, and why?
cards.cloze: A life insurer incorporated in {{c1::Delaware}} with its principal place of business in {{c2::California}} faces claims to policy proceeds from residents of {{c3::New Jersey}}, {{c4::Nevada}}, and {{c5::California}}. Because the insurer is a citizen of both {{c6::Delaware}} and {{c7::California}}, the presence of a {{c8::California}} claimant defeats {{c9::complete diversity}}, so {{c10::Rule 22 interpleader}} based on diversity is improper. However, {{c11::statutory interpleader}} is proper because there is {{c12::minimal diversity}} among the {{c13::claimants}} (they are from different states) and, assuming at least {{c14::$500}} in controversy, the statutory requirements are satisfied.
cards.easyContent: In the life insurance example, Rule 22 interpleader fails because the insurer is a citizen of California and one of the claimants is also from California, so complete diversity is missing. Statutory interpleader works because it only needs minimal diversity between claimants and at least $500 in controversy, both of which are present.
cards.mediumContent: Where a life insurer is a citizen of Delaware and California, and claimants to the proceeds are citizens of New Jersey, Nevada, and California, Rule 22 interpleader cannot be based on diversity because complete diversity between the stakeholder and all claimants is lacking due to the shared California citizenship.
