By contrast, statutory interpleader is available because minimal diversity is met—there are claimants from different states—and the statutory amount-in-controversy requirement (at least $500) is easily satisfied in a typical life insurance dispute.
cards.hardContent: In the hypothetical involving a life insurance policy issued by a corporation incorporated in Delaware with its principal place of business in California, and claimants from New Jersey, Nevada, and California, the insurer is a citizen of both Delaware and California. For a diversity-based Rule 22 interpleader action, complete diversity requires that the stakeholder be diverse from every claimant. Because one claimant is a citizen of California, complete diversity is destroyed, and Rule 22 interpleader is therefore unavailable on a diversity theory. Statutory interpleader, however, only demands minimal diversity—at least two claimants from different states—which is easily satisfied by, for example, the New Jersey and Nevada claimants. Assuming the policy proceeds exceed $500, the statutory amount-in-controversy requirement is also satisfied. Thus, statutory interpleader would be proper even though Rule 22 interpleader is not.
cards.mnemonic: Rule 22 needs total split; statute needs just some split.
cards.clozeLite: Here, {{c1::Rule 22 interpleader fails}} because {{c2::complete diversity between stakeholder and all claimants is lacking}}, but {{c3::statutory interpleader works}} with {{c4::minimal diversity and $500+ at stake}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Class Actions – Personal Jurisdiction over Absent Class Members
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 044-1. Class Actions – Personal Jurisdiction over Absent Class Members
cards.front: Class Actions – Personal Jurisdiction over Absent Class Members
cards.backPlain: Personal jurisdiction over absent class members in federal class actions is not assessed individually under the minimum contacts test. Instead, due process for absent members is protected through procedural safeguards: 1. No individual minimum contacts requirement: - Absent class members are not required to show personal minimum contacts with the forum state. 2. Due process protections: - Reasonable and adequate notice must be provided to class members (especially in Rule 23(b)(3) damages classes). - Class members must be given an opportunity to opt out where the Rules require it (e.g., Rule 23(b)(3) classes). - The named class representatives must adequately represent the interests of the absent class members. If these notice, opt-out (when applicable), and adequate-representation requirements are satisfied, the personal jurisdiction due process requirements for absent class members are met.
cards.frontPrompt: How is personal jurisdiction over absent class members handled in federal class actions, and what due process protections substitute for individual minimum contacts?
cards.cloze: In federal class actions, {{c1::absent class members}} are not each required to satisfy {{c2::minimum contacts}} with the forum state. Instead, their due process rights are protected through procedural safeguards: - {{c3::Reasonable and adequate notice}} must be provided to class members. - Class members must be given an {{c4::opportunity to opt out}} where the applicable rule (e.g., Rule 23(b)(3)) requires it. - The {{c5::named class representatives}} must {{c6::adequately represent}} the interests of the absent class members. If these protections are in place, the {{c7::personal jurisdiction due process}} requirements for absent class members are satisfied without individualized minimum contacts.
cards.easyContent: Absent class members do not need their own minimum contacts with the forum. Due process is protected instead by giving them reasonable notice, an opportunity to opt out when required, and ensuring adequate representation by the named class representatives.
cards.mediumContent: In class actions, the forum does not test each absent member’s minimum contacts. Rather, personal jurisdiction due process is satisfied if absent members receive reasonable and adequate notice, have an opportunity to opt out where the Rules require it (such as in Rule 23(b)(3) damages classes), and are adequately represented by the named plaintiffs.
cards.hardContent: Personal jurisdiction over absent class members in federal class actions is not based on each member satisfying International Shoe–style minimum contacts. Instead, the Supreme Court treats absent members as protected by class procedures: due process is secured by providing reasonable and adequate notice of the action and class status, affording an opportunity to opt out when the governing rule (e.g., Rule 23(b)(3)) mandates exclusion rights, and requiring that the named class representatives and class counsel adequately represent the interests of absent members. When these conditions are met, the court may bind absent class members without separate personal jurisdiction showings for each of them.
cards.mnemonic: Class PJ trades contacts for N-O-R: Notice, Opt-out, Representation.
cards.clozeLite: Absent class members need no {{c1::individual minimum contacts}} if they get {{c2::reasonable notice}}, a {{c3::Rule 23(b)(3) opt-out chance}}, and {{c4::adequate representation}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Class Actions – Traditional Subject-Matter Jurisdiction (Especially Diversity)
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 044-2. Class Actions – Traditional Subject-Matter Jurisdiction (Especially Diversity)
cards.front: Class Actions – Traditional Subject-Matter Jurisdiction (Especially Diversity)
cards.backPlain: In class actions, traditional subject-matter jurisdiction rules still apply, but diversity is evaluated by looking only to the class representatives. 1. Federal question jurisdiction: - The same rules apply as in individual cases. - The claim(s) asserted must arise under federal law; the fact that the case is a class action does not change the basic federal question analysis. 2. Diversity jurisdiction in class actions (absent CAFA): - The court looks only to the named class representatives for: a. Citizenship: The class representatives must be completely diverse from all opposing parties (no representative may share citizenship with any defendant). b. Amount in controversy: Each class representative’s individual claim must exceed $75,000. - The citizenship or individual claim amounts of absent class members are disregarded for these determinations. - If these requirements are not met, the court may still have jurisdiction under another statute (e.g., the Class Action Fairness Act).
cards.frontPrompt: How do federal question and traditional diversity subject-matter jurisdiction work in class actions, and whose citizenship and claims are considered for diversity?
cards.cloze: In class actions, {{c1::traditional subject-matter jurisdiction}} still governs unless a special statute like CAFA applies. 1. For {{c2::federal question}} jurisdiction, the same rules apply as in individual cases—the claims must {{c3::arise under federal law}}, and the fact that the case is a class action does not change the analysis. 2. For {{c4::diversity}} jurisdiction (absent CAFA): - The court looks only to the {{c5::named class representatives}} to determine: • {{c6::Citizenship}}: The representatives must be {{c7::completely diverse from all opposing parties}}. • {{c8::Amount in controversy}}: Each representative’s {{c9::individual claim}} must {{c10::exceed $75,000}}. - The {{c11::citizenship}} and {{c12::claim amounts}} of absent class members are disregarded. - If these requirements are not satisfied, jurisdiction may still arise under {{c13::another statute such as CAFA}}.
cards.easyContent: For federal question class actions, use the normal test: the claims must arise under federal law. For diversity class actions (without CAFA), the court looks only at the class reps: they must be completely diverse from all defendants, and each rep must have more than $75,000 at stake; other class members’ citizenship and amounts don’t matter.
cards.mediumContent: Class actions must still satisfy a basis for subject-matter jurisdiction. In federal question cases, the usual “arising under” standard applies. In diversity class actions, courts focus on the named representatives: complete diversity is required between each representative and every opposing party, and each representative’s own claim must exceed $75,000. The citizenship and claim sizes of the unnamed class members do not affect diversity jurisdiction, though an alternative statute like CAFA can sometimes provide jurisdiction even if these traditional requirements are not met.
cards.hardContent: In federal class actions, traditional subject-matter jurisdiction doctrines continue to apply. For federal question jurisdiction, the well-pleaded complaint rule governs and the presence of a class mechanism does not alter the requirement that the claims arise under federal law. For diversity jurisdiction where CAFA is not invoked, the federal court evaluates diversity by reference to the named class representatives alone. Their citizenship must be completely diverse from all opposing parties—that is, no representative may share state citizenship with any defendant—and each representative’s individual claim must exceed $75,000. The citizenship and individual amounts in controversy of absent class members are ignored for these jurisdictional determinations. If these traditional diversity criteria cannot be satisfied, the action may still gain access to federal court under a separate statute, most notably the Class Action Fairness Act.
cards.mnemonic: Reps Rule: only reps’ diverse $75k+ claims count.
cards.clozeLite: In diversity class actions (no CAFA), courts look only at {{c1::named representatives}}: {{c2::complete diversity}} with all defendants and {{c3::each rep > $75,000}}; {{c4::unnamed members’ citizenship and amounts don’t matter}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Class Action Fairness Act (CAFA) – Jurisdiction and Exceptions
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 044-3. Class Action Fairness Act (CAFA) – Jurisdiction and Exceptions
cards.front: Class Action Fairness Act (CAFA) – Jurisdiction and Exceptions
cards.backPlain: The Class Action Fairness Act (CAFA) provides a separate and more permissive basis for federal subject-matter jurisdiction over certain large class actions. 1. Basic CAFA jurisdictional requirements: - Minimal diversity: • Jurisdiction exists if any class member is diverse from any opposing party (only one diverse pairing is required). - Aggregated amount in controversy: • The aggregated claims of all class members must exceed $5 million. 2. Scope limitations and exclusions: - CAFA does not apply to: • Class actions with fewer than 100 class members. • Certain shareholder claims against corporate management (e.g., some derivative or internal corporate governance suits). • Certain class actions based solely on state securities law fraud claims. If CAFA applies and its minimal diversity and aggregated amount thresholds are met, it can provide federal subject-matter jurisdiction even when traditional complete diversity or individual $75,000 amounts in controversy are not satisfied.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the basic jurisdictional requirements under CAFA for federal class actions, and which types of class actions are excluded from CAFA’s coverage?
cards.cloze: The {{c1::Class Action Fairness Act (CAFA)}} creates a separate basis for federal subject-matter jurisdiction in certain large class actions. 1. Jurisdictional requirements: - {{c2::Minimal diversity}}: Jurisdiction exists if {{c3::any class member}} is diverse from {{c4::any opposing party}} (only one diverse pairing is needed). - {{c5::Aggregated amount in controversy}}: The {{c6::aggregated claims of all class members}} must {{c7::exceed $5 million}}. 2. Exclusions – CAFA does not apply to: - Class actions with {{c8::fewer than 100 class members}}. - Certain {{c9::shareholder claims against corporate management}}. - Certain {{c10::state securities law fraud}} class actions. If these CAFA requirements are met and no exclusion applies, CAFA can provide {{c11::federal subject-matter jurisdiction}} even when traditional {{c12::complete diversity}} or {{c13::$75,000 individual}} requirements for diversity are not satisfied.
cards.easyContent: CAFA lets big class actions into federal court more easily. It requires minimal diversity (any class member diverse from any defendant) and more than $5 million in the aggregate. It does not cover small classes under 100 members or certain shareholder and state securities fraud class actions.
cards.mediumContent: Under CAFA, federal courts can hear certain large, multi-state class actions that meet two thresholds: minimal diversity—at least one class member is diverse from at least one defendant—and an aggregated amount in controversy exceeding $5 million. CAFA excludes small classes with fewer than 100 members and certain kinds of corporate and state securities fraud class actions, but when it applies, it provides jurisdiction even if traditional complete diversity and $75,000-per-plaintiff requirements are not met.
cards.hardContent: The Class Action Fairness Act (CAFA) significantly broadens federal subject-matter jurisdiction over qualifying class actions. CAFA requires only minimal diversity, satisfied when any single class member is a citizen of a different state from any single defendant. It also requires that the aggregated claims of all class members exceed $5 million in amount in controversy. However, CAFA’s reach is not unlimited: it expressly excludes class actions with fewer than 100 putative class members, certain shareholder suits against corporate management (often involving internal corporate governance or derivative claims), and particular class actions based solely on state securities fraud statutes. When a class action falls within CAFA and meets these minimal diversity and $5 million aggregate thresholds, the federal court may exercise jurisdiction even if traditional complete diversity and the $75,000-per-plaintiff standard for diversity jurisdiction are not independently satisfied.
cards.mnemonic: CAFA: 100 people, $5M pot, 1 pair diverse.
cards.clozeLite: CAFA allows federal jurisdiction if {{c1::minimal diversity}} exists and {{c2::aggregated claims exceed $5 million}}; it excludes {{c3::classes under 100 members}} and {{c4::certain shareholder and state securities fraud class actions}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Class Actions – Certification Timing, Class Definition, & Class Counsel
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 045-1. Class Actions – Certification Timing, Class Definition, & Class Counsel
cards.front: Class Actions – Certification Timing, Class Definition, & Class Counsel
cards.frontPrompt: In a federal class action, when must the court decide certification, and what must it do regarding defining the class and appointing class counsel?
cards.backPlain: 1. Timing of certification 1.1 The court must determine at an early practicable time whether to allow the case to proceed as a class action (i.e., certify the class). 2. Requirements upon certification 2.1 If a class is certified, the court must: 2.1.1 Define the class (i.e., who can be a class member), and the class claims, issues, and defenses; and 2.1.2 Appoint class counsel. 2.2 Class counsel must fairly and adequately represent the interests of the class as a whole.
cards.cloze: 1. Timing of certification 1.1 The court must determine at an {{c1::early practicable time}} whether to allow the case to proceed as a {{c2::class action}} (i.e., certify the class). 2. Requirements upon certification 2.1 If a class is certified, the court must: 2.1.1 Define the {{c3::class}} (i.e., who can be a class member), and the class {{c4::claims, issues, and defenses}}; and 2.1.2 Appoint {{c5::class counsel}}. 2.2 Class counsel must {{c6::fairly and adequately represent}} the interests of the class as a whole.
cards.easyContent: The court must decide class certification at an early practicable time. If it certifies, it must define the class and the class claims, issues, and defenses, and appoint class counsel who fairly and adequately represent the class.
cards.mediumContent: Certification must be decided at an early practicable time. Upon certification, the court must (1) define the class—who qualifies as a member—and the class claims, issues, and defenses, and (2) appoint class counsel, who must fairly and adequately represent the interests of the class as a whole.
cards.hardContent: In a federal class action, the court must determine at an early practicable time whether the case may proceed as a class action. If it certifies the class, the court must: (1) define the class—identifying who qualifies as a class member—and specify the class claims, issues, and defenses; and (2) appoint class counsel, who bear an ongoing duty to fairly and adequately represent the interests of the class as a whole.
cards.mnemonic: Early CC: Certification, then Class defined and Counsel appointed.
cards.clozeLite: Certification must be decided at an {{c1::early practicable time}}. If certified, the court must {{c2::define the class and class claims}} and {{c3::appoint class counsel}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Class Actions – Appeal of Certification & Effect of Judgment
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 045-2. Class Actions – Appeal of Certification & Effect of Judgment
cards.front: Class Actions – Appeal of Certification & Effect of Judgment
cards.frontPrompt: How can a class certification decision be reviewed before final judgment, and what is the binding effect of a class judgment on absent class members?
cards.backPlain: 1. Appeal of certification 1.1 A certification decision can be appealed via interlocutory appeal before final judgment on the merits. 2. Effect of judgment 2.1 A class judgment is binding as to all absent class members, unless they opt out, if applicable.
cards.cloze: 1. Appeal of certification 1.1 A certification decision can be appealed via {{c1::interlocutory appeal}} before final judgment on the merits. 2. Effect of judgment 2.1 A class judgment is {{c2::binding}} as to all {{c3::absent class members}}, unless they {{c4::opt out}}, if applicable.
cards.easyContent: A class certification decision can be reviewed by interlocutory appeal before final judgment. A judgment in a certified class action binds all absent class members unless they have a right to and do opt out.
cards.mediumContent: Federal rules allow interlocutory appeal of a class certification decision before final judgment on the merits. Once a class is properly certified, the resulting judgment binds all absent class members, subject to any available opt-out rights that they timely exercise.
cards.hardContent: Class certification decisions are unusually important and can be challenged before the case concludes through interlocutory appeal, rather than waiting for final judgment on the merits. When a class is certified, any judgment—whether favorable or adverse—is binding on all absent class members, provided due process is satisfied and, where applicable (e.g., for most damages classes), absent members are given the opportunity to opt out and do not exercise that right.
cards.mnemonic: After Certification: think "IA-Bind"—Interlocutory Appeal and Binding judgment (subject to opt-out).
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::class certification decision}} can be reviewed by {{c2::interlocutory appeal}} and a {{c3::certified class judgment}} {{c4::binds absent class members}} subject to {{c5::opt-out rights}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Class Actions – Settlement Approval Standards & Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 045-3. Class Actions – Settlement Approval Standards & Procedure
cards.front: Class Actions – Settlement Approval Standards & Procedure
cards.frontPrompt: What must a federal court do to approve a class action settlement, and what standard applies?
cards.backPlain: 1. Court approval of settlement 1.1 The court must approve any settlement reached between class representatives and the opposing party. 2. Standard for approval 2.1 A class settlement must be fair, reasonable, and adequate. 3. Procedure and input from absent class members 3.1 In deciding whether to approve or reject the settlement, the court will seek feedback (e.g., notice and objections) from absent class members.
cards.cloze: 1. Court approval of settlement 1.1 The court must {{c1::approve any settlement}} reached between class representatives and the opposing party. 2. Standard for approval 2.1 A class settlement must be {{c2::fair, reasonable, and adequate}}. 3. Procedure and input from absent class members 3.1 In deciding whether to approve or reject the settlement, the court will seek {{c3::feedback}} (e.g., {{c4::notice}} and {{c5::objections}}) from absent class members.
cards.easyContent: Any class action settlement must be approved by the court. The settlement must be fair, reasonable, and adequate, and the court will typically give notice and a chance for absent class members to object.
cards.mediumContent: A class action cannot be settled solely by agreement of the parties; the court must approve any settlement. The settlement will be approved only if it is fair, reasonable, and adequate, which the court assesses after providing notice to the class and an opportunity for absent members to offer feedback, typically through objections.
cards.hardContent: In class actions, the court acts as a guardian of absent class members in evaluating settlements. Any settlement between class representatives and the opposing party requires court approval and will be approved only if the court finds it fair, reasonable, and adequate in light of factors such as the strength of the case, risks and costs of further litigation, and the relief offered. To make this determination, the court typically orders notice to the class and provides absent class members with an opportunity to object or otherwise provide feedback before deciding whether to approve or reject the settlement.
cards.mnemonic: Class settlements need "FRA": Fair, Reasonable, Adequate, after notice and objections.
cards.clozeLite: A class action {{c1::settlement}} requires {{c2::court approval}} and must be {{c3::fair, reasonable, and adequate}} after {{c4::notice and chance to object}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 046-1. Discovery – Nature and Purpose
cards.frontPrompt: What is discovery in civil litigation, who conducts it, and what is the court’s role?
cards.backPlain: Nature and purpose of discovery: - Definition: Discovery is a court-mandated process of acquiring and producing information in civil litigation. - Who conducts discovery: Discovery is conducted primarily by the parties, who seek and exchange information from parties and non-party witnesses. - Court’s role: The court supervises discovery, manages deadlines, and resolves disputes, but does not typically participate directly in the exchange of information. - Purpose: To ensure that parties have access to relevant information necessary to prepare their cases, narrow issues for trial, and promote fair and efficient resolution of disputes.
cards.cloze: Nature and purpose of discovery: - Discovery is a {{c1::court-mandated process}} of acquiring and producing information in civil cases. - It is conducted primarily by the {{c2::parties}}, who seek and exchange information from {{c3::parties and non-party witnesses}}. - The {{c4::court}} supervises discovery, manages deadlines, and resolves disputes, but does not typically {{c5::participate directly in the exchange of information}}. - The purpose of discovery is to provide access to {{c6::relevant information}} so parties can {{c7::prepare their cases, narrow issues, and promote fair and efficient resolution}}.
cards.easyContent: Discovery is the formal process of exchanging information in civil cases. The parties run it, the court supervises and resolves disputes, and the purpose is to give both sides access to relevant information to prepare and narrow the case.
cards.mediumContent: Discovery is a court-mandated but party-driven process in which parties obtain and produce information from parties and non-party witnesses. The court manages timing and disputes but does not itself trade documents or take testimony. Its purpose is to give parties access to relevant information so they can prepare their claims and defenses and narrow the issues for trial.
cards.hardContent: Discovery is a court-mandated, party-driven process of acquiring and producing information in civil litigation. Parties use discovery to obtain information from both parties and non-party witnesses. Although the court oversees discovery—entering scheduling orders, enforcing deadlines, and resolving motions—it does not usually engage in the exchange of information itself. The primary purposes of discovery are to give each side access to relevant information, to reduce surprise at trial, to narrow and clarify the issues in dispute, and to promote accurate, fair, and efficient resolution of civil cases.
cards.mnemonic: Discovery: parties dig, judge directs the dig.
cards.clozeLite: Discovery is a {{c1::court-mandated but party-driven}} process to obtain {{c2::relevant information}} and {{c3::narrow the issues for trial}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Discovery – Overarching Questions: Scope and Privilege
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 046-2. Discovery – Overarching Questions: Scope and Privilege
cards.front: Discovery – Overarching Questions: Scope and Privilege
cards.frontPrompt: What two overarching questions frame all discovery requests in civil litigation?
cards.backPlain: Two overarching discovery questions: 1. Scope of discovery: - What information is within the permissible scope of discovery under the rules (e.g., relevance, proportionality, non-privileged matter)? - Parties must assess whether the requested information falls within that scope. 2. Privilege and protection: - Is the information sought protected by a privilege (e.g., attorney–client privilege) or another protection (e.g., work-product doctrine)? - Even if information is otherwise within the scope of discovery, it generally cannot be discovered if it is privileged or protected.
cards.cloze: Two overarching discovery questions: 1. {{c1::Scope of discovery}} – whether the requested information falls within the rules’ permissible scope (e.g., {{c2::relevance, proportionality, and non-privileged matter}}). 2. {{c3::Privilege and protection}} – whether the information is protected by a {{c4::privilege}} (such as attorney–client) or another protection like the {{c5::work-product doctrine}}. Even information within the scope of discovery is generally not discoverable if it is {{c6::privileged or protected}}.
cards.easyContent: All discovery turns on two big questions: (1) Is the requested information within the scope of discovery (relevant, proportional, non-privileged)? and (2) Is it protected by privilege or another protection, such as work product?
cards.mediumContent: Every discovery request is framed by two overarching questions. First, does the information fall within the permissible scope of discovery (e.g., relevant, proportional, and non-privileged under the rules)? Second, even if it is within that scope, is it protected by a privilege (like attorney–client) or another protection (such as work product), which would generally bar its discovery.
cards.hardContent: Discovery in civil litigation is guided by two overarching questions. First, what is the permissible scope of discovery—i.e., does the information requested fall within the rules’ scope requirements, such as relevance to a claim or defense, proportionality to the needs of the case, and being non-privileged? Second, is the information nonetheless protected by a privilege or other doctrine, such as attorney–client privilege or the work-product doctrine. Even if information is otherwise within the scope of discovery, it is generally not discoverable if it is privileged or otherwise protected.
cards.mnemonic: SP: Scope first, then Privilege.
cards.clozeLite: All discovery turns on {{c1::scope}} (relevant, proportional, non-privileged) and {{c2::privilege or work-product protection}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 046-3. Discovery – Steps and Tools
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main steps in initiating discovery and what formal tools are used to conduct it?
cards.backPlain: Steps and tools in the discovery process: 1. Initiating discovery: - Meet and confer: Parties must meet and confer to discuss claims and defenses and develop a proposed discovery plan. - Initial disclosures: Parties must make initial disclosures of discoverable information, insurance coverage, and damages information. - Scheduling order: The court and parties develop and enter a scheduling order setting deadlines for completing discovery. 2. Conducting discovery: - Formal tools: Parties conduct discovery using tools such as: • Depositions • Requests for production • Interrogatories • Requests for admission - Later disclosures: Discovery is followed by expert disclosures and pretrial disclosures.
cards.cloze: Steps and tools in discovery: 1. Initiating discovery: - {{c1::Meet and confer}} to discuss claims and develop a proposed discovery plan. - Make {{c2::initial disclosures}} of discoverable information, insurance, and damages information. - Obtain a {{c3::scheduling order}} from the court setting discovery deadlines. 2. Conducting discovery: - Use formal tools such as {{c4::depositions}}, {{c5::requests for production}}, {{c6::interrogatories}}, and {{c7::requests for admission}}. - After fact discovery, provide {{c8::expert disclosures}} and {{c9::pretrial disclosures}}.
cards.easyContent: Discovery starts with a meet-and-confer, initial disclosures, and a scheduling order. Then parties use formal tools—depositions, document requests, interrogatories, and requests for admission—followed by expert and pretrial disclosures.
cards.mediumContent: The discovery process begins with early case-management steps: the parties meet and confer to develop a discovery plan, make initial disclosures (including key information, insurance, and damages material), and obtain a scheduling order from the court setting deadlines. Discovery is then conducted through formal tools such as depositions, requests for production, interrogatories, and requests for admission, and later rounds out with expert disclosures and pretrial disclosures.
cards.hardContent: Discovery is initiated through a series of early steps. The parties must meet and confer to discuss their claims and defenses and to develop a proposed discovery plan. They then make initial disclosures, which include key discoverable information, insurance coverage, and damages information. Working with the court, they obtain a scheduling order that sets deadlines for completing discovery. Once initiated, discovery is conducted through formal tools: depositions, requests for production of documents or things, interrogatories, and requests for admission. After this core fact discovery, parties typically make expert disclosures (identifying experts and their opinions) and pretrial disclosures (such as witness and exhibit lists) as the case approaches trial.
cards.mnemonic: Flow: Meet–Disclose–Schedule; then Depose–Produce–Interrogate–Admit; then Experts–Pretrial.
cards.clozeLite: Discovery starts with {{c1::meet-and-confer}}, {{c2::initial disclosures}}, and a {{c3::scheduling order}}, then uses {{c4::depositions, document requests, interrogatories, and RFAs}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 047-1. Conferences – General Rule & Mandatory Meet-and-Confer
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule 1.1 Party representatives must meet and confer with each other and/or the court at various times throughout the proceeding. 1.2 Most of these conferences are for discovery purposes. 2. Mandatory meet and confer 2.1 Parties must meet at least 21 days before the scheduling conference to: 2.1.1 Discuss claims, defenses, and settlement; and 2.1.2 Develop a plan for discovery. 2.2 Parties must present a written discovery plan to the court within 14 days of the meet and confer.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general requirement for parties to meet and confer in federal civil litigation, and what are the timing and required topics for the mandatory meet-and-confer before the scheduling conference?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule 1.1 Party representatives must {{c1::meet and confer}} with each other and/or the court at various times throughout the proceeding. 1.2 Most of these conferences are for {{c2::discovery}} purposes. 2. Mandatory meet and confer 2.1 Parties must meet at least {{c3::21 days before}} the scheduling conference to: 2.1.1 Discuss {{c4::claims, defenses, and settlement}}; and 2.1.2 Develop a {{c5::plan for discovery}}. 2.2 Parties must present a {{c6::written discovery plan}} to the court within {{c7::14 days}} of the meet and confer.
cards.easyContent: In federal civil cases, parties must meet and confer throughout the case, mainly about discovery. At least 21 days before the scheduling conference, they must meet to discuss claims, defenses, settlement, and discovery planning, and then submit a written discovery plan to the court within 14 days.
cards.mediumContent: Party representatives must meet and confer with each other and/or the court at various stages of a federal civil case, primarily to manage discovery. A mandatory meet-and-confer must occur at least 21 days before the scheduling conference. At that meeting, the parties must discuss their claims, defenses, and potential settlement, and develop a discovery plan. Within 14 days after the meeting, they must file a written discovery plan with the court.
cards.hardContent: Under the federal rules, party representatives have an ongoing obligation to meet and confer with each other and sometimes the court, usually in connection with discovery. One specific requirement is a mandatory meet-and-confer held at least 21 days before the scheduling conference. At this session, the parties must discuss their respective claims and defenses, explore settlement, and jointly develop a plan for discovery. They must then reduce this plan to writing and submit it to the court as a written discovery plan within 14 days of the meeting.
cards.mnemonic: 21/14 rule: meet 21 days before scheduling; file plan 14 days after.
cards.clozeLite: Parties must {{c1::meet and confer}} throughout the case, and at least {{c2::21 days before the scheduling conference}} they must discuss {{c3::claims, defenses, settlement, and discovery planning}} and then {{c4::file a written discovery plan within 14 days}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 047-2. Conferences – Scheduling Conference & Scheduling Order
cards.backPlain: 3. Scheduling conference 3.1 A scheduling conference is a conference at or after which the judge issues a scheduling order. 3.2 The scheduling order sets deadlines for filing pleadings, joinder, amendments, and discovery deadlines.
cards.frontPrompt: What happens at a federal scheduling conference, and what does the resulting scheduling order typically cover?
cards.cloze: 3. Scheduling conference 3.1 A scheduling conference is a conference at or after which the judge issues a {{c1::scheduling order}}. 3.2 The scheduling order sets deadlines for {{c2::filing pleadings}}, {{c3::joinder}}, {{c4::amendments}}, and {{c5::discovery deadlines}}.
cards.easyContent: At the scheduling conference in federal court, the judge issues a scheduling order that sets key deadlines, including for pleadings, joinder, amendments, and discovery.
cards.mediumContent: A federal scheduling conference is a case-management conference at or after which the judge issues a scheduling order. That order sets the timetable for the case, including deadlines for filing pleadings, joining additional parties, amending pleadings, and completing discovery.
cards.hardContent: In federal civil litigation, the scheduling conference is a critical case-management event. At or after this conference, the judge issues a scheduling order, which functions as a roadmap for the case. The scheduling order typically sets firm deadlines for filing initial and amended pleadings, for joinder of additional parties, for amendments to pleadings, and for the completion of discovery. These deadlines structure the progress of the case and are generally enforced by the court.
cards.mnemonic: Scheduling conference creates the case calendar.
cards.clozeLite: A federal {{c1::scheduling conference}} is a case-management conference where the judge issues a {{c2::scheduling order}} setting deadlines for {{c3::pleadings}}, {{c4::joinder}}, {{c5::amendments}}, and {{c6::discovery}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Conferences – Pretrial & Final Pretrial Conferences and Orders
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 047-3. Conferences – Pretrial & Final Pretrial Conferences and Orders
cards.front: Conferences – Pretrial & Final Pretrial Conferences and Orders
cards.backPlain: 4. Pretrial conferences 4.1 A pretrial conference is held before the court, as needed, to move the case forward and encourage settlement. 5. Final pretrial conference and order 5.1 A final pretrial conference may be set to finalize the issues to be resolved at trial and the evidence to be presented, memorialized in a pretrial conference order. 5.2 Issues not included in the pretrial conference order are generally excluded at trial. 5.3 The pretrial conference order may be modified only to prevent manifest injustice.
cards.frontPrompt: What are pretrial and final pretrial conferences in federal civil litigation, and what is the effect of the final pretrial order on the issues and evidence at trial?
cards.cloze: 4. Pretrial conferences 4.1 A pretrial conference is held before the court, as needed, to {{c1::move the case forward}} and {{c2::encourage settlement}}. 5. Final pretrial conference and order 5.1 A final pretrial conference may be set to finalize the {{c3::issues to be resolved at trial}} and the {{c4::evidence to be presented}}, memorialized in a {{c5::pretrial conference order}}. 5.2 Issues not included in the pretrial conference order are generally {{c6::excluded at trial}}. 5.3 The pretrial conference order may be modified only to prevent {{c7::manifest injustice}}.
cards.easyContent: Pretrial conferences are held as needed to move the case forward and encourage settlement. A final pretrial conference produces a pretrial order that fixes the issues and evidence for trial; matters not in the order are generally excluded, and the order can be changed only to prevent manifest injustice.
cards.mediumContent: In federal civil practice, pretrial conferences are held before the court, when needed, to manage the case and encourage settlement. A final pretrial conference may be held to nail down the specific issues to be tried and the evidence to be presented. These determinations are recorded in a final pretrial order. Issues not included in that order are generally excluded at trial, and the order may be modified only to prevent manifest injustice.
cards.hardContent: Pretrial conferences in federal civil litigation are discretionary tools the court uses to control the course of the action and promote efficiency and settlement. They are held as needed to move the case forward and to encourage the parties to resolve or narrow disputes. A final pretrial conference may be scheduled to definitively identify the issues that will be resolved at trial and the evidence that will be presented. These decisions are memorialized in a final pretrial conference order. The final pretrial order effectively supersedes prior pleadings on matters of trial management: issues not included in the order are generally excluded at trial, and departures from the order are permitted only when necessary to prevent manifest injustice.
cards.mnemonic: FINAL order: Fixes Issues, Narrowed, Altered only for manifest Injustice, Limited trial.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::final pretrial conference}} produces a {{c2::final pretrial order}} that {{c3::fixes the issues and evidence for trial}} and may be modified only to {{c4::prevent manifest injustice}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Scope of Discovery – General Standard & Proportionality Factors
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 048-1. Scope of Discovery – General Standard & Proportionality Factors
cards.front: Scope of Discovery – General Standard & Proportionality
cards.frontPrompt: Under the Federal Rules, what is the general standard for the scope of discovery, and what factors are used to evaluate proportionality?
cards.backPlain: 1. General standard for discoverability 1.1 Material is discoverable if it is non-privileged, relevant to any party’s claim or defense, and proportional to the needs of the case. 2. Elements of discoverability 2.1 Non-privileged. 2.2 Relevant to a claim or defense. 2.3 Proportional to the needs of the case. 3. Proportionality factors 3.1 Amount in controversy. 3.2 Importance of the issues at stake in the action. 3.3 Resources of the parties involved. 3.4 Importance of the discovery in resolving the issues at stake. 3.5 Parties’ relative access to the information. 3.6 Whether the burden or expense of the proposed discovery outweighs its likely benefit.
cards.cloze: Material is within the scope of discovery if it is {{c1::non-privileged}}, {{c2::relevant to any party’s claim or defense}}, and {{c3::proportional to the needs of the case}}. Proportionality is assessed by considering: - {{c4::Amount in controversy}}. - {{c5::Importance of the issues at stake}} in the action. - {{c6::Resources of the parties}} involved. - {{c7::Importance of the discovery in resolving the issues}}. - {{c8::Parties’ relative access to the information}}. - Whether the {{c9::burden or expense}} of the proposed discovery {{c10::outweighs its likely benefit}}.
cards.easyContent: Discovery reaches information that is non-privileged, relevant, and proportional to the needs of the case. Proportionality weighs money at stake, importance of the issues, parties’ resources, usefulness of the discovery, relative access to information, and burden versus benefit.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Federal Rules, information is discoverable if it is non-privileged, relevant to any party’s claim or defense, and proportional to the needs of the case. Proportionality looks at: (1) amount in controversy; (2) importance of the issues at stake; (3) the parties’ resources; (4) the importance of the discovery in resolving the issues; (5) the parties’ relative access to the information; and (6) whether the burden or expense of the proposed discovery outweighs its likely benefit.
cards.hardContent: The federal scope of discovery includes any non-privileged matter that is relevant to any party’s claim or defense and proportional to the needs of the case. Proportionality is determined by considering: (1) the amount in controversy; (2) the importance of the issues at stake in the action (including public importance); (3) the parties’ resources; (4) the importance of the discovery in resolving the issues; (5) the parties’ relative access to the information; and (6) whether the burden or expense of the proposed discovery outweighs its likely benefit. Discovery outside these limits is subject to objection or limitation by the court.
cards.mnemonic: Scope = NRP; Props = MONEY, IMPORTANCE, RESOURCES, USE, ACCESS, BURDEN.
cards.clozeLite: Discovery covers {{c1::non-privileged, relevant matter}} that is {{c2::proportional to the needs of the case}}, judging {{c3::amount in controversy and issue importance}}, {{c4::resources and access to info}}, and {{c5::burden vs likely benefit}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 048-2. Scope of Discovery – Privileged Material (Undiscoverable)
cards.frontPrompt: Which types of privileged material are generally outside the scope of discovery in federal civil cases?
cards.backPlain: 1. Privileged material is generally undiscoverable 1.1 Privileged communications and materials are outside the scope of discovery and may be withheld if properly asserted. 2. Common privileges that bar discovery 2.1 Attorney–client privilege. 2.2 Work-product protection (subject to a substantial-need exception). 2.3 Physician–patient privilege. 2.4 Clergy–penitent privilege. 2.5 Marital privileges (e.g., spousal communications). 2.6 Journalist–source privilege (recognized in some contexts). 2.7 Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination. 3. Effect on discovery 3.1 If information falls within one of these privileges, it is generally not discoverable unless an exception (such as the work-product substantial-need exception) applies.
cards.cloze: Certain categories of information are generally {{c1::undiscoverable}} because they are {{c2::privileged}}. These include: - {{c3::Attorney–client}} privilege. - {{c4::Work-product}} protection. - {{c5::Physician–patient}} privilege. - {{c6::Clergy–penitent}} privilege. - {{c7::Marital}} privilege. - {{c8::Journalist–source}} privilege (in some contexts). - {{c9::Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination}}. If material is protected by one of these privileges, it is generally {{c10::outside the scope of discovery}} unless an exception applies.
cards.easyContent: Privileged communications and materials are generally outside the scope of discovery. This includes attorney–client, work product, physician–patient, clergy–penitent, marital, journalist–source (in some contexts), and the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination.
cards.mediumContent: Discovery cannot reach privileged material. Common privileges that bar discovery include attorney–client communications, work product (subject to a separate substantial-need exception), physician–patient, clergy–penitent, marital privileges, journalist–source (to the extent recognized), and the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination. If information is privileged and properly asserted, it is generally not discoverable.
cards.hardContent: The scope of discovery is limited by privileges. Information protected by a valid privilege is generally not discoverable. Key privileges include: (1) attorney–client privilege, protecting confidential communications for the purpose of seeking or providing legal advice; (2) the work-product doctrine, protecting materials prepared in anticipation of litigation (subject to a substantial-need exception addressed separately); (3) physician–patient privilege; (4) clergy–penitent privilege; (5) marital privileges, including confidential spousal communications; (6) journalist–source privilege in certain jurisdictions and contexts; and (7) the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination. When a valid privilege applies and is properly invoked, the material is outside the permissible scope of discovery unless a recognized exception (such as the work-product substantial-need exception) applies.
cards.mnemonic: LAW JFMP: Lawyer, Attorney notes, White coat, Jesus, Family, Media, Plead Fifth.
cards.clozeLite: Discovery cannot reach {{c1::privileged material}} such as {{c2::attorney–client communications}}, {{c3::work product}}, {{c4::marital}} and {{c5::Fifth Amendment}} privileges.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Scope of Discovery – Work Product Exception & Privilege Objections
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 048-3. Scope of Discovery – Work Product Exception & Privilege Objections
cards.front: Scope of Discovery – Work Product Exception & Privilege Objections
cards.frontPrompt: When can work product be discovered despite protection, and what is required for a party to object to discovery based on privilege?
cards.backPlain: 1. Work-product protection and its exception 1.1 General rule: Work product (materials prepared in anticipation of litigation) is protected from discovery. 1.2 Exception: Work product may be discoverable upon a showing that: 1.2.1 The requesting party has a substantial need for the materials; and 1.2.2 The materials are not otherwise available (cannot, without undue hardship, obtain their substantial equivalent by other means). 2. Privilege-based objections to discovery 2.1 A party objecting to discovery on the basis of privilege must state the objection with particularity. 2.2 Typically, this includes identifying the nature of the documents, communications, or things not produced, and the privilege claimed, without revealing the privileged information itself (e.g., via a privilege log). 3. Interaction with the scope of discovery 3.1 Even if material is relevant and proportional, it may still be withheld if it is protected work product or otherwise privileged, unless a recognized exception (such as substantial need for work product) is satisfied.
cards.cloze: Work product is generally {{c1::protected}} from discovery, but it may be discovered if the requesting party shows {{c2::substantial need}} for the material and that it is {{c3::not otherwise available}} (cannot, without undue hardship, obtain its substantial equivalent by other means). Objections to discovery based on privilege must be stated with {{c4::particularity}}, typically identifying the nature of the material withheld and the {{c5::specific privilege}} asserted, without disclosing the privileged information itself.
cards.easyContent: Work product is normally protected, but it can be discovered if the requesting party shows substantial need and that they cannot get its equivalent without undue hardship. Privilege objections must be stated with particularity, clearly identifying what is withheld and which privilege is claimed.
cards.mediumContent: Although work product is generally protected, it may be discovered if the requesting party demonstrates a substantial need for the materials and an inability, without undue hardship, to obtain their substantial equivalent by other means. Privilege-based objections to discovery must be asserted with particularity, usually by describing the nature of the documents or information withheld and the specific privilege claimed, so the court can evaluate the claim without revealing the privileged content.
cards.hardContent: The work-product doctrine protects materials prepared in anticipation of litigation from discovery, but this protection is qualified. A court may order discovery of work product if the requesting party shows: (1) a substantial need for the materials to prepare its case; and (2) that it cannot, without undue hardship, obtain their substantial equivalent by other means. Even then, courts must protect against disclosure of counsel’s mental impressions, conclusions, opinions, or legal theories (opinion work product). In addition, a party resisting discovery on the basis of privilege must object with particularity, typically via a privilege log that identifies the nature of the documents or communications, their date, author, recipients, and the specific privilege asserted, enabling assessment of the claim without revealing the privileged information. Thus, even relevant and proportional material may be withheld if privileged or protected work product, unless an applicable exception—such as the substantial-need exception for work product—applies.
cards.mnemonic: SNAP-P: Substantial Need, And no Practical alternative; Particularity for privilege.
cards.clozeLite: Work product is discoverable if the requester shows {{c1::substantial need}} and {{c2::undue hardship getting the equivalent}}; {{c3::privilege objections}} must be made {{c4::with particularity}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Mandatory Disclosures – Initial Disclosures & Duty to Supplement
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 049-1. Mandatory Disclosures – Initial Disclosures & Duty to Supplement
cards.front: Mandatory Disclosures – Initial Disclosures & Duty to Supplement
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule 1.1 Parties must disclose certain information irrespective of requests from the opposing party. 2. Initial disclosures – parties must disclose: 2.1 Sources of discoverable information – witnesses and documents that they may use to support their claims or defenses. 2.2 Damages – a computation of each category of damages claimed. 2.3 Insurance – any insurance agreement that may be used to satisfy all or part of a judgment. 3. Timing of initial disclosures 3.1 Initial disclosures must be made within 14 days of the parties' mandatory meet and confer. 3.2 Parties served or joined later must make initial disclosures within 30 days of being served or joined. 4. Duty to supplement 4.1 Parties must supplement their mandatory disclosures if the produced information becomes incomplete or incorrect.
cards.frontPrompt: What must be included in initial mandatory disclosures in federal civil litigation, when are they due (including for later-joined parties), and what is the ongoing duty to supplement?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule 1.1 Parties must disclose certain information {{c1::without awaiting discovery requests}} from the opposing party. 2. Initial disclosures – parties must disclose: 2.1 {{c2::Sources of discoverable information}} – witnesses and documents that they may use to support their claims or defenses. 2.2 {{c3::Damages}} – a computation of each category of damages claimed. 2.3 {{c4::Insurance}} – any insurance agreement that may be used to satisfy all or part of a judgment. 3. Timing of initial disclosures 3.1 Initial disclosures must be made within {{c5::14 days}} of the parties' mandatory meet and confer. 3.2 Parties served or joined later must make initial disclosures within {{c6::30 days}} of being served or joined. 4. Duty to supplement 4.1 Parties must {{c7::supplement}} their mandatory disclosures if the produced information becomes {{c8::incomplete or incorrect}}.
cards.easyContent: Initial disclosures require each party to automatically provide sources of discoverable information (witnesses and documents they may use), damage computations, and relevant insurance coverage. These are due within 14 days after the meet-and-confer (or 30 days after service/joinder for later parties), and parties must supplement if the information becomes incomplete or incorrect.
cards.mediumContent: Initial mandatory disclosures must, without awaiting requests, identify: (1) sources of discoverable information—witnesses and documents the party may use to support its claims or defenses; (2) a computation of each category of damages claimed; and (3) any insurance agreement that may satisfy all or part of a judgment. These disclosures are due within 14 days after the mandatory meet-and-confer conference, unless a party is served or joined later, in which case that party has 30 days from service or joinder. Parties also have a continuing duty to supplement these disclosures if they learn that prior disclosures were incomplete or incorrect.
cards.hardContent: Under the federal rules, parties must make initial disclosures without waiting for discovery requests. The initial disclosures must include: (1) sources of discoverable information—names, contact information, and the subjects of information for individuals, and descriptions and locations of documents or ESI, that the party may use to support its claims or defenses; (2) a computation of each category of damages claimed, along with the documents or other evidentiary material on which the computation is based; and (3) any insurance agreement under which an insurer may be liable to satisfy all or part of a possible judgment. These initial disclosures must be served within 14 days after the parties’ mandatory Rule 26(f) conference, unless otherwise stipulated or ordered. A party first served or joined after that conference must make its initial disclosures within 30 days after being served or joined. In addition, parties have an ongoing duty to supplement or correct their mandatory disclosures in a timely manner if they learn that the information previously provided is materially incomplete or incorrect.
cards.mnemonic: Initials "SID": Sources, Insurance, Damages; then supplement.
cards.clozeLite: Initial {{c1::mandatory disclosures}} include {{c2::sources of discoverable info}}, {{c3::damage computations}}, and {{c4::insurance}}; due {{c5::14 days after 26(f) (30 for later parties)}} with a duty to {{c6::supplement if incomplete or incorrect}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 049-2. Mandatory Disclosures – Expert & Pretrial Disclosures
cards.backPlain: 1. Expert disclosures 1.1 At least 90 days before trial, parties must identify experts who may be used at trial. 1.2 Parties must produce an expert report containing the expert's opinions, the data and information considered, the expert's qualifications, and similar details. 2. Pretrial disclosures 2.1 Parties must give detailed information about evidence to be used at trial at least 30 days before trial. 2.2 This includes documents and other exhibits that will be used as evidence and the identity of witnesses who will testify at trial.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the federal rules for expert and pretrial disclosures, including what must be disclosed and when?
cards.cloze: 1. Expert disclosures 1.1 At least {{c1::90 days before trial}}, parties must identify experts who may be used at trial. 1.2 They must provide an expert report containing the expert's {{c2::opinions}}, the {{c3::data and information considered}}, the expert's {{c4::qualifications}}, and similar details. 2. Pretrial disclosures 2.1 Parties must provide detailed information about evidence to be used at trial at least {{c5::30 days before trial}}. 2.2 This includes {{c6::documents and other exhibits}} to be used as evidence and the identity of {{c7::witnesses who will testify}} at trial.
cards.easyContent: Expert disclosures require parties to identify testifying experts and provide detailed expert reports at least 90 days before trial. Pretrial disclosures require parties to list the evidence and witnesses they will use at trial at least 30 days before trial.
cards.mediumContent: As trial approaches, parties must make additional mandatory disclosures. At least 90 days before trial, each party must identify any expert witness who may testify at trial and provide a written report stating the expert’s opinions, the data and information considered, and the expert’s qualifications and related details. Separately, at least 30 days before trial, parties must make pretrial disclosures identifying the evidence they expect to present, including documents and other exhibits, and the identity of witnesses who will testify at trial.
cards.hardContent: Beyond initial disclosures, the federal rules require specific expert and pretrial disclosures. Expert disclosures must be made at least 90 days before trial (unless the court orders a different time). A party must identify each expert witness it may use at trial and provide a written report for each retained expert, setting out the expert’s opinions, the facts or data considered in forming them, the expert’s qualifications, a list of publications and prior testimony as required by rule, and information about compensation and other similar details. Closer to trial, at least 30 days before trial, parties must serve pretrial disclosures, which list the evidence they expect to present, including documents, physical exhibits, and the identity of witnesses who will testify, often specifying whether testimony will be live or by deposition. These disclosures ensure the parties have advance notice of expert opinions and the specific evidence to be used at trial.
cards.mnemonic: Think 9-3: 90 days experts, 30 days trial evidence.
cards.clozeLite: Late-stage disclosures: {{c1::expert reports at least 90 days before trial}} and {{c2::pretrial evidence and witness lists at least 30 days before trial}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 050-1. Interrogatories – Definition, Use, and Deadline
cards.frontPrompt: What are interrogatories in federal civil discovery, what are they typically used to find out, and what is the response deadline?
cards.backPlain: Interrogatories (FRCP 33) 1. Definition: - Interrogatories are written questions propounded by one party to an opposing party. 2. Typical use: - Commonly used to obtain basic factual information. - Frequently used to ask about: • The identity of documents; and • The identity of people who may have information related to the parties’ claims and defenses. 3. Response deadline: - The responding party must serve answers or objections within 30 days from service of the interrogatories, unless the court orders or the parties stipulate otherwise.
cards.cloze: {{c1::Interrogatories (FRCP 33)}} are {{c2::written questions propounded by one party to an opposing party}}. They are typically used to obtain {{c3::basic factual information}}, especially the {{c4::identity of documents}} and the {{c5::identity of people who may have information related to claims and defenses}}. The responding party must serve answers or objections within {{c6::30 days from service}} (unless the court or a stipulation provides otherwise).
cards.easyContent: Interrogatories are written questions to the opposing party, usually to find out who and what evidence is involved, and they must generally be answered within 30 days.
cards.mediumContent: Under FRCP 33, interrogatories are written questions served by one party on an opposing party. They are mainly used to identify documents and witnesses or other basic factual information relevant to claims and defenses. The responding party must answer or object within 30 days of service unless the time is changed by court order or stipulation.
cards.hardContent: FRCP 33 allows a party to serve written interrogatories on any other party. Interrogatories are written questions designed to elicit basic factual information and to identify key evidence and witnesses—for example, the identity of documents and people with knowledge concerning the claims and defenses. The responding party must serve written answers or objections within 30 days after being served, unless a shorter or longer time is set by stipulation or court order. Answers must be made under oath and signed by the responding party.
cards.mnemonic: INTERrogatories = written INTERviews to the other side.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::FRCP 33}}, {{c2::interrogatories}} are {{c3::written questions to an opposing party}} and must be {{c4::answered or objected to within 30 days}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Requests for Production – Scope, Non-parties, and Deadline
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 050-2. Requests for Production – Scope, Non-parties, and Deadline
cards.front: Requests for Production – Scope, Non-parties, and Deadline
cards.frontPrompt: What is a request for production in federal civil discovery, what can it reach, how are non-parties compelled, and what is the usual response deadline?
cards.backPlain: Requests for production (RFPs) – FRCP 34 1. Definition and scope: - A request for production is a written request served on a party. - It directs the party to make available for inspection, reviewing, and/or copying: • Documents; • Electronically stored information (ESI); and • Other tangible things - The requested items must be within the responding party’s possession, custody, or control. 2. Response deadline: - The responding party must respond in writing within 30 days after the RFP is served, unless the court or a stipulation provides otherwise. 3. Non-parties: - A non-party cannot be compelled to respond to a Rule 34 request alone. - A non-party may be compelled to produce materials only through a subpoena (typically under Rule 45).
cards.cloze: A {{c1::request for production (RFP)}} under {{c2::FRCP 34}} is a written request to a {{c3::party}} to make available for inspection, review, and/or copying {{c4::documents, electronically stored information (ESI), or other tangible things}} within that party’s {{c5::possession, custody, or control}}. The responding party must serve a written response within {{c6::30 days after service}} of the RFP, unless the time is modified. A {{c7::non-party}} cannot be compelled to respond to a Rule 34 request alone; instead, a non-party may be compelled to produce materials only {{c8::under a subpoena (e.g., Rule 45)}}.
cards.easyContent: Requests for production ask a party to produce documents, ESI, or tangible things in its control, with about 30 days to respond. Non-parties must be compelled by subpoena.
cards.mediumContent: Under FRCP 34, a request for production is a written request to a party to make documents, ESI, or tangible items in its possession, custody, or control available for inspection or copying. The typical response deadline is 30 days after service. Non-parties are not subject to direct Rule 34 requests and must be compelled to produce documents via subpoena, usually under Rule 45.
cards.hardContent: FRCP 34 authorizes a party to serve on any other party a written request to produce and permit inspection, copying, testing, or sampling of documents, electronically stored information, or tangible things in the responding party’s possession, custody, or control. The responding party must respond in writing within 30 days after service, stating whether inspection will be permitted as requested or objecting with specificity. The rule applies only to parties; a non-party may be compelled to produce documents or tangible things only through a subpoena, typically issued under Rule 45.
cards.mnemonic: RFP: Request For Papers from Parties; outsiders need subpoenas.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::FRCP 34}}, a request for production seeks {{c2::documents, ESI, or tangible things}} in a party’s {{c3::possession, custody, or control}}. {{c4::Non-parties}} are reached via {{c5::Rule 45 subpoena}} and the usual response time is {{c6::30 days after service}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Requests for Admission – Scope, Effect, and Responses
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 050-3. Requests for Admission – Scope, Effect, and Responses
cards.front: Requests for Admission – Scope, Effect, and Responses
cards.frontPrompt: What are requests for admission in federal discovery, what can they ask a party to admit, what is the effect of an admission, and how and when must a party respond?
cards.backPlain: Requests for admission (RFAs) – FRCP 36 1. Definition and scope: - A request for admission is a written request served on a party. - It asks the party to admit the truth of discoverable information, including: • Facts; • The application of law to fact; or • The genuineness of documents. 2. Effect of admission: - Any matter admitted is conclusively established for the purposes of the action, unless the court permits withdrawal or amendment. - As a result, issues admitted do not have to be litigated at trial, and the requesting party may show the admission to the jury. 3. Response deadline and types of responses: - The responding party must serve a written response within 30 days from service, unless the court or a stipulation provides otherwise. - The responding party may: • Admit the matter; • Deny the matter; or • State that it lacks knowledge or information necessary to admit or deny the matter, but only after making a reasonable inquiry.
cards.cloze: A {{c1::request for admission (RFA)}} under {{c2::FRCP 36}} is a written request that a {{c3::party}} admit the truth of {{c4::discoverable information}}, including {{c5::facts}}, {{c6::the application of law to fact}}, or the {{c7::genuineness of documents}}. If a matter is admitted, it is {{c8::conclusively established for purposes of the action}} and {{c9::need not be litigated at trial}}; the requesting party may {{c10::show the admission to the jury}}. The responding party must respond within {{c11::30 days from service}} (unless modified) by {{c12::admitting, denying, or stating that it lacks knowledge or information after a reasonable inquiry}}.
cards.easyContent: Requests for admission ask a party to admit specific facts, law–fact applications, or document genuineness. An admission conclusively establishes the matter, and the party has 30 days to admit, deny, or claim lack of knowledge after reasonable inquiry.
cards.mediumContent: Under FRCP 36, requests for admission are written requests to a party asking it to admit facts, the application of law to fact, or the genuineness of documents. Any matter admitted is conclusively established for the case, so it does not need to be proved at trial, and the admission can be shown to the jury. The responding party generally has 30 days to respond by admitting, denying, or stating that it cannot truthfully admit or deny after a reasonable inquiry.
cards.hardContent: FRCP 36 permits a party to serve on another party a written request to admit the truth of any matters within the general scope of discovery, including facts, the application of law to fact, or opinions about either, as well as the genuineness of documents. An admission conclusively establishes the matter in the action, subject only to a court order permitting withdrawal or amendment. As a result, issues admitted are removed from dispute and need not be litigated at trial; the admission itself may be offered to the jury. The responding party must serve a written answer or objection within 30 days after service, unless a different time is set. The answer must specifically admit or deny the matter, or state in detail why the responding party cannot truthfully admit or deny, including that it lacks knowledge or information after making a reasonable inquiry.
cards.mnemonic: RFA: Requests Fix Admissions—facts become fixed for trial.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::FRCP 36}}, requests for admission ask a party to admit {{c2::facts}}, {{c3::application of law to fact}}, or {{c4::genuineness of documents}} within {{c5::30 days}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Physical or Mental Examinations – Availability, Standard, and Privilege
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 050-4. Physical or Mental Examinations – Availability, Standard, and Privilege
cards.front: Physical or Mental Examinations – Availability, Standard, and Privilege
cards.frontPrompt: When can a court order a physical or mental examination in federal civil discovery, what must the moving party show, and what happens to doctor–patient confidentiality if the exam is ordered?
cards.backPlain: Physical or mental examinations – FRCP 35 1. Availability: - Physical or mental examinations are not available as of right. - They are available only through a court order. - Typically used where a person’s physical or mental condition is at issue, such as in a tort case involving bodily injury. 2. Standard for order: - The moving party must demonstrate both: • That the person’s physical or mental condition is in controversy; and • That there is good cause for the examination. 3. Effect on privilege: - If the court orders the examination, doctor–patient confidentiality or privilege as to that particular condition is effectively waived for purposes of the litigation. - The party examined (and usually any party) can obtain a copy of the examiner’s report, but doing so may require production of other medical information about the same condition.
cards.cloze: Under {{c1::FRCP 35}}, a {{c2::physical or mental examination}} is available only {{c3::by court order}}, not as of right. The moving party must show that the person’s {{c4::physical or mental condition is in controversy}} and that there is {{c5::good cause}} for the examination. If the examination is ordered, {{c6::doctor–patient confidentiality or privilege as to that condition}} is effectively {{c7::waived for purposes of the litigation}}, allowing the examination results to be discovered and used in the case.
cards.easyContent: Physical or mental exams in discovery require a court order. The movant must show the condition is in controversy and good cause, and an ordered exam waives doctor–patient confidentiality for that condition in the case.
cards.mediumContent: Under FRCP 35, a physical or mental examination is not automatic; it requires a court order. The movant must show that the person’s physical or mental condition is genuinely in controversy and that there is good cause for the exam. Once the court orders it, doctor–patient confidentiality regarding that condition is effectively waived for the litigation, and the exam report is discoverable subject to the rule’s procedures.
cards.hardContent: FRCP 35 authorizes the court to order a party, or a person in the party’s custody or legal control, to submit to a physical or mental examination. This is available only on motion and for good cause, and only when the party’s physical or mental condition is in controversy—such as when a plaintiff claims personal injury or mental distress. The motion must specify the time, place, manner, conditions, and scope of the examination, as well as the person(s) who will perform it. If an examination is ordered, the examined party is entitled to receive a copy of the examiner’s report, but obtaining the report generally waives any privilege regarding other examinations of the same condition and may require producing related medical records. In any event, the usual doctor–patient confidentiality with respect to that condition is effectively waived for purposes of the litigation.
cards.mnemonic: Rule 35 CHECKUP: Condition in controversy, Good cause, Privilege opened up.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::FRCP 35}}, a physical or mental exam requires a {{c2::court order}} based on {{c3::in-controversy condition}} and {{c4::good cause}}, and {{c5::doctor–patient confidentiality is waived}} for that condition in the case.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Right to a Civil Jury Trial – Seventh Amendment & Mechanics
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 060-1. Right to a Civil Jury Trial – Seventh Amendment & Mechanics
cards.front: Right to a Civil Jury Trial – Seventh Amendment & Mechanics
cards.backPlain: 1. Seventh Amendment right to a civil jury trial 1.1 Scope: The Seventh Amendment provides the right to a jury trial in federal civil actions at law, but not in suits in equity (i.e., not where only equitable relief is sought). 1.2 Demand for jury trial - A party may include a demand for a jury trial in any pleading. - Deadline: The demand must be served no later than 14 days after service of the last pleading directed to a triable issue. - Waiver: Failure to make a timely demand waives the right to a jury trial. 1.3 Jury size and verdict - Number of jurors: A civil jury must have at least 6 and no more than 12 jurors. - Verdict: Unless the parties stipulate otherwise, the verdict must be unanimous and returned by at least 6 jurors. 1.4 Mixed legal and equitable claims - When a case involves both legal and equitable claims, the jury decides the underlying factual issues for the legal (law) claims first. - Any remaining equitable claims are then decided by the judge, who is bound by the jury’s factual findings on the legal issues.
cards.frontPrompt: In federal civil cases, when does the Seventh Amendment guarantee a jury trial, how must it be demanded, what are the jury size and verdict rules, and how are mixed legal/equitable cases handled?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Seventh Amendment}} right to a civil jury trial 1.1 Scope: The Seventh Amendment provides the right to a jury trial in federal civil actions at {{c2::law}}, but not in suits in {{c3::equity}} (i.e., not where only {{c4::equitable relief}} is sought). 1.2 {{c5::Demand}} for jury trial - A party may include a demand for a jury trial in {{c6::any pleading}}. - Deadline: The demand must be served no later than {{c7::14 days}} after service of the last pleading directed to a {{c8::triable issue}}. - {{c9::Waiver}}: Failure to make a timely demand waives the right to a jury trial. 1.3 {{c10::Jury size}} and {{c11::verdict}} - Number of jurors: A civil jury must have at least {{c12::6}} and no more than {{c13::12}} jurors. - Verdict: Unless the parties stipulate otherwise, the verdict must be {{c14::unanimous}} and returned by at least {{c15::6}} jurors. 1.4 Mixed legal and equitable claims - When a case involves both {{c16::legal}} and {{c17::equitable}} claims, the jury decides the underlying factual issues for the legal (law) claims {{c18::first}}. - Any remaining equitable claims are then decided by the {{c19::judge}}, who is {{c20::bound}} by the jury’s factual findings on the legal issues.
cards.easyContent: The Seventh Amendment guarantees a jury in federal civil actions at law (not pure equity). A party must demand a jury within 14 days after the last pleading on a triable issue or the right is waived. Civil juries have 6–12 members and must return a unanimous verdict by at least 6 jurors, unless the parties agree otherwise. In mixed law/equity cases, the jury decides facts for legal claims first, and the judge then decides equitable issues.
cards.mediumContent: In federal civil actions at law, the Seventh Amendment provides a jury trial right, but not in suits seeking only equitable relief. A party must demand a jury in a pleading within 14 days after service of the last pleading directed to a triable issue, or the right is waived. Juries must have 6–12 members, and their verdict must be unanimous and returned by at least 6 jurors unless the parties stipulate otherwise. In cases with both legal and equitable claims, the jury first decides factual issues underlying legal claims; the judge then resolves equitable claims, bound by the jury’s factual findings.
cards.hardContent: The Seventh Amendment preserves the right to a jury trial in federal civil actions at law, meaning claims historically recognized as legal, but not in suits in equity where only equitable relief is sought. A party may demand a jury trial in any pleading, but the demand must be served within 14 days after service of the last pleading directed to a triable issue. Failure to timely demand a jury waives the Seventh Amendment jury right. A civil jury must consist of at least six and no more than twelve jurors. Unless the parties stipulate otherwise, the verdict must be unanimous and returned by at least six jurors. When both legal and equitable claims are present, the court must let the jury decide the factual issues relating to the legal claims first; the judge then decides any remaining equitable claims and is bound by the jury’s factual determinations on the legal issues.
cards.mnemonic: 7th CIVIL JURY: 14 days, 6–12, law first, equity after.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Seventh Amendment}} gives a civil jury right in {{c2::actions at law, not pure equity}} if {{c3::demanded within 14 days}}; juries are {{c4::6–12 unanimous jurors}} and {{c5::decide legal facts before equitable claims}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Voir Dire – For-Cause and Peremptory Challenges
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 060-2. Voir Dire – For-Cause and Peremptory Challenges
cards.front: Voir Dire – For-Cause and Peremptory Challenges
cards.backPlain: 2.
