Voir dire (jury selection) 2.1 Jury selection process - During voir dire, each party may seek to remove prospective jurors from the panel either (a) for cause or (b) through peremptory challenges. 2.2 For-cause strikes - Basis: Used to remove a potential juror for legally sufficient cause, such as bias, prejudice, or a close relationship to a party or witness. - Number: Each side has an unlimited number of for-cause challenges, but each must be supported by an adequate reason recognized by the court. 2.3 Peremptory challenges - Number: Each side generally has 3 peremptory challenges in federal civil cases. - Basis: May be used for any reason, but the reason must be race-neutral and gender-neutral; peremptory challenges cannot be used to intentionally discriminate on the basis of race or gender (Batson-type limitations).
cards.frontPrompt: In federal civil cases, how does voir dire work, and what are the rules governing for-cause and peremptory challenges to jurors?
cards.cloze: 2. {{c1::Voir dire}} (jury selection) 2.1 Jury selection process - During voir dire, each party may seek to remove prospective jurors either {{c2::for cause}} or through {{c3::peremptory challenges}}. 2.2 {{c4::For-cause}} strikes - Basis: Used to remove a potential juror for legally sufficient cause, such as {{c5::bias}}, {{c6::prejudice}}, or a close {{c7::relationship}} to a party or witness. - Number: Each side has an {{c8::unlimited}} number of for-cause challenges, but each must be supported by an adequate reason recognized by the court. 2.3 {{c9::Peremptory}} challenges - Number: Each side generally has {{c10::3}} peremptory challenges in federal civil cases. - Basis: May be used for any reason, but the reason must be {{c11::race-neutral}} and {{c12::gender-neutral}}; peremptory challenges cannot be used to intentionally discriminate on the basis of race or gender.
cards.easyContent: During voir dire, parties can remove jurors either for cause or peremptorily. For-cause strikes are unlimited but must be based on bias, prejudice, or relationship. Each side gets three peremptory challenges, which can be used freely but not for race- or gender-based discrimination.
cards.mediumContent: Voir dire is the jury selection process where parties question potential jurors and move to excuse them. For-cause challenges are unlimited and are used to remove jurors who are biased, prejudiced, or closely related to a party or witness. Peremptory challenges are limited to three per side in federal civil cases and can be used without showing cause, but they must be exercised for race-neutral and gender-neutral reasons and cannot be used to discriminate based on race or gender.
cards.hardContent: In federal civil cases, voir dire is the process by which the court and parties question prospective jurors to detect bias and select an impartial jury. Each party may challenge jurors either for cause or peremptorily. For-cause challenges are based on legally sufficient reasons such as demonstrated bias, prejudice, or close relationship to a party or witness, and each side has an unlimited number of such challenges, subject to the court’s approval. Peremptory challenges, by contrast, do not require a stated cause, but each side is typically limited to three peremptories in civil cases. Despite their discretionary nature, peremptory challenges are constrained by equal protection principles: they may not be exercised on the basis of race or gender, and must be justified with race-neutral and gender-neutral reasons if challenged under Batson-type objections.
cards.mnemonic: V for Voir dire: Veto for Cause is unlimited; Peremptory is 3, never racist or sexist.
cards.clozeLite: In federal civil cases, {{c1::for-cause challenges}} are {{c2::unlimited for bias, prejudice, or relationship}}, while {{c3::peremptory challenges}} are {{c4::limited to three per side}} and {{c5::cannot be based on race or gender}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 060-3. Non-Jury (Bench) Trials and Judge’s Duties
cards.backPlain: 3. Non-jury (bench) trial 3.1 Election of bench trial or documentary trial - Parties can elect to have the case decided on documentary evidence alone or to proceed with a non-jury (bench) trial where the judge is the fact-finder. 3.2 Judge’s duties in a bench trial - In a bench trial, the judge must: - Make findings of fact; and - State separate conclusions of law. - These findings and conclusions are typically set out in a written opinion or on the record and provide the basis for appellate review.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the options for proceeding without a jury in federal civil cases, and what must a judge do in a non-jury (bench) trial?
cards.cloze: 3. {{c1::Non-jury (bench) trial}} 3.1 Election of bench trial or documentary trial - Parties can elect to have the case decided on {{c2::documentary evidence alone}} or to proceed with a {{c3::non-jury (bench) trial}} where the {{c4::judge}} is the fact-finder. 3.2 Judge’s duties in a bench trial - In a bench trial, the judge must: - Make {{c5::findings of fact}}; and - State separate {{c6::conclusions of law}}. - These findings and conclusions are typically set out in a written opinion or on the record and provide the basis for {{c7::appellate review}}.
cards.easyContent: Instead of a jury, parties can have a bench trial or even a decision on documents alone. In a bench trial, the judge acts as fact-finder and must issue findings of fact and separate conclusions of law for appellate review.
cards.mediumContent: If the parties do not use a jury, they may proceed by bench trial or have the court decide the case on documentary evidence alone. In a bench trial, the judge functions as both fact-finder and law-declarer. The judge must enter findings of fact and separately state conclusions of law, usually in a written opinion or on the record, which form the basis for appellate review.
cards.hardContent: When a civil case proceeds without a jury—either because the parties elect a non-jury (bench) trial or submit the case on documentary evidence alone—the judge serves as the trier of fact. In a bench trial, the judge must make findings of fact and state separate conclusions of law, typically in a written decision or announced on the record. These findings and conclusions are essential for appellate review, as appellate courts generally defer to the trial court’s factual findings (unless clearly erroneous) but review its legal conclusions de novo.
cards.mnemonic: BENCH: Both Evidence and Novel Conclusions by Her.
cards.clozeLite: In a {{c1::bench trial}}, the judge acts as {{c2::fact-finder}} and {{c3::law-declarer}} and must {{c4::enter findings of fact and separate conclusions of law}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 064-1. Rule 60(b) – Specific Grounds 1–5
cards.frontPrompt: Under Rule 60(b), for what specific reasons (grounds 1–5) may a court set aside a final judgment or order?
cards.backPlain: Under Federal Rule 60(b), a court may relieve a party from a final judgment or order on the following specific grounds: 1. Mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect • Example: relief from a default judgment entered against a defendant who did not receive actual notice. 2. Newly discovered evidence that could not have been discovered in time to move for a new trial under Rule 59(b) • The evidence must have existed at the time of trial. • The moving party must have made diligent efforts to discover it. • The evidence would likely have changed the result. 3. Fraud, misrepresentation, or misconduct by the opposing party • The fraud or misconduct must be established by clear and convincing evidence. • It must have prevented the party from fully and fairly presenting her case. 4. The judgment is void • Example: a judgment rendered by a court that lacked subject matter jurisdiction. • A judgment is not void merely because it is erroneous. 5. The judgment has been satisfied, released, or discharged • This includes judgments based on an earlier judgment that was later reversed or vacated.
cards.cloze: Under {{c1::Federal Rule 60(b)}}, a court may relieve a party from a final judgment or order on the following specific grounds: 1. {{c2::Mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect}} • Example: relief from a {{c3::default judgment}} entered against a defendant who did not receive {{c4::actual notice}}. 2. {{c5::Newly discovered evidence}} that could not have been discovered in time to move for a new trial • The evidence must have {{c6::existed at the time of trial}}. • The moving party must have made {{c7::diligent efforts}} to discover it. • The evidence would likely have {{c8::changed the result}}. 3. {{c9::Fraud, misrepresentation, or misconduct}} by the opposing party • The fraud or misconduct must be established by {{c10::clear and convincing evidence}}. • It must have prevented the party from {{c11::fully and fairly presenting her case}}. 4. The {{c12::judgment is void}} • Example: a judgment rendered by a court that lacked {{c13::subject matter jurisdiction}}. • A judgment is not void merely because it is {{c14::erroneous}}. 5. The judgment has been {{c15::satisfied, released, or discharged}} • Includes judgments based on an earlier judgment that was later {{c16::reversed or vacated}}.
cards.easyContent: Rule 60(b) allows a court to set aside a judgment for: (1) mistake or excusable neglect, (2) newly discovered evidence that meets strict criteria, (3) fraud or misconduct by the opposing party, (4) a void judgment, or (5) a judgment that has been satisfied, released, or discharged.
cards.mediumContent: Specific Rule 60(b) grounds 1–5 are: (1) mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect (e.g., default where the defendant lacked actual notice); (2) newly discovered evidence that existed at trial, could not have been found with diligent efforts, and would likely have changed the result; (3) fraud, misrepresentation, or misconduct by the opposing party, proven by clear and convincing evidence and preventing a full and fair presentation; (4) a void judgment, such as one entered without subject matter jurisdiction (mere error is not enough); and (5) a judgment that has been satisfied, released, or discharged, including when based on an earlier judgment that was later reversed or vacated.
cards.hardContent: Federal Rule 60(b) enumerates five principal grounds for setting aside a final judgment or order. First, a court may grant relief for mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect, such as a default judgment entered against a defendant who never received actual notice. Second, relief is available for newly discovered evidence that existed at the time of trial, could not have been discovered earlier despite diligent efforts, and would likely have changed the outcome. Third, the court may vacate a judgment for fraud, misrepresentation, or misconduct by the opposing party, but this must be established by clear and convincing evidence and must have prevented the movant from fully and fairly presenting her case. Fourth, a party may obtain relief from a void judgment, such as a judgment rendered by a court lacking subject matter jurisdiction; a judgment is not void merely because it is legally erroneous. Fifth, relief is proper when the judgment has been satisfied, released, or discharged, including when it rests on an earlier judgment that has since been reversed or vacated.
cards.mnemonic: Rule 60(b) 1–5 = MNFSJ: Mistake, New evidence, Fraud, void, Satisfied.
cards.clozeLite: Rule 60(b) grounds 1–5: {{c1::mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect}}; {{c2::newly discovered evidence}}; {{c3::fraud, misrepresentation, or misconduct}}; {{c4::void judgment}}; {{c5::satisfied, released, or discharged judgment}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 064-2. Rule 60(b) – Catchall Extraordinary Relief (Ground 6)
cards.frontPrompt: What is Rule 60(b)(6) catchall relief, and in what kinds of situations is it available?
cards.backPlain: Under Rule 60(b)(6), a court may relieve a party from a final judgment or order for "any other reason that justifies relief." • This catchall provision is used only in extraordinary circumstances. • It is not a substitute for the more specific grounds in Rule 60(b)(1)–(5) and cannot be used to evade their stricter time limits or element requirements. • Courts generally require a showing of exceptional hardship or injustice that cannot be adequately addressed under the other subsections of Rule 60(b).
cards.cloze: Under {{c1::Rule 60(b)(6)}}, a court may relieve a party from a final judgment or order for {{c2::"any other reason that justifies relief"}}. • This catchall is used only in {{c3::extraordinary circumstances}}. • It is not a substitute for the more {{c4::specific grounds}} in Rule 60(b)(1)–(5) and cannot be used to evade their {{c5::time limits}} or element requirements. • Courts typically require {{c6::exceptional hardship or injustice}} that cannot be addressed under the other subsections.
cards.easyContent: Rule 60(b)(6) is a narrow catchall that lets a court set aside a judgment for any other reason that justifies relief, but only in truly extraordinary circumstances.
cards.mediumContent: Rule 60(b)(6) allows relief from a final judgment for "any other reason that justifies relief," but courts strictly limit it to extraordinary circumstances involving exceptional hardship or injustice. It cannot be used to repackage arguments that properly fall under Rule 60(b)(1)–(5) or to avoid those subsections’ tighter requirements or time limits.
cards.hardContent: Rule 60(b)(6) is the residual or catchall provision of Rule 60(b). It authorizes a court to relieve a party from a final judgment or order for "any other reason that justifies relief." Courts interpret this language narrowly: it is available only in truly extraordinary circumstances and is not a general license to reopen final judgments. A movant must show exceptional hardship or injustice that cannot be fairly remedied under any of the specific grounds in Rule 60(b)(1)–(5). Rule 60(b)(6) cannot be used to circumvent the one‑year limitation or other element requirements that apply to those specific grounds.
cards.mnemonic: 60(b)(6) = 6th SENSE safety valve for rare injustice.
cards.clozeLite: Rule {{c1::60(b)(6)}} is a narrow {{c2::catchall}} for "{{c3::any other reason that justifies relief}}" in {{c4::truly extraordinary circumstances}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 064-3. Rule 60(b) – Timing for Grounds 1–6
cards.frontPrompt: What are the timing requirements for motions under Rule 60(b), and how do they differ for grounds 1–3 versus 4–6?
cards.backPlain: Timing requirements under Rule 60(b): 1. General requirement • All Rule 60(b) motions must be made within a reasonable time. 2. Grounds 1–3: mistake, newly discovered evidence, and fraud/misconduct • The motion must be brought within a reasonable time, • And in any event no more than one year after entry of judgment. 3. Grounds 4–6: void judgment, satisfied judgment, and other reasons (including 60(b)(6)) • The motion must be brought within a reasonable time. • There is no absolute one‑year cap, but delay must still be reasonable in light of the circumstances and the interest in finality.
cards.cloze: Timing requirements under {{c1::Rule 60(b)}}: 1. General requirement • All Rule 60(b) motions must be made within a {{c2::reasonable time}}. 2. Grounds {{c3::1–3}} (mistake, newly discovered evidence, fraud/misconduct) • Must be brought within a {{c4::reasonable time}}, • And in any event no more than {{c5::one year}} after entry of judgment. 3. Grounds {{c6::4–6}} (void judgment, satisfied judgment, other reasons) • Must be brought within a {{c7::reasonable time}}. • There is {{c8::no one‑year cap}}, though delay must still be reasonable given the circumstances and finality concerns.
cards.easyContent: All Rule 60(b) motions must be made within a reasonable time. For grounds 1–3 (mistake, new evidence, fraud), there is also a strict one‑year cap from entry of judgment. Grounds 4–6 (void, satisfied, or other reasons) have no one‑year cap but still must be raised within a reasonable time.
cards.mediumContent: Rule 60(b) imposes a universal "reasonable time" requirement for all motions. In addition, motions based on grounds 1–3—mistake or excusable neglect, newly discovered evidence, and fraud or misconduct—must be filed no later than one year after entry of judgment. Motions based on grounds 4–6—a void judgment, a satisfied or discharged judgment, or any other reason (including Rule 60(b)(6))—are not subject to the one‑year limit but still must be filed within a reasonable time, considering the circumstances and the interest in finality.
cards.hardContent: The timing rules for Rule 60(b) are critical on exams. All Rule 60(b) motions must be made within a reasonable time. For the first three grounds—mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect; newly discovered evidence; and fraud, misrepresentation, or misconduct—the rule adds an absolute deadline: the motion must be filed within a reasonable time and, in any event, not more than one year after entry of the judgment or order. For grounds four through six—a void judgment; a judgment that has been satisfied, released, or discharged; or any other reason that justifies relief—there is no one‑year cap, but the motion must still be brought within a reasonable time under the circumstances. Courts weigh the movant’s diligence and the prejudice to the opposing party and the judicial system’s interest in finality.
cards.mnemonic: Rule 60(b) timing: "1–3, one year; 4–6, just reasonable."
cards.clozeLite: Rule 60(b) requires filing within a {{c1::reasonable time}}; grounds {{c2::1–3}} also have a strict {{c3::one-year cap from judgment}}, while {{c4::4–6}} do {{c5::not}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 065-1. Appeals – Standards of Review
cards.backPlain: Appellate courts review different types of trial-court decisions under distinct standards of review. 1. Questions of law: reviewed **de novo**; the appellate court may substitute its judgment for that of the trial judge. 2. Questions of fact: a. Non-jury (bench) trials: factual findings will not be disturbed unless **clearly erroneous**. b. Jury trials: factual findings will not be disturbed unless a **reasonable jury could not have reached the same conclusion**. 3. Mixed questions of law and fact: reviewed **de novo**. 4. Discretionary matters (e.g., evidentiary rulings): reviewed for **abuse of discretion**.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main standards of appellate review for questions of law, questions of fact (bench vs. jury), mixed questions, and discretionary matters?
cards.cloze: Appellate courts review different trial-court decisions under distinct standards of review. 1. Questions of law: reviewed {{c1::de novo}}; the appellate court may substitute its judgment for that of the trial judge. 2. Questions of fact: a. Non-jury (bench) trials: factual findings will not be disturbed unless {{c2::clearly erroneous}}. b. Jury trials: factual findings will not be disturbed unless a {{c3::reasonable jury}} could not have reached the same conclusion. 3. Mixed questions of law and fact: reviewed {{c4::de novo}}. 4. Discretionary matters (e.g., evidentiary rulings): reviewed for {{c5::abuse of discretion}}.
cards.easyContent: Appellate courts review law and mixed questions de novo, bench-trial facts for clear error, jury facts for reasonableness, and discretionary rulings for abuse of discretion.
cards.mediumContent: Questions of law and mixed questions are reviewed de novo, allowing the appellate court to substitute its judgment. Bench-trial factual findings are reviewed for clear error; jury findings are upheld unless no reasonable jury could have reached them. Discretionary rulings, like evidentiary decisions, are reviewed only for abuse of discretion.
cards.hardContent: On appeal, the standard of review depends on the type of issue. Pure questions of law, as well as mixed questions of law and fact, are reviewed de novo, meaning the appellate court gives no deference to the trial court’s view. Findings of fact from bench trials are not reversed unless clearly erroneous, a highly deferential standard. Jury findings of fact are upheld unless no reasonable jury could have reached the same result. Discretionary rulings—including evidentiary decisions and other matters committed to the trial court’s judgment—are reviewed only for abuse of discretion.
cards.mnemonic: L-F-D: Law/mixed = de novo; Facts = deferential; Discretion = abuse.
cards.clozeLite: Appellate courts review {{c1::questions of law}} and {{c2::mixed questions}} {{c3::de novo}}, bench-trial facts for {{c4::clear error}} and jury facts for {{c5::no reasonable jury}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Final Judgment Rule and Timing of Appeal
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 065-2. Final Judgment Rule and Timing of Appeal
cards.front: Final Judgment Rule and Timing of Appeal
cards.backPlain: Final Judgment Rule and basic timing requirements for appeals. 1. Final Judgment Rule: a. General rule: An appeal may be taken only from a **final judgment**. b. Final judgment: The trial court has made an **ultimate decision on the merits of the entire case**. c. Jurisdiction: If there is no final judgment (and no applicable exception), the appellate court **lacks jurisdiction**. 2. Timing of appeal: a. Notice of appeal must be filed in the **trial court**. b. The notice of appeal must generally be filed within **30 days** of entry of the final judgment.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the Final Judgment Rule in civil appeals, what counts as a final judgment, and what is the basic timing requirement for filing a notice of appeal?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::Final Judgment Rule}}, an appeal may be taken only from a {{c2::final judgment}}. A final judgment is an {{c3::ultimate decision on the merits of the entire case}}. If there is no final judgment (and no exception applies), the {{c4::appellate court lacks jurisdiction}}. For timing, a {{c5::notice of appeal}} must be filed in the {{c6::trial court}} within {{c7::30 days}} of entry of the final judgment.
cards.easyContent: Only final judgments—ultimate decisions on the merits of the entire case—are appealable, unless an exception applies. A notice of appeal must be filed in the trial court within 30 days after entry of the final judgment.
cards.mediumContent: The Final Judgment Rule allows appeals only from final judgments, meaning the trial court has fully resolved the entire case on the merits. Absent a final judgment or an applicable exception, the appellate court lacks jurisdiction. To perfect an appeal, the appellant must file a notice of appeal in the trial court, generally within 30 days of entry of the final judgment.
cards.hardContent: The Final Judgment Rule limits appellate jurisdiction to final judgments—orders that constitute an ultimate decision on the merits of the entire action, leaving nothing for the trial court to do but execute the judgment. Without such a final judgment (or an applicable exception), the appellate court cannot hear the appeal. As a procedural requirement, a notice of appeal must be filed in the trial court, typically within 30 days after entry of the final judgment. Failure to file a timely notice is generally a jurisdictional defect that can forfeit the right to appeal.
cards.mnemonic: FINAL: Fully decided, In trial court, Notice in 30 days, Appeal Limited.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::Final Judgment Rule}}, appeals lie only from {{c2::final judgments resolving the entire case}}, and a notice of appeal must be filed in the {{c3::trial court}} within {{c4::30 days}} of {{c5::entry of the final judgment}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Appeals – Exceptions to the Final Judgment Rule
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 065-3. Appeals – Exceptions to the Final Judgment Rule
cards.front: Appeals – Exceptions to the Final Judgment Rule
cards.backPlain: Certain orders are immediately appealable even without a final judgment. 1. Injunctions: a. Orders concerning **injunctions** (granting, denying, modifying, or dissolving) are typically subject to **interlocutory appeal**. 2. Class actions: a. Orders **granting or denying class certification** may be appealed on an interlocutory basis. 3. Controlling legal questions: a. Some orders involving **debatable questions of controlling law** may be appealed if: i. The order involves a **controlling issue of law**, ii. There is **substantial ground for difference of opinion** on that issue, and iii. An **immediate appeal may materially advance termination of the litigation**. 4. Multiple claims and/or parties: a. In cases involving multiple claims or parties, the trial court may enter a **final judgment as to one or more claims or parties**. b. Such a judgment is immediately **appealable**, even though other claims or parties remain in the case.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main exceptions to the Final Judgment Rule that allow interlocutory or partial appeals (injunctions, class certification, controlling legal questions, and multiple claims/parties)?
cards.cloze: Certain orders are immediately appealable even without a final judgment. 1. {{c1::Injunctions}}: Orders concerning injunctions (granting, denying, modifying, or dissolving) are typically subject to {{c2::interlocutory appeal}}. 2. {{c3::Class actions}}: Orders {{c4::granting or denying class certification}} may be appealed on an interlocutory basis. 3. {{c5::Controlling legal questions}}: Some orders involving {{c6::debatable questions of controlling law}} may be appealed if: i. The order involves a {{c7::controlling issue of law}}, ii. There is {{c8::substantial ground for difference of opinion}}, and iii. An {{c9::immediate appeal may materially advance termination of the litigation}}. 4. {{c10::Multiple claims and/or parties}}: In such cases, the trial court may enter a {{c11::final judgment as to one or more claims or parties}}, and that judgment is immediately {{c12::appealable}} even though other claims or parties remain.
cards.easyContent: Even without a final judgment, some orders are immediately appealable: injunction orders, class certification decisions, certain certified controlling legal questions, and separate final judgments for some claims or parties in multi-claim or multi-party cases.
cards.mediumContent: The Final Judgment Rule has important exceptions. Orders regarding injunctions are typically appealable interlocutory orders. Class certification orders—granting or denying certification—can be appealed before final judgment. Some orders that turn on a debatable controlling legal question may be certified for immediate appeal when there is substantial ground for difference of opinion and immediate review could materially advance the litigation. In multi-claim or multi-party cases, the court may enter a final judgment as to fewer than all claims or parties, and that partial judgment is immediately appealable.
cards.hardContent: Several categories of orders are appealable notwithstanding the absence of a final judgment. Orders relating to injunctions, including grants, denials, modifications, or dissolutions, are typically subject to interlocutory appeal. Orders granting or denying class certification may also be appealed before the case is fully resolved. Additionally, certain orders raising debatable controlling legal questions can be certified for interlocutory review where the order involves a controlling issue of law, there is substantial ground for difference of opinion, and an immediate appeal may materially advance the termination of the litigation. Finally, in actions involving multiple claims or multiple parties, the trial court may direct entry of a separate final judgment as to one or more—but fewer than all—claims or parties, making that judgment immediately appealable even though the rest of the case continues.
cards.mnemonic: I-CLASS-M: Injunctions, CLASS cert, controlling Questions, Multiple claims/parties.
cards.clozeLite: Exceptions to the Final Judgment Rule include {{c1::injunction orders}}, {{c2::class certification orders}}, {{c3::certified controlling legal questions}}, and {{c4::partial final judgments in multi-claim/party cases}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Interlocutory Appeals – Orders Reviewable as of Right
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 066-1. Interlocutory Appeals – Orders Reviewable as of Right
cards.front: Interlocutory Appeals – Orders Reviewable as of Right
cards.backPlain: Although only final orders are usually appealable, certain interlocutory orders are reviewable as of right: 1. Injunctions: Orders concerning an injunction. 2. Receivers: Orders concerning the appointment of a receiver. 3. Patent: Orders in patent cases where only an accounting is left in the case. 4. Property: Orders affecting property, such as attachment or similar property-control orders.
cards.frontPrompt: Which interlocutory orders are immediately appealable as of right in federal court?
cards.cloze: Although only final orders are usually appealable, certain {{c1::interlocutory orders}} are reviewable {{c2::as of right}}: 1. {{c3::Injunctions}} – orders concerning an injunction. 2. {{c4::Receivers}} – orders concerning the appointment of a receiver. 3. {{c5::Patent}} – orders in patent cases where only an {{c6::accounting}} is left in the case. 4. {{c7::Property}} – orders affecting property, such as {{c8::attachment}}.
cards.easyContent: Some non-final orders can always be appealed immediately: orders concerning injunctions, receivers, certain patent orders where only an accounting remains, and property orders like attachments.
cards.mediumContent: Interlocutory orders reviewable as of right include: (1) orders concerning injunctions; (2) orders concerning the appointment of receivers; (3) certain patent orders where only an accounting remains; and (4) property orders such as attachments or similar orders affecting property.
cards.hardContent: Despite the final judgment rule, several interlocutory orders are statutorily reviewable as of right. These include: (1) orders concerning injunctions (e.g., granting, denying, modifying, or dissolving an injunction); (2) orders concerning the appointment of a receiver; (3) certain patent case orders where the only remaining task is an accounting; and (4) property orders, such as attachment or other orders that significantly affect property interests. These categories may be appealed immediately without needing special certification.
cards.mnemonic: I-R-P-P: Injunctions, Receivers, Patent, Property.
cards.clozeLite: Interlocutory orders reviewable as of right include {{c1::injunction orders}}, {{c2::receiver appointments}}, {{c3::certain patent orders (accounting only)}}, and {{c4::property orders like attachments}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.topic: Interlocutory Appeals – Interlocutory Appeals Act & Class Certification
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 066-2. Interlocutory Appeals – Interlocutory Appeals Act & Class Certification
cards.front: Interlocutory Appeals – Interlocutory Appeals Act & Class Certification
cards.backPlain: In addition to interlocutory orders appealable as of right, certain non-final orders may receive discretionary interlocutory review: 1. Interlocutory Appeals Act: 1.1 An appellate court may hear an appeal of a non-final order if the trial judge certifies that the order: • Involves a controlling issue of law; • There is substantial ground for difference of opinion on that issue; and • An immediate appeal may materially advance the ultimate termination of the litigation. 2. Class Actions: 2.1 An appellate court may review an order granting or denying class certification.
cards.frontPrompt: When can an interlocutory order be appealed under the Interlocutory Appeals Act, and how are class certification orders treated for appeal purposes?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::Interlocutory Appeals Act}}, an appellate court may hear an appeal of a non-final order if the trial judge certifies that the order: • Involves a {{c2::controlling issue of law}}; • There is {{c3::substantial ground for difference of opinion}} on that issue; and • An immediate appeal may {{c4::materially advance the ultimate termination of the litigation}}. In addition, in {{c5::class actions}}, an appellate court may review an order {{c6::granting or denying class certification}}.
cards.easyContent: A non-final order can be appealed if the trial judge certifies it under the Interlocutory Appeals Act as a controlling, disputed legal issue whose early review could speed up the case, and class certification decisions can also be reviewed before final judgment.
cards.mediumContent: The Interlocutory Appeals Act allows discretionary appeal of a non-final order when the district judge certifies that it involves a controlling legal issue, there is substantial disagreement about that issue, and an immediate appeal could materially advance the litigation. Separately, orders granting or denying class certification in class actions are also subject to discretionary immediate review by the appellate court.
cards.hardContent: Beyond those interlocutory orders appealable as of right, federal law provides discretionary interlocutory review. Under the Interlocutory Appeals Act, the district judge must certify that a non-final order: (1) involves a controlling issue of law; (2) presents substantial ground for difference of opinion; and (3) that an immediate appeal may materially advance the ultimate termination of the litigation. The court of appeals then has discretion to accept or reject the appeal. Additionally, in the class action context, the court of appeals may review orders granting or denying class certification prior to final judgment, providing early appellate scrutiny of decisions that dramatically affect the scope and stakes of the litigation.
cards.mnemonic: IAC: Issue controlling, Agreement conflicted, speeds Case; plus class cert review.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::Interlocutory Appeals Act}}, a non-final order with a {{c2::controlling legal issue}}, {{c3::substantial disagreement}}, and where {{c4::immediate appeal may speed litigation}} can be reviewed, and {{c5::class certification orders}} also get {{c6::discretionary immediate review}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 066-3. Interlocutory Appeals – Collateral Order Exception
cards.backPlain: Under the collateral order exception, an interlocutory order may be immediately appealed even though it is not a final judgment, if it satisfies all of the following: 1. Collateral: The issue is too distinct from the merits of the case (i.e., it is collateral to the merits). 2. Importance: The issue is too important to be denied immediate review. 3. Unreviewable later: The order would essentially be unreviewable if the parties waited for a final judgment.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for an interlocutory order to be immediately appealable under the collateral order exception?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::collateral order exception}}, an interlocutory order may be immediately appealed if it: 1. Is {{c2::collateral}} – too distinct from the merits of the case; 2. Is too {{c3::important}} to be denied immediate review; and 3. Would essentially be {{c4::unreviewable}} if the parties waited for final judgment.
cards.easyContent: An interlocutory order can be appealed under the collateral order doctrine if it is separate from the merits, very important, and effectively unreviewable after final judgment.
cards.mediumContent: The collateral order exception allows immediate appeal of a narrow class of non-final orders when: (1) the order resolves an issue that is collateral to the merits; (2) the issue is sufficiently important that delaying review would be unacceptable; and (3) the order would effectively be unreviewable on appeal from a final judgment.
cards.hardContent: The collateral order doctrine is a narrow exception to the final judgment rule. An interlocutory order qualifies only if it: (1) conclusively determines the disputed question; (2) resolves an important issue completely separate from the merits (i.e., it is collateral); and (3) is effectively unreviewable on appeal from a final judgment, such that delaying review would effectively deny the right at stake. In bar-exam shorthand, the order must be collateral to the merits, too important to defer review, and essentially unreviewable later.
cards.mnemonic: C-I-U: Collateral, Important, Unreviewable later.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::collateral order exception}} allows appeal of a {{c2::non-final order}} that is {{c3::collateral to the merits}}, {{c4::important}}, and {{c5::effectively unreviewable later}}.

cards.subject: Civil Procedure
cards.rawHeader: Civil Procedure 066-4. Extraordinary Writs – Mandamus & Prohibition
cards.backPlain: When a party is aggrieved by an order that is not otherwise appealable, it may seek an extraordinary writ to obtain immediate relief: 1. Types of writs: 1.1 Mandamus: A writ to compel a lower court or official to perform a duty. 1.2 Prohibition: A writ to prohibit a lower court from taking or continuing unauthorized action. 2. Requirements: 2.1 The party must show that irreparable harm will occur if relief is denied; and 2.2 The normal route of appeal is inadequate to address the problem.
cards.frontPrompt: When are extraordinary writs such as mandamus or prohibition available to challenge an unappealable order, and what must a party show?
cards.cloze: If a party is aggrieved by an order that is not otherwise appealable, it may seek an {{c1::extraordinary writ}}: 1. Types: • {{c2::Mandamus}} – to compel a lower court or official to perform a duty. • {{c3::Prohibition}} – to prohibit a lower court from taking or continuing unauthorized action. 2. Requirements: • The party must show {{c4::irreparable harm}} will occur; and • That the {{c5::normal route of appeal is inadequate}}.
cards.easyContent: If no normal appeal is available, a party can seek an extraordinary writ like mandamus or prohibition, but must show irreparable harm and that regular appeals are inadequate.
cards.mediumContent: Extraordinary writs, such as mandamus and prohibition, provide a last-resort mechanism to control lower courts when no ordinary appeal is available. The party must demonstrate irreparable harm and that the normal appellate process is inadequate to correct the error.
cards.hardContent: Extraordinary writs are exceptional remedies used to control lower courts when a party cannot obtain effective review through normal appeals. A writ of mandamus directs a lower court or official to perform a ministerial duty or to correct an abuse of discretion; a writ of prohibition restrains a lower court from acting outside its jurisdiction or from proceeding in a clearly unauthorized manner. To obtain such a writ, the petitioner must show a clear and indisputable right to relief, that irreparable harm will occur without immediate intervention, and that the usual appellate routes are inadequate or unavailable.
cards.mnemonic: Writs: MANDAMUS Makes do, PROHIBITION Prevents, when Appeals are Awful.
cards.clozeLite: Extraordinary writs like {{c1::mandamus}} and {{c2::prohibition}} are a {{c3::last-resort}} when {{c4::no ordinary appeal}} is available and {{c5::irreparable harm}} plus {{c6::inadequate appellate remedies}} are shown.
